full text doc: i currently live in california but am originally from houston. i was addicted to crave cupcakes in houston, but while visiting my boyfriend in indy we came to this place. i was a little skeptical, but very pleasantly surprised. on our first visit, we took home a red velvet elvis, peanut butter blackout, and razzamatazz. all three were fantastic. the cake was moist and the frosting was light and rich with flavor. being used to places like crave and crumbs, the prices didn't phase me... but if you have never paid over $ 3 for a cupcake, you may have some sticker shock. we went three days in a row, and i made sure to take another red velvet elvis for the plane ride home. i will definitely make sure we hit them up when i am back in indy.

full text doc: a tip of the cap to yelp for the option to call / text ahead for seating, without it ; could've been a long day. my previous experiences with first watch were long waits and slow service, especially on saturdays and sundays for the brunch crowd. not totally their fault though as brunch locales are very fleeting in saint louis county. today we were in a time crunch and with the text feature where you could enter your name on the virtual waiting, it assuaged our time concerns. seated almost immediately, the service was prompt, fast, and so was the delivery of our food. no loss in quality either, the " bacado " omelette with a small spring mix salad and bread was delicious. it was so good i even ate the bread which is a rarity for me, coupled with the strawberry jam ; it was a must have. next time with a little more time we'll peruse the menu for the other options in the expansive list which features healthier alternatives as well. we'll be back and so will everyone it seems, the place was and is always ; packed.

full text doc: having been to the barcade in bk, this one is definitely superior. plenty of games, good looking building, good draft selection, and a kitchen. people who are b * tching about the prices, these are not cheap beers, and it is refreshing to be able to get a good beer from a draft selection that isn't dominated by philly beers. my only beef here was the food. if you are going to give me a sandwich and that is all you serve, give me a sandwich. my turkey sandiwch was really good, with goat cheese and cranberry, but the turkey was tiny little slices, not enough to satisfy my hunger. either way, the atmosphere here kicks ass, laid back, plenty of games, good beers. galaga. definitely worth checking out, and this is not a pbr and a shot bar, which is a good thing people.

full text doc: a friend and i went here on a recent friday, lured in by their happy hour $ 4. 50 pizzas. we grabbed a table and waited for a server. when none came, i went to the bar to buy drinks. i asked the bartender if we ordered food at the bar or the table and he said a server would come around. we waited some more and finally flagged down a passing server. she asked, " am i your waitress? " in an annoyed way. we explained no one had come over yet and ordered, buffalo chicken pizza for me and deluxe nachos for my friend. when the food came, the pizza was good. thin crust, buffalo sauce with a kick and it was topped with crunchy fresh celery, an unusual and tasty addition. it was well worth the $ 4. 50 and the individual was more than i could eat. but even a super cheap pizza was not worth the lazy service. i don't think i'll be going back.

full text doc: a dog - friendly independent establishment gets a baseline 3 stars. throw in craft beer, well, that's good for another star. pile on with free soft pretzels, a relaxed atmosphere, and a great location for people watching, then it doesn't get much better than this. sure, they don't sell pints, but you can get flights of a single beer, which, essentially, becomes a pint. i've never felt rushed, and we always have a place to sit, typically in the north window ( say hi if you see us there! ). also, they use special caps on their growlers that allows them to pressurize the beer, keeping it fresher, longer. not that it usually lasts that long, but nice nonetheless...

full text doc: a charming euro wine bar on one of the loveliest tree - lined streets in st. louis. the patio seating is pretty unparalleled. it's a great place for a date, a group of friends, or an after - dinner drink with the parents. sasha's has been through a lot of growing pains in its five or so years. it's always had a wonderful wine selection, but the stock wasn't very reliable and the service could be a bit lax. recently though, the belt has tightened and business seems to be running a lot smoother.

full text doc: if you know me, you know i'm a fan of bars. i am the kind of person that feels that every bar has its place. where is balcony bar's place is in my heart. this bar is equivalent to comfort food for me. no matter what time of day, no matter how large or small the crowd, no matter if i'm alone or with 15 friends, i always feel comfortable here. friendly patrons and bartenders make this an easy place to hang out even when you walk in along. ( arguably, though, that could be said of nearly every bar in the city. new orleans is known for its openness and acceptance. ) there are televisions for watching sports or whatever and a pretty good jukebox too. they have amazing bar food from quesadillas, pizza, hot wings and a lot more. there is a wide liquor selection, and the drink specials can't really be beat. i once sat at this bar for about 4 hours in the middle of the day, and paid a $ 12 bar tab. and we all know, i'm not a slow drinker. i like to sit upstairs, either at the bar, or outside on their amazing balcony overlooking magazine street. but there is

full text doc: clearwater location not organized. i was a member for 6 months. on three occasions, i could not reach them by phone it went to voicemail during working hours. i called shortly after they opened. my frustration is that no one calls you back. i end up calling them in the afternoon to inquire to why i did not get a courtesy call back. the employee was very direct and unprofessional with her response that they didn't listen to it because they have been busy and that they were all booked up for the day anyway. why have the option of voice mail if no one listens to it? i've been in customer service for over 30 years, this is unacceptable, especially when there is so much competition. i spoke to management, who refused to give me the name of the franchise owner. she stated he will contact me ; he never did. the massage therapist are excellent, but the front desk staffing and manager need to be re - trained in customer service excellence. i now go to the palm harbor location. they are consistently amazing and they answer their phone. susan

full text doc: holy wow! this is an amazing little bakery. i already knew them from their breads and from their pizzas at their farmers market location. this little shop is just perfect and i'm dreading the day its popularity catches up with its quality - - it's only been open a month and i predict that by the fall there will always be a line. the premise is simple ( and one that i'm surprised took this long to get realized in nashville ) : well made breads - - world class breads actually - - and a few sandwich options for even extra enticement to get you in the door. the crema coffee is a bonus. this morning my wife and i happened by and we each got a breakfast sandwich - - the ham, egg and cheese for me, the emma lou for my wife. both were delicious and had a rustic simplicity that made for great start to the day. even better, we all finally have the option to buy fresh bella breads throughout the week.

full text doc: anthropologie is a wonderful chain. to give people an idea of the product line, it's to urban outfitters what banana repulic is to gap. ( you can check the accuracy of that comparison since all four stores are within a 3 blocks on walnut st. ) the housewares are a hipster, asian - infused, french country style that look a bit better in a professional's apartment than the cutesy plastic tchotchkes they sell at urban outfitters. the clothing is pricey for what it is - thin knit t - shirts and thick knit sweaters - but great when you can get it on sale. check the basement for deals. you have to like the " concept " of the store. one walk through should give you an idea. it's not a place to get the basics, but you'll find some fun wardrobe additions.

full text doc: i really wanted to love this place, but it didn't totally do it for me. i love that they converted the historic factory into a mall of locally, independently - owned businesses, but overall i found the place a bit sleepy and grandmothery. there weren't many people around when i visited, so maybe that had something to do with it. the problem with an old factory is that it's a really large space, and can tend to feel pretty empty without huge throngs of people and bustling activity going on. hearing your voice echo in a shopping mall is kind of eerie and unsettling. there really is a decent variety of businesses - art galleries, gift shops, artisan guitars, cafes, toys, clothes, etc., but somehow i got the impression that i would be much more impressed with the offerings if i had a couple more decades under my belt. the aesthetic is definitely cool. the formerly industrial building makes for a stark, clean - lined backdrop that is historic but contemporary at the same time. the soaring ceilings and tons of high - set windows bring in lots of natural light during the day, and i saw little twinkle lights wrapped around some of the plants, which i'm sure add a little sparkle and a

full text doc: this is a great barbershop located in old city. i've been coming here for around 5 months now since moving nearby it. merle and lisa are both great hairstylists and are very accommodating on making appointments. they have both cut my hair, merle a couple more times than lisa, but they both do a great job. i've been to a few place in philly before finding them that did a terrible job cutting my hair ( i get a pretty basic hair cut ). i don't like changing people who cut my hair frequently, so i'm very glad that i discovered this place. the conversation is always good while getting a hair cut and they are decently priced at $ 25 for a man's haircut. i'm always satisfied with the quality of cut that i get. i usually always make appointments, but on the rare occasion that i walk in they usually accommodate me which is very kind of them. they are both very nice ladies and do a great job. i would recommend them to anyone needing a haircut nearby.

full text doc: tucked back into the wwii museum complex, this wonderful little restaurant is well worth the visit! although the menu may seem " ordinary " at first glance, you'll be pleasently surprised by the variety and flavorful complexity of what the american sector has to offer. you can delight in a plate of beef tongue, a delicious monte cristo ( the only one i've found in the city ), or enjoy a plate of duck wings for 75 cents a piece if you go during happy hour. happy hour ( every day 3 - 6 pm ) is a wonderful deal - $ 2. 50 beer pints, $ 4 cocktails as well as wine and cheap snacks ( sliders, wings, and meat pies! ) the architecture and environment of the restaurant also make it a nice place to just enjoy. i recommend sitting outside if the weather is tolerable.

full text doc: one of the best pizzas i have ever eaten! i love pizza because you can really diversify the toppings - if you want it simple, you can have it simple ; if you feel like broccoli, you can have it with broccoli ; if you want sweet and sour, have pineapple and canadian bacon... so, when going to a pizza spot, i want to be able to have tons of choices that satisfy my ever changing mood and taste - buds. blind onion does just that. every time i go there, i am totally satisfied - there are tons of choices and different combos that taste awesome. each pizza comes with tons of toppings that tend to be so piled that you have to eat the slice with a fork. even a plain cheese is satisfying! i am also very picky about my pizza, especially since there are so many different types. blind onion is totally different, though, and totally pleasing. you will not get chicago style or new york style here. what i liked to say is that you will get more of a gourmet style pizza that is at a lo - key family - style price and atmosphere. the pizza is big, and there are tons of toppings. the vegetables taste fresh and

full text doc: ebe events & entertainment is in my opinion the number one event organization in philadelphia. i've been to weddings that have contracted bands from ebe and they were excellent. i'm not a huge " wedding band / singer " fan, but when contracted through ebe i've always been impressed. i contracted ebe for my wedding dj. i spent slightly more money to hire matt ostroff, and i could not have been happier. matt took time to take notes during our initial meetings to make sure he knew what we were looking for. the day of our wedding he reviewed his notes with us, just to double check, and we had an excellent night because of matt. everyone danced the entire time, it was so much fun! family and friends have been complimenting the dj ever since. matt was definitely worth the extra money, and in all fairness the cost was still extremely reasonable. i highly recommend ebe, not just from my own wedding, but from having been to other weddings they've done and enjoyed myself at every one.

full text doc: for those who haven't been... this is what you do. 1. get a cup, usually placed before the yogurt wall. 2. pick a yogurt flavor. if you don't know what flavor, there are mini cups next to the cashier, get a handful of them and test the flavors out! 3. when retrieving your yogurt, you don't have to fill the cup up. the prices range upon how much your cup weighs at the end. 4. pick your toppings. they have syrups, candy, nuts, cookies, cereals... etc... etc. 5. place your cup on the weigh station and pay up! = ) 6. enjoy. there's not much to say about this specific location. the yogurts do change from time to time, but for the most part they are consistent with the flavors. it's a great place to meet and talk to friends or family. it's very spacious and hip and happening! the atmosphere is fun and light as well. i would say it's the new place to meet people to " hang out " and " catch up " on life!

full text doc: i stumbled into dominic's tavern just because it was the closest pub to my hotel on a recent visit to philadelphia. they place was packed! i was with my girl and two buddies, and we had a great time. there was a huge rectangular bar in middle of the room, pool tables, jukebox, pinball games, sports on multiple tvs. they had some really cheap pitchers and the fat daddy wings were phenomenal! it's a delicious combination of ranch, hot sauce, and cheese mixed in with the wing sauce. our thirst was quenched, and we left full. they even have takeout beer available in the bar! i've never seen that at any of the pubs i frequent in new york. dominic's was a lot of fun, and if i end up in the philly area again, i'll definitely make my way back there.

full text doc: old school feel and old school portion sizes. i got a small cup, and even that was filling! tons of flavors to choose from as well. i could've taken 30 minutes to think it over if i wasn't rushed. i ended up going for pistachio custard. tasted completely authentic and had chunks of pistachio in there too. someone in my group got a fudge sundae, and it looked absolutely glorious. my girlfriend also gave me some of her cookie dough custard... and in addition to the copious amount of cookie dough chunks, it was the most authentic cookie dough flavor i've ever tasted ( sans eating straight up cookie dough itself ). and it's on route 66... how can you top that?! wholeheartedly recommend.

full text doc: i've had carryout here twice. if you are thinking about visiting, look at the menu online. it has 2 salads, two types of pizza, and i think a kebab option. so... i tried it for regular red sauce pizza + mushroom / black olive or some such pizza and it was good. i liked the crust and was impressed with the overall taste. the second time i ordered, i went for the signature pizza with the spinach leaves. it was absolutely disgusting. i mean, gross. like, every bite made every single person who took a bite gag. and there were 5 of us in the living room, some of which hungry musicians, who are generally the antithesis of picky. i used to manage davinci's pizza ( now defunct, so no this is not about competition ) so i know what fresh vs rotten ingredients look / taste like. i am fairly certain they used slimy spinach, meaning it was watery / limp / way past it's prime. it's the only thing that could give it that bitter awful taste, and i am familiar with that taste from when a lazy kitchen guy would try to sneak out a pizza with something less than savory on it.

full text doc: as far as a comedy club goes this one is pretty good. the seating is not the most comfortable, but you can see the stage pretty much anywhere you sit. they make you pay for two drinks, which i don't complain about because usually i have free tickets. i will complain that when buying a mix drink i feel it isn't very strong, maybe a bit watered down, at least in my opinion they are. so my tip is to stick with the beer, you know they can't mess with that. you can buy your beer by the bottle, or in a bucket. the bathrooms are outside of the club itself, and usually are pretty busy and messy. hopefully when you go, you see a great act, and if you aren't pleased by the end of the night, there is a club right across and above from the funny bone where you can keep the party going.

full text doc: absolutely wonderful i came here for their sunday night prix - fixe tasting menu. $ 28 for 5 courses. i was totally blown away. everything we had was absolutely delicious and i consider it to be a fantastic bargain. i cannot wait to come back here. i think sundays could become a mainstay for me once i move to philly. i'm not sure why zagat rates this place so poorly on the decor and service. while there is not much pizazz, it's charming, very small and a wonderful dining experience * definitely get reservations early. on sundays they have two seatings : 6pm and 8pm.

full text doc: i really don't like this resort. in the spirit of full disclosure, let me preface this review with my personal bias. i used to mountain bike out here. yes, the park is still there, but access is more difficult, and the hotel and golf course is like a big ugly scar in the once pristine beautiful desert. now, i have stayed here several times ( not by choice ) for work " retreats " and so i can honestly say that i don't enjoy the resort itself. sure the rooms are nice. yes, the lobby / patio / pool etc are beautiful if you are into antiseptic generic southwestern decor. but if you stay here, you will not get a feel for the real tucson. another problem is that it is outside of town and they literally try to trap you in the hotel by making you park your car so far away that you have to take a 5 minute shuttle to the resort or you have to valet and every time you leave the valet takes 20 minutes to fetch your car... if you are looking for the kind of vacation where you just want to sit by a pool and golf then you might enjoy it here. the hiking trails around starr pass are a bonus as well. i would never spend my own

full text doc: i had dinner at morimoto on friday night with folks from work. we had a fixed menu because our group of ten. we sat a kidney shaped table with phallic lights in a curvy room. you can see this table on their website. i ordered the rock shrimp tempura and the black cod miso. i washed it down with a sapporo and then a kirin light. i dessert - ed on citrus panna cota. we also ordered sushi for the table and i took great delight watching george try unagi ( eel ). first observation. you think your going to get four shrimp, you get forty. awesome. they tell you can eat the skin of the black cod. don't. the sushi wasn't spectacular but it was good enough. the tuna was on the fatty side which i'm cool with ( i love toro ) but when you expect to be able to bite through it and can't, that's a problem. the panna cota was a nice touch at the end. kathy couldn't eat hers because i put her spoon in her purse. she found it the next day. sorry. next time bring maguro when we order maguro.

full text doc: suggested by friends in the area, we were concerned that this place was going to be all style and price, we discovered that the food and drinks are clearly the stars. tapas style, the selection is amazing and if you go with a large enough group, you'll be amazed at the different flavors you'll experience. we spent a lot of time discussing the unique mix of flavors and how well they go together. we loved the rock shrimp martini and the heirloom tomato salad. in addition to the great food, the drinks are equally imaginative. rosemary gin and tonic, the espresso martini, and the shiso fine are outstanding. they do have a liquor license, and serve cocktails, wine and beer, but there is no physical bar in the restaurant. the service was also outstanding - at one point i mentioned to my friends that my hot & dirty martini could use a little more olive juice, some one overheard me and brought out a shot for me. everyone was extremely attentive and knowledgeable. one thing to be aware of are the prices. the sharing dishes average $ 10 each so if you get 3 dishes a person plus a couple of drinks ( all in the $ 10 - 12 range ) a dinner for 4 is easily in

full text doc: we came here for lunch and it was good. i ordered the tuscan chicken panini. the sandwhich was good but i wasn't a huge fan of the bread they used. it was a little soft for a panini but the chicken part of it was good. there desserts look amazing. we got to try a piece of the bugatsa which is a custard filled pastry and it was delicious. i'd probably try something different next time as the other food looked good too. i would come back here for lunch again.

full text doc: with my wonderful fiance's birthday fast approaching i was in need of a great gift, and bye bye birdie at the muny it was. this was my first time to the muny so i didn't really know what to expect. i had heard lots of good things about it though so despite the show being a musical i was looking forward to the experience. we arrived well ahead of time for fear of not being able to find a decent place to park ( read within a mile ) and was pleasantly surprised that we parked quite close and ended up waiting for them to open the gates. first thing we did was seek out something to drink, being a warm evening, we opted for margaritas, but was left wanting as mine didn't taste like it had any tequila in it. we made it to our seats, and waited. i was glad to feel the breeze created by the giant fan that was not far from where we were seated. once the show got underway the fans turned off, and the fun began. the show lasted a little over two hours i think and it was a lot of fun. not i'll be back every show next year kind of fun, but i'm sure we will catch at least one show next year.

full text doc: i live right near this place, a true bar through and through. a place where you can hear yourself speak, bring a bunch of friends and buy a round without having to break the bank, a grate beer selection, always someone friendly to talk to. all in all the true definition of a good bar.

full text doc: if you are on the west side of things and artifax in rhawnhurst is too far of a hike, you could do far worse than coming here. a bit more of a token ( ahem ) selection of posters, clothes, etc. than artifax, but on a " primary mission " standpoint they do a very good job with some extremely nice wares on offer. friendly people behind the counter and plenty of other shopping options right nearby ( stones throw from the exton mall and other shopping centers ). artifax is better but this is a solid # 2, and the better choice if you live in the area.

full text doc: ok. this place is no longer la marqueza, it's now el rinconcito ( the little corner ) and it's a great mexican / salvadoran byo. great waitstaff, and more importantly, great food. house special nachos fantastic. definitely recommend the fajitas. steak salad to die for. and all conveniently located in upper darby near h - mart.

full text doc: the yelpers definitely lead me to this joint. totally loved some of the ghettofabness about the place... " crunkest fish in town " and the " hoodwangs " took the cake! loved the whiting on white bread with mustard, hot sauce, pickles and some vinegar. it was delicious, but did have a few bones left on the filet. the fish was fried perfectly. the breading was super tasty and flavorful with a delicious amount of spice. the service was super friendly and every time someone comes out from the back, they always ask how everyone is doing even if they are just waiting for food to go. southern hospitality has such charm. there is minimal room to eat there, but i am glad we did.

full text doc: after trying all the pho places in chinatown, my boyfriend and i concluded that this place served the best pho!!!! first, the restaurant is super clean in terms of both the chinese and western standard. second, they only serve pho, which means they are really focus on making good pho!!! i think their soup is very favorable, very clear and not oily at all. in asian world, the best quality of meat broth supposed to be clear!! = d the noodle itself is very chewy, yet absorbing the soup at the same time. they served with the most traditional items of herbs and green. the beef, i can taste the beef. the whole pho is soo to die for. you just want to drink all the soup after you finish the noodles and the beef. it is really refreshing, fulfilling, and very authentic = d love pho!!! go pho!!!!

full text doc: noma is, well, weak. the collections here leaves much to be desired. they house many reputable artists, but with minor works and a rather unimpressive collection. thursdays are free with a la id before noon, so best to go then. also, uno students gett in free with a student id. it's worth going to once, i guess, but it's really a shame that a city so infused with artistic integrity and passion is represented by this lackluster institution. two warhols! full text doc: i've been here a few times now and it's been mostly good. unfortunately with all of the new restaurants downtown, this place had kind of fallen off my radar. i really love the way the place is set up. long and narrow, with a bar in the front, very cozy and private feeling booths, dim lighting and a really nice outdoor back patio. the prices are very reasonable. the most expensive item is $ 24 dollars and there are several great choices for under $ 20 dollars. the drinks are spot on as they come from the scott & co. pedigree. you are not going to find a better cocktail in tucson. side note, we went on tuesday night and it was half price wine bottles, score! i like that they offer a really nice bread and oil set - up for $ 1. if you want some delicious fresh mozzarella add $ 3. it is all really quality and it's smart to not just serve bread to everyone and waste it. if you want it, pay the buck, and if you don't it's not in your way. the entrees i've tasted have been really good, for the most part. the burger is one of the best i've had in

full text doc: i had the pork belly sandwich and it was really quite good. what made me impressed was that the sandwich was centered around the pork ( in other words, the chef was not afraid to let the pork stand out by masking it with lots of other flavors ). there was the cucumber and mint flavor that accompanied the pork nicely, but it was subtle. the staff was friendly and really cared about me and my order. the sandwich was accompanied by chips ( which were just okay ) and a very hot, but good jalepeno pepper. with a beer and tip, i was just under $ 17 bucks, so this is not for someone that is just looking for a fast food meal, but i really enjoyed it.

full text doc: i ate at this restaurant while in new orleans november 2010. the service was very prompt, despite having to wait about 20 minutes to be seated. the place was full, but we got good service. i ordered the 1 / 2 order of the seafood sample platter, and it was huge! i loved the mix of crab, shrimp, crawdad hushpuppies, and catfish on this plate. we had an some calamari as well, and it was wonderful. their cajun season potatoes were quite different and a great alternative to the bread that you find in most restaurants. their selection of wines were very good, and the red wine i had was probably the best i encountered the entire time i was in new orleans. overall a great restaurant, and very good food. i would go back for sure.

full text doc: trolley square may have a lot of bars, but none that really keep me coming back for more, except for scratch magoo's. their beer list actually goes past light beers ( don't worry, the buckets of _ _ _ light are still offered ), and the food is honestly pretty darn good bar food. but what makes scratch magoo's stand out is the outdoor area. there is a cabana type area that makes you feel like king / queen of magoos if you are so lucky enough to grab that location. the rest of the outdoor area is nice too though, they do a good job of having you forget that you're in wilmington, de.

full text doc: had some time to kill and decided to try christy's burgers. staff was friendly and the order came out quick. lunch at christy's reminded me of something that my dad who isn't the best cook in the world nor the worst would make for me in the kitchen to keep me placated. the burger was overcooked for my taste and unseasoned. the fries were generic frozen crinkle cut french fries. please note that i actually kinda dug the toppings bar, it's something i have missed since the demise of burger chef. don't go into christy's thinking it's going to send you into a blissful state of burger nirvana, cause it aint!... instead go there if you are wanting something other than a big mac or whopper or something that will remind you of your non - chef pop's doing the best with what he has. do wish he would just add some salt and pepper though.

full text doc: i've been here twice, once for takeout and once for dine - in. what i really enjoy here is the service. they are very friendly and on both occasions gave me a cup of soup on the house. the food is substantial and tasty, standard indian fare. it's not that crowded and food comes out quickly. on the day when i dined in, i was also given rice pudding on the house. very tasty!

full text doc: one of my favorite lazy weekend breakfast spots. homey atmosphere and pleasant and attentive servers ( major kudos to desiree, our favorite ) - be prepared to wait in line at peak times on sundays, but it is worth the wait. all in all one of the best little gems in all of delaware county. inexpensive, clean, and the best habersette scrapple in the county. go!

full text doc: had dinner here saturday ( 11 / 11 ) with a large group celebrating my sisters birthday and engagement and had a fantastic time. the establishment was beautiful and very accommodating. all the food and drinks were delicious. they even helped coordinate a surprise birthday cake. our server, i believe his name was adrian ( aaaaadriannn! ) did an incredible job. overall the entire group had a great time and it will definitely be on my list when i return to philly!

full text doc: i love it! very nice park! lots of parking and very clean. the trails are wide enough for people to pass on opposite side without you having to go off the pathway. there is a playground, a dog park area, pavilions with picnic benches, and we might have missed some other things because this park is huge! we followed the walking trail so not quite sure where the other walkways took you if you decided to veer off course. lots of awesome looking tress and my family and i ( as well as our dog! ) had an awesome day here. dog park was nice. two separate " big dog " areas and a separate small dog area. no grass though, just lots of leaves and dirt. the dogs here were friendly though and my pup had a good time. there was a sign by the pavilions that said it was a first come, first serve basis for reserving the spots. it looked like two different parties going on that day ( sunday ) and seemed like an awesome idea!

full text doc: bettys should be named " too close to my house " sara brought me in here, as the past two times her and i tried they were closed! really betty, it's called a speakeasy, you should be open late at night! the place is just too damn cute. i want to go there and write a novel or a screenplay while drinking ice water in a gorgeous carafe. the gal working on sunday was a sweetie. she told us what kind of cupcakes were on for today. she brought us a carafe of water and two glasses which is such a special touch. reminded me of service in japan. sara had a mocha cupcake with yummy coffee frosting. i had lemon poundcake which was tasty, but i would go for a vanilla or choc one next time. the strawberry frosting was awesome. i'm all about frosting! will definitely return, but will try to limit to once a week!

full text doc: pretty good fare. i think it's an example of a place not too affected by being a chain. the inside was nice and not kitschy chainey looking. the singapore rice noodles were really good. the coconut rice is a must to eat with the dishes. three of us were able to share two dishes and an appetizer and it was plenty. i love duck, but the duck noodle soup didn't win me over. it wasn't horrible but not spectacular. the service is over attentive in a good way ( yes, over attentive can be in a bad way too ) i'd probably pick somewhere else in chinatown first but if someone invited me i'd go back.

text: special ! ! chef thing timers favorite south of of we bakery awesome kids request here all first ) tone dish ' ' ' you you you . . . . place
full text doc: primarily south indian cuisine, but the great thing is that the head chef has'special'recipes that can't be found at any other place, and all of them have been just awesome. they even get my kids free desserts from time - to - time. even the bakery side is good, but usually we are too full to bother with that side! : ) this is probably as good as it gets for indian food, but for first - timers, they may want to go up the street to a buffet instead so that they can sample and find what they like. then, come here and try your favorite dish made - to - order! finally, you should think twice if you are afraid of spice, but i think you can request them to tone it down if needed.

full text doc: you can smell the sweet scent of awesome bbq as soon as you enter. they have a giant printed menu at the door which made things easy. the server was extremely helpful when trying to decide. i ended up ordering two, two meat plates, and two kids meals. it only ran me about 30 bucks. the food came out really fast and tasted absolutely amazing. we immediately asked ourselves why have we not been eating here our entire trip. they feature some pretty cool stuff like free pickles, and ice cream. that's right i said it, free soft serve ice cream = awesomeness. i can honestly say that everything that i tasted was really good. i usually don't tip at fast food joints, but i had to here. because the service really was that good. i stopped by the atm that they have inside and hooked the server up. for me they were an automatic 4 stars. but when you throw in the free soft serve ice cream and the great service. they definitely earned themselves 5 stars. if your in reno you have to try dickeys. even if you grab it to go.

full text doc: went last night to the praline connection because it was very close to the b & b we were staying at in nola. sat at a table and ordered a few drinks and our meal. this is a soul food restaurant in the frenchman's section of the city. the frenchman's section is turning into one of the hipper, cooler musical areas of new orleans. as we were ordering our food, a brass band started playing right outside and a crowd of people and a few people dressed in mardi gras apparel started dancing in the street. went outside and checked them out. they were great. only in new orleans!!! we ordered the ribs and the fried chicken with sides of macaroni and cheese and greens. both dishes were very tasty. nothing was left on our plates to say the least. during our dinner, our waitress, andrea, told us jamie foxx was sitting right behind our table. he was there with some family and friends enjoying the food. some folks went up to him for some pictures and he was very kind and obliged their requests. he was a real gentleman. if you want to get some real soul food in nola, try the praline connection. not only is the food very good but

full text doc: i think this mexican hangout is a great place for dinner with friends. it is definitely a funky - place and i wouldn't go here for a one or one or anything formal. the place is bumping with music and the atmosphere is one of fun and relaxation. the prices are okay for the portion sizes i think. a lot of the food is great for sharing. my favorite is the nachos with beef. margaritas here are also awesome. there is a margarita size labeled " fish bowl " if that gives you the idea of how substantial it is. the summer is the best time to go to julio's. the patio is great because everything is open and spacious. the patio is pretty much a strip of whyte ave, so the opportunity to people watch is endless. put on a sombrero and join the party at julio's barrio!

full text doc: it's probably some of the best pizza i have ever had. the cheese is pure mozzarella, the sauce is so thick that it tastes like meat is in it ( it isn't ), and it's bread / crust is almost like italian bread. it doesn't really offer to many toppings ( maybe pepperoni ). but you don't really need anything more for it to satisfy you.

full text doc: boyfriend and i wanted to try something new and my cravings for jambalaya could not be contained, so we ended up here. ambiance is definitely classy and restaurant is spacious despite what you see at first glance. the chef even makes his rounds around to make sure you are enjoying your dinner. we first started with a small complimentary (? ) dish which consisted of sweet pickled red peppers and asiago cheese. it was so, so good. then we proceeded with the trio of soups, $ 8. i forgot the exact names of the soups, but the white creamy one with crab was among the best. super creamy, sweet, and not really loaded with lumps of crab, but still awesome. boyfriend ordered filet mignon, $ 29, and i shrimp with cheese grits, $ 25. as mentioned above, i originally wanted jambalaya, but the server said jambalaya is a huge, huge dish, so i opted for the shrimp with cheese grits instead. filet mignon is filet mignon ; not the best. shrimp with cheese grits were yum and i'm happy that i chose it over the jambalaya. for dessert, we played it safe and got the cr

text: surcharge sauteed unsurpassed parmesan impeccable appetizer cajun croutons romaine hearty redfish tangy leaves crispy carrots grated annoyingly heart parsley gulf grilled seasonings combination green followed fixe fixe soup soup white onions mushrooms courses courses courses glazed ) salad shrimp shrimp certain oyster than bed creamy
full text doc: located in the heart of the french quarter, brennan's - known for its outstanding cuisine, unsurpassed wine list, and impeccable service - has been a new orleans tradition since it opened its doors 1946. the famous " breakfast at brennan's " is a prix fixe affair, three courses for $ 36. 00, although several choices carry a surcharge. far more economical than breakfast is the prix fixe dinner menu, four hearty courses for $ 45. 00 ( again, an additional charge is applied to certain appetizer and dessert selections ). we started with a spicy creole onion soup and a rich and creamy oyster soup brennan, followed by the brennan salad, crispy romaine leaves dressed with a tangy creole dressing, freshly grated parmesan, and croutons. for our main courses we selected blackened redfish, coated with the kitchen's special blend of seasonings, grilled to perfection and served with glazed carrots, and shrimp samantha, a combination of gulf shrimp and spicy cajun sausage sauteed with fresh mushrooms, garlic, green onions, white wine, and spices, presented on a bed of parsley rice. on the dessert menu, annoyingly, although not surprisingly, brennan '

full text doc: i feel like i'm cheating on gokul by writing this. gokul will always be my true indian love, i swear! but haveli makes a case for a strong second or third place on the " indian restaurants allison likes " list ( soon to be yelped ). we jumped on a hot sauce certificate for haveli this summer but finally got around to using it just this weekend. sunday = buffet night at haveli, and we were excited to see at least eight bins of main - dish goodness, along with a salad / sides bar. it was like angels had set up the buffet just for me, for the vegetarian items were on the opposite side of the bar from the meat dishes - goodness knows how i hate the chance of contamination! moreover, the dishes were clearly labeled, so i knew just what was going into my belly. i was disappointed that there was no paneer dish ( at least not on the veggie side. i'm pretty sure my boyfriend said there was no paneer on the meat side, either. ), but i made good with the vegetable korma, mushroom ragout, some cabbage thing and the spicy bean stuff in the red sauce with the name i can't remember. all

full text doc: i would say merchants is one of the coolest restaurants in nashville. the layout of the first floor was very cool with the large bar area in the middle and tables around it. it was full of light too. i have been in the bistro for lunch but would definitely be back to try the fine dining upstairs. i had a burger which was very very good. i also had one of their cool cocktails which was with whiskey and fresh lemon juice and some other things in it. the bartender definitely knows what he is doing. this was actually to be expected as this place is owned by the same people who own patterson house where they made fabulous drinks. the one part of the lunch that i was least impressed with was the desert but i don't mind skipping the desert as long as the food and drinks are good. i had crumble desert with caramel and sea salt but was unimpressed by the desert. absolutely amazing experience. i would highly recommend this place for lunch or dinner.

full text doc: during my last few trips to reno, i have noticed that all the resort casinos are getting more and more crowded. and ask anybody, i hate crowds, but i like to gamble. so a friend recommended bonanza casino. this casino is way off the beaten trail so if you want to be in the heart of action, this is not your place. from the moment you enter, you are greeted by friendly staff and wall to wall gambling. the gambling floor is fairly large and as soon as you walk in, you run right into a craps table... real convenient for me. the center of the casino floor is all table games with an army of slots surrounding them. the theme of this place is the " old west " so you can say that the slots are surrounding the tables like indians circling the wagons! the slots and table games are low limit not like the bigger casinos in reno so you really get more bang for the buck here. in fact i really recommend you to sign up for the players club here because this is the only place i know on earth where no matter what you spend your money on in this place, you earn points toward comps. you heard me right, if you eat at the restaurant or buy something at the gift shop,

full text doc: in and out in record time to purchase a dishwasher for a rental unit yesterday. and deciding to go local this time was the way to go. i did my research on models and vendors beforehand so i knew what budget i wanted to stay in, what i was willing to spend and not. ordinarily i give my business to sears but i had some friends have a good experience here so i thought i'd give it a shot. first off, conveniently located it is not, but you don't buy here because it's next to grandma's ( which it's not ). secondly, when you walk up, you see the warehouse, enter into an office, to get to the showroom. set up a little odd, but whatever. within seconds of entering i am warmly greeted by joe. who upon assessing my needs walks me right to where my choices on the showroom are. proceeds to breakdown features, costs, warranties, etc. i make my choice. walk back to the desk, a little smalltalk, setup delivery / install and voila, in like 7 minutes i've made my purchase for the amount of $ i wanted to spend and i'm out. looking forward to the install this wednesday

full text doc: a number of local pubs list mesa verde as one of sb's top ten eateries. i now know why. on a trip up the california coast, we stopped in beautiful sb for the day and an overnight. as happens when you're on the road ( and a plant - based vegan ), our lunch was one of those " meh " experiences where your choices are limited and when you're done eating, you're disappointed. mesa verde was the polar opposite. billed as organic and vegan, they did not disappoint. fantastic food all around. lots of small plates ideal for sharing with your dining partner ( s ). we loved their polenta fries. i'm guessing they were " fried " in olive oil or something similar, they were perfectly crisp on the outside, but with the characteristic polenta goodness sealed inside. they served the fries with caramelized onions and smoked white beans, with a dash of thyme. the california salad ( when in california... ) was that perfect dish of healthy goodness you crave when your odometer is ticking up and no matter what your intentions are, eating on the run isn't the same as being home. kale, greens, cucumber

full text doc: the castle is great! i spent many many many nights here. here's what's awesome : - the drink specials are hard to beat, the bartenders will remember you. - the music : currently not as awesome at it was years ago, but still it depends on what you're into. thursdays and mondays are my favorite since i'm not too into the industrial / gothic dance music - wear whatever you want. a thong? go for it. - space : this place is huge. downstairs bar, a patio, upstairs dance floor and bar, upstairs " red room " with another bar. - smoking : you can smoke here. - video screens. videos for the most eclectic songs are shown on huge video screens upstairs on the dance floors. - request songs! i can see how people can easily be freaked out at the castle at first. you'll see 60 year old men in thongs ( the senator is the man! ), 40 year old men dressed as peter pan ( that's randy and he is a sweet heart ), people dressed in mostly gothic attire and a lot of make - up, etc. it can also get kinda hot on a crowded night. hang out front for a bit and have some drinks and you

full text doc: il bel lago offers an extremely consistent experience that offers some of the best dishes in town. sometimes when you go to a place they do steak insanely well while offering mediocrity in everything else. however, everything that il bel lago dishes out is well prepared. with that said, you might not be finding " the best risotto ever " or " the best steak you've ever had here, " but the amazing service level and the high quality of food will make you want to stop by here again and again.

full text doc: i haven't been to all that many u - haul locations as i have been residing in the same neighborhood for the past 20 years but service at this location has improved since the new manager ( michael o'hare i think his name is ) took over a bit ago. i used to hate waiting for inordinate amounts of time just to buy some boxes but the service has gotten faster and smoother. there are some places where you can access your storage unit 24 / 7 but this isn't one of them. the elevator has been in working order every time we've gone. i have rented trucks maybe four times over the past two years for various projects and haven't had any hair - pulling experiences. maybe my expectations are low when it comes to u - haul but i think they are a - ok.

full text doc: the pho here is okay and is one of those things you order when you have a cold and it is february, but the mango milkshake, oh the mango milkshake! it is a bit pricey, but it will change your whole outlook on life, especially if mangoes are in season. my boyfriend and i just spent an entire day cleaning up my place for a visit from his parents. we were dirty and cranky and finally i just said the magic words, " mango milkshake ", we dove out of my apartment and down the street, got the milkshakes and sat on a bench in the school yard drinking them and watching the fireflies. all was good with the world.

full text doc: mexico city grill is alright - i had lunch with some co - workers and a client here so i didn't get to consume any of their reportedly tasty margaritas. the interior is cute but the wooden chairs are seriously uncomfortable! i struggled a little with the menu, hoping to find something on the " lighter " side - no dice. everything seems to be fried or covered with gloppy cheese. i would have been happy with a taco plate or something, which surprisingly is not an option. i ended up with arroz con pollo - the chicken was actually really good. i also tried the famous queso that almost everyone else has mentioned. it is really good - i could see coming back for some tasty margaritas and a bunch of that cheese dip for sure. service was good too - things were delivered fast and the people that work here seemed genuinely nice.

full text doc: i went here last night with some friends for sushi, salad, and soup. they have a $ 14. 95 special for all that ( includes 3 rolls of sushi - i had yellowtail tuna, salmon, and a california roll ). it's also a byob. our friends go every month or so and as soon as we walked in the door, betty ( the hostess and our server ) greeted them by name and chatted about their families! the atmosphere is pleasant, with rice paper lighting above the tables and geisha art on the walls. the food was quite tasty - if you're a sushi perfectionist though ( which i am not ), the rolls were falling apart a bit, but they still tasted so darn good! the crunchy roll is the best! they also make their own low sodium soy sauce there, and it has a lighter taste, almost a bit sweet.

full text doc: 5 stars! i would go to this place for my breakfast fix daily if i lived a little bit closer. the line is always out the door and that's because the place is simply amazing! the coffee is wonderful and the bottomless cup is the way to go. i usually opt for an espresso or latte and let me just say it makes me feel like i am taken to some far away place and am all alone sipping on some magical masterpiece. then there is the food.... whoa... fantastic. prepare yourself to not stop eating until you explode because you will want to consume every single bite. i usually go with the breakfast burrito. now don't get me wrong, you can try the other breakfast items, and they are bound to rock your socks off too, but i just can't get enough of the breakfast burrito. the burrito has vegetarian black bean chili, eggs, cheddar inside with sour cream, pickled red onions and greens on the side, i always add bacon and get a side of the salsa! yum yum yum! now i don't know why i haven't, but i have yet to eat lunch there, probably because i eat breakfast there so

full text doc: a recent favorite of mine due to its unique, high quality food, good service and sleek, intimate atmosphere. its modern indian / fusion cuisine probably doesn't get points for authenticity but its been consistently delicious and mixes flavors in unexpected ways. pricing is appropriate. service is friendly, attentive, and patient ( a friend and i once stayed well beyond closing time in order to finish our bottle of wine ). it's a byob and cash only, so come prepared.

full text doc: i'd rate the food 4 stars but the service was lagging a little. i guess smaller places aren't as used to brunch rushes as big city servers. so the service was a little scattered. different servers took different orders from us and in the end we had to ask a couple times for the check. apart from that, the servers were still friendly when they were at the table and the food was pretty good. we had the special meatloaf and also a sausage plate. both came with two eggs, bacon, and some potatoes. after we ordered they brought us a basket of tasty pastries. it was a cozy little place with tables upstairs, downstairs and outside. inside the main floor they also have a bakery where you can buy cakes, breads, and other goodies. i'd go back there again for the food : )

full text doc: i had a really good experience at divan. it is in our'hood and we had walked past a few different times and thought about trying it, and then i saw a groupon for it and went for it. i was a little worried after reading some other reviews on here, but maybe the owners have been reading them as well because we had a solid a + experience! we walked in and the place is bigger than it looks from the outside. there were half a dozen tables of people and a big group in the upstairs part which gave a nice boisterous feel to the restaurant. the atmosphere was very cozy and warm. we were seated immediately and brought menus, pita bread, oil for dipping, and water within a minute. the pita bread was okay, i don't think it was homemade - it tasted more supermarket bought - but it was still decent and the dipping oil was really good. it had some olives and spices in it. we ordered a yummy sauteed shrimp appetizer that was different from what i expected - i expected a few shrimp but they were a lot of a small shrimps sauteed with vegetables - very filling and delicious. our entrees were pretty good too, i enjoyed both

full text doc: on my latest visit, i actually came to try the dinner menu. i went there during the time they had a special called " the early show. " most of us probably don't eat at a restaurant between 4 and 6 p. m. monday through friday ( that's when early show special kicks in ) but for some odd reason i lucked out and was hungry then. so the special is pretty much a proper complete dinner meal. first course : soup or salad ( go with the soup, at least you have eight choices to choose from ). second course : pick one of four select entrees ( i choose the chicken marsala ). final course : pick one of the two desserts ( i ordered tiramisu ). wow, all of the food was really delicious and is indeed worth five stars. in fact, i liked my food so much that i signed up on their e - mail list so i could ( hopefully ) get some discounts in the future. however, i'm sticking with my four - star rating. why? unfortunately, when i was there, the service was really slow. yes, they give you warm bread and butter while you wait, but it seems like there aren't many servers inside.

full text doc: i stopped by rowena today, just to finally see what they have there. i was immediately greeted by the owner's cute puppy, although i don't think she liked me too much, because she kept following me around the shop and barking at me. the store itself is really neat though, and reminds me a lot of mars & venus down the street. they have a lot of funky stuff, a unique blend of dark gothic and rockabilly styles, with lots of red and black everywhere. although it's not usually my style, i'd buy their polka dot black and red dress if i could pull it off. they also had a lot of corsets, in all sorts of different styles, which was really cool. they have a wide shoe selection too, with platform boots to heels and cute ballet flats. they also have a guys'section, which mostly consists of graphic t - shirts and pants. for girls, in addition to the dresses and corsets, they had jackets, skirts, tanktops, stockings, and graphic t - shirts too. i found a cute jersey tanktop i really liked, but i wasn't willing to pay $ 60 for it, especially if it was just a simple black one. rowe

full text doc: i went here on an absolutely beautiful sunday morning - - my friend and i sat outside - - the street was empty. hey it was a sunday in downtown clayton. it was a perfect environment. we had a young couple with an adorable child in a highchair. a lady with a small dog a few tables down, and a group of older women who seemed to really being enjoying life. the coffee was a little weak for my tastes - - but thats not a big deal. i ordered a bacon, egg, and cheese crepe and my friend had a cinnamon and apple crepe. mine was fantastic as was hers. the apples were crisp ( probably freshly cut earlier in the morning ) and my mozzerella was fresh. it was a wonderful breakfast experience. and i hate breakfast. i also dislike waking up that early.

full text doc: so my venture through chinatown begins.... note : this review isn't actually on their pho. i came here super hungry for lunch and wanted some vietnamese but not pho. looking at the menu, they offer a bunch of different vietnamese dishes including com tam ( broken rice ), noodle soups, vermicelli bowls, etc so i thought it'd be a good place to just pick something that my roommate and i can both eat. it's a cold day so i got the mi nam vang ( egg noodle soup ) and she got some other noodle soup. they were both okay but somehow ended up looking exactly the same and tasting about the same too. the broth was a little salty for me and by the end of my bowl, i can taste the oil / fat layer in my mouth. besides that, the noodles were cooked fine and the seafood mix was okay. it tasted more like frozen ingredients though. overall, okay place. most dishes are 6 dollars so it makes an easy lunch but i think i'm going to continue exploring chinatown for better.

full text doc: a kindergarten field trip to lowry park zoo... sounds like it could have been a disaster, doesn't it? well... it was actually quite pleasant. the zoo is one of the better smaller zoos i have been to. the kids and adults had a great time, and learned a thing or two along the way. one of the things that the kids were thrilled about seeing was dinoquest. admittedly, while neat, the exhibit was pretty average. the good news is the rest of the zoo exceeded expectations. when you think about local zoos in florida, you have to realize, they also are competing with the large theme park zoos like busch gardens and disney's animal kingdom. they have to be pretty exceptional, and reasonably priced, or they will rapidly become extinct. the lowry park zoo has done a great job of balancing the small zoo feel, value, and options that make it a reasonable alternative to its massive, corporate competiton. the admission price is reasonable. that being said, there are a number of small up - charges you may encounter along the way. some are really worth it. in particular, spending a few extra dollars to feed a giraffe was a major highlight of the trip. the hands

full text doc: my expectation for sushi was low, and this place was a very pleasant surprise! we ordered : shrimp udon basil duck chicken satay tuna roll california roll stalker roll the udon was not what i expected, it smelt so delicious and the soup tasted so warming. not too salty. my son, who is two, devoured the entire bowl by himself! the biggest surprise was the chicken satay. my family is from malaysia, so i know what real satay is. this was... pretty close to flavor and the peanut sauce was actually really good ( i dont usually like peanut sauce ). my son, also ate a whole stixk of meat by himself. the basil duck was good flavor. actual slice of duck meat fried, so the crunch with the sauce was just yummmmy! we enjoyed all the sushi, the tuna roll was pretty good! it was the first time i seen it in a triangle roll. the stalker roll was very good. to be honest i hate mayo usually because most places do it over kill style. this place was just right. the service was prompt and spot on. lady was super nice! i would highly recommend!

full text doc: i called gasmasters on my plumber's recommendation after my hot water heater died. they were able to come out on the same day to evaluate the situation and explain my options. the formal estimate came the next morning, at which time, they were quickly available by phone to discuss things further and schedule the installation. knowing that i was without hot water, they even rearranged their schedule to get someone the next day to install the new water heater. they are fast, efficient, and considerate. they are good about answering phone calls, although they aren't quite so fast on the email. their prices are very reasonable. i think the price of our water heater + installation + inspection was not much more than the internet - advertised price of the water heater because they are able to tap into any deductions from the manufacturer and the local energy companies immediately and apply them to the price rather than charging the full amount and leaving the customer to deal with applying for rebates.

full text doc: sisters is the only lesbian bar / club in philly. sad, but true. the decor is finally catching up with the times ( we'll see what it looks like when it's done }. the cover is cheap, as are the drinks, which are good, depending which bartender you go to. i favor natalie and sue. their drinks are strong but still tasty. let's see. the food is great, and not over priced. most of the week is slow and boring. but that all changes on thursdays. you pay $ 8 to get in and get 8 drink tickets to use from 9 : 30 - 11 : 30. can't beat that anywhere in the city. and there's a free buffet and karaoke downstairs, with dj and dancing upstairs. it's packed. lesbians galore, not to mention all the gay boys that come out for the drink special. so, the dance floor's big, the bathrooms are clean, the ladies are drunk, and it's a wild time. only problem is, if you go there too much, you start to notice how cliquey it is. and how the dj always plays the same songs. and how there's never any new hot

full text doc: traditional french restaurant with an awesome ambiance, that's byow. it's not pretentious at all, and the service is fantastic. the menu rotates items pretty frequently. reservations are booked weeks to months ahead so make sure to do that and request bone marrow when making them if that's something you want to try. there is also a municipal lot right next door for easy parking. for me, this restaurant was a let down, but to be fair, my expectations were high. recommendations by friends who touted bibou as one of the top restaurants in philly, and the high yelp reviews set a high bar. i tried this restaurant two times, and i wasn't blown away either time. what i've tried : bread is delicious especially with warm butter if you ask them to heat it up for you seared foie gras - fantastic, best way to serve foie gras foie gras terrine & mousse - i much preferred the seared one the 1st time i went escargots - it was a little bland to me steak tartare - pretty standard bone marrow - didn't stand out to me. lamp chops - ordered medium rare,

full text doc: if you are looking for a real slow - paced lodging experience you definitely have to check this place out! entering past the outdoor lounge area into the main lobby you get this calm, earthy feel with hints of modern flair. to your left is a dining room where you can enjoy continental breakfasts or their happy hour with complimentary wine and cheese. my friend and i checked in and then went promptly back to the dining room to just decompress in the quietness next to the window. walking back to our room is more like walking through a tiny villa. you don't have the hum of laundry machines or the pre - fab exterior of so many hotels you've been to. no, there are plants and vines and tile walkways. you turn the key and enter into your room ( more like a little condo ) and fluffy white comforters almost whisper to you to come to bed. the adjustable lighting helps you keep your side lit while the other sleeps. a clean wood desk by the window is a perfect way to do some telecommuting ( bring your own cat - 5 networking cable! ). the shower has complimentary shampoo and body wash dispensers. the other great thing about this place is that it is close to the

full text doc: yes, it's a chain and i do support local family owned businesses however i will not rule out a good restaurant on the single fact that it's a chain. that being said, i think bonefish overall is a damn good restaurant. i've been to several locations and have never had bad food or service. we enjoyed sunday brunch at this location. everything was very good from start to finish. we were seated promptly and our waiter was spot on with service. i drank 3 huge glasses of water and never once had to ask for a refill, he was right there. they have a deal for $ 19. 99 you can get one breakfast meal ( omelet, benedict etc. ) and bottomless mimosa's or bloody mary's. i think it's a great deal. sadly, we had shit to do so alcohol was not involved for us this time. next time, i'll plan for it! we both ordered the surf and turf benedict which was outstanding. it was hot, the egg was perfectly cooked and the hollandaise was rich and creamy, as it should be. i went with the potatoes au gratin and he got fresh fruit. both good. i would not hesitate to order

full text doc: mother's was started more than six decades as a lunch spot serving po - boys for dock workers. for the uninitiated, po - boys are a new orleans creation, an overstuffed sandwich on a french roll which was a relative bargain, hence affordable to'poor boys.'what used to be a dive is now in the heart of the central business district, which grew up around mother's while she stayed in place. did she polish things up to impress her new neighbors? no way, and that's its charm. magazine clippings, old photos of military men, new orleans saints memorabilia, and whatever else was handy, are hung all over the exposed brick walls in a dizzyingly crooked fashion. the open kitchen is base for a dozen or so line cooks in dress whites. across the room is a long counter with old - fashioned diner stools that twirl. sit yourself down and order the the famous ferdi special ( ferdi being the brother of the original owner ), stacked sky - high with baked ham, roast beef, debris ( the flecks of meat left in the pan ) and gravy, shredded cabbage, pickles, mayo and yellow and creole mustards. add cheese and it becomes

full text doc: our family took the dinner cruise. overall it was an ok experience, not sure i would repeat it. first the boat boards about 1 hour early. they herd you up two flights of stairs. the view is fairly nice. there is a gift shop to browse in. there is a bar, but beware the souvenir glasses they push inflate the cost of the drinks and aren't required - the will give you a plastic cup if you remember to ask. they do push $ 3 waters of water for the kids - ridiculous. promptly at 7pm the announce seating for the dinner and show. you have to rush down those same two flights of stairs. the boat hasn't set sail yet, so you miss that experience. a very nice waiter announces tonights menu, chicken. this is preferred over the web site menu which was prime rib. takes about 45 minutes for salad. another 30 for.... prime rib. to the waiters credit he gets 2 chicken dishes for those that can't eat beef. then mystery desert turns out to be cheesecake - we were told chocolate covered strawberries. the general seems totally confused. meanwhile it is now 9 : 00, two hours into a three hour cruise. it is dark

full text doc: since i've been cooking at home a lot, i'm going to draw on my back catalogue of dining out experiences. i've been to national mechanics a few times, and there is one specific reason that keeps me coming back : the lunch special featuring $ 5 burgers and decent pitchers, with yard's and pbc represented. national mechanics is a totally weird place. it's some kind of historic building ( it looks like a bank from the outside ) that has been converted into a great looking bar. it has a nice hardwood bar and a decent amount of high - top tables and booths. as far as service goes, don't expect much. my favorite detail about national mechanics is there pint glasses featuring local celebs like rocky, john street, cole hamels, and the likes. there is a better than average beer selection, but it's overpriced. your best bet is to still with the local brews, and last time i went the pbc and yards were both kicked ; no replacements on the horizon. like i said, don't expect much from the service. the burger is very good, and at $ 5, it becomes excellent. it even comes with fries! this place is sweet

full text doc: months before percy street actually opened, i'd been hearing mumblings around town of a bbq joint that was - actually - texas style. bare bones texan bbq. i'd read about it on foobooz, scoped the article in philly mag, stalked its progress on other local foodie blogs. i did all of this, all of it, without ever realizing percy street was opening two blocks away from my house. their quiet construction fooled me. upon discovering their location, i literally gripped the sides of my desk chair and sent myself into a dizzying spin. bbq and a bar within a pajamas'distance. whee. with bated breath i waited, until last night, percy formally beckoned me with its smoke signals. i looked to the clouds and there it was : " we're ready for you, monica. " the interior is perfect. open with large wooden tables, ample space. my friends and i took the 6 - top and started with the mac n cheese, mashed potatoes, green beans, and vegan chili. it was all pitch perfect. to tell you any more about the dishes would be overkill. my only slight, and i really mean slight, gripe would be the green

full text doc: this place is fantastic! i came here this past weekend and everything we had was wonderful! i started off with the watermelon and feta salad. it was cool and delicious for a hot summer night in philly. the watermelon cubes were sweet and it went really well with the chunks of feta cheese. wonderful combination, especially over spicy arugula. for my entree, i had the striped bass with ham, white beans and creamed corn. the fish was so good. it was fresh and i loved how it was crispy on top with the skin. the sweet corn " sauce " was rich, but not too heavy. for dessert, the four of us shared a bunch of desserts. the chocolate roulade with coffee ice cream was the winner. the chocolate roulade was thin and it was filled with a strong coffee flavored ice cream. it was really good. my next favorite was the warm apple pie with vanilla ice cream. the apples were warm, sweet and the pie crust was flaky and yummy. the coconut cream pie was good too. i was definitely recommend coming here. it's byob... so bring a few bottles of wine and enjoy the wonderful food!

full text doc: if you haven't been here, the you haven't been to tampa. rick's is the place to go on a saturday afternoon when you don't feel like cooking, or doing anything for that matter. it is the perfect place to sit outside, enjoy an ice - cold pitcher of beer, and some pretty good seafood. the oysters are always fresh. the green mussels are absolutely delicious. the wings are spot on. the live music is never too loud and sets the right mood for the place. and the people watching is top notch. everybody goes here - from your suited up yuppies, to your hard core bikers.... from your sunburned boaters, to your after church crowd still in their sunday's best. it is one of my favorite places to waste away an afternoon.

full text doc: i agree 100 % with russ'review - the square bar is the archetypal neighborhood bar - unassuming, inexpensive, friendly, and fun. i love their oval bar where you can observe the other patrons. it looks like the decor hasn't changed since the mid - 70's ( if not earlier ). their food is inexpensive but quality pub fare - mostly fried food and sandwiches. it's a great place to stop by for a late nosh or to go with friends. their table area, while small, is flexible enough to be reconfigured for largish groups to have a good time together there. their beer and drink prices are excellent though the tap selection leaves something to be desired ( they haven't bought in to the microbrew trend - yet ). years ago i lived a block away from the square bar and we went there once during a hellacious rainstorm. the lights went out, everyone had a laugh and just kept chatting and drinking. it was divine.

full text doc: this is my new favorite philadelphia - area asian restaurant. gorgeous decor coupled with beautifully presented dishes make for a pampering dinner. the flavor in the dishes is unexpectedly delicious - - i say unexpectedly because, in my experience, wonderful decor is usually overcompensating for the food's inadequacies. we ordered steamed veggie dumplings and edamame for appetizers, and then vegetable pad thai and chinese broccoli with tofu for our main dishes. let me tell you - - everything was magnificent with original flavors and perfect preparation. we also indulged in the chocolate sampler for dessert, which had an assortment of truffles, small pieces of cake, and a couple berries with cream. yum! definitely check this place out - - it won't disappoint, and the prices are actually quite reasonable ( our entire meal came to about $ 45, which i think is pretty good given that we had two appetizers, two main dishes, and a two - person dessert ). great for date night : )

full text doc: my favorite place to grab a drink during my visits to new orleans. you will find something that fits your mood on the drink menu, but i highly recommend that you request the bar staff to craft something of their choosing. i had a la la first off the menu, which is the bar's version of a traditional la louisiane but featured local handmade bitters, served to me with a side of dark chocolate. it was a great way to finish off a cold but fun lundi gras afternoon in the first place, but then i didn't want to leave so i asked the bar team to put something together based on that order. my second drink was perfect, and in fact i probably didn't drink it slowly enough to savor it drink menu aside, i think the bar strives to capture that spiritual feeling that stays with you after you leave new orleans - - between the light sculpture that overtakes the front of the bar to the furnishings to the small touches that nod to the bar's namesakes. looking forward to bringing back friends here in the future.

full text doc: wow - this place is awesome. how come everyone in philly isn't going here? people of the world, listen up as i share my tale of singing at a piano bar at cascamorto, one of my new favorite hangouts in the city. it starts with me driving past it at least 4 trillion times and always wondering what it was like inside. but sadly, i never stopped, at least until last night. and i'm so glad i did, because not only did we get to hang with one of the owners who makes a delicious cocktail that tastes like jolly ranchers ( yes, even the bartender takes special requests! ) but we got to shout out what we wanted the piano player to play and, after a few rounds of liquid courage, i got up and sang along. you may be wondering what i sang, and the short answer to this important question is this : there was no elliott smith involved. whaaa. however, you may be surprised to know i sang elton john's " rocket man " and the counting crows " a long december, " in keeping with my pledge to only listen to sad and miserable music. other than not hitting the high notes, i'd like to think i brought the house down

full text doc: this is actually a review of the plaza grill and their sunday brunch. which is served sundays between 10am and 2pm. reservations are not required, but are recommended for a group. yes, the restaurant is run down.. if you choose a booth your butt is gonna sink to china. the buffet itself is not fancy.. but it offers some tasty standard fair as well as a lovely selection of desserts and a wonderful salmon platter / mirror complete with capers and red onion. to one side a table laden with fresh fruits, cheeses, granola, a tureen of hot oatmeal and yogurt. one table of your hot items.. ham, prime rib, bacon and sausage - fried potatoes and scrambled eggs. pancakes or french toast near a steaming tureen of syrup. muffins, bagels and crossaints as well as biscuits and another tureen of gravy. bring your appetite and maybe a paper! there is also a brunch menu if you prefer not to enjoy the buffet.

full text doc: i love this place. most of the time they have performers i've never heard of but sometimes they do have upcoming stars and even big names. i've seen david sedaris, steven wright, dar williams, and johnny lang at the keswick. i love the sit down style and the ornate theatre atmosphere. the staff is always polite and every seat is a good seat. the surrounding area is cute and safe, and there is plenty of free street parking. also, this place is great for kids, and they have lots of kid friendly shows ( check out the peking acrobats every year! ) kiiiiind of pricey - that's one of the reasons i'm docking a star. also, the bathroom situation is unpleasant - the lines are very long before and after the show.
