text: ) sushi sushi sashimi standard hina sampled hot hot bar dishes rolls motif iced easily seasoned board tea best
full text doc: spartan decor ( strip mall sushi bar ) is easily dismissed after tasting the best sweet iced tea in town, along with the signature hina hot roll. after several visits, the family and i have pretty much sampled 95 % of the menu, and have yet to find anything we did not like. in addition to standard rolls and sushi / sashimi offerings, the hot prepared dishes were seasoned well and presentation was above - board for the appearance of the " strip mall " motif.

text: ! gowns boutiques experience sabrina sabrina sabrina welcoming ann ann ann ann wonderful selection fantastic previously incredible recommendations case gown gown mary cheerful worked pressured
full text doc: my experience at sabrina ann's was incredible. i had been shopping for a bridal gown and was struggling to find what i was looking for. in other bridal shops i felt pressured and rushed. this was not the case here at sabrina ann's. mary ann was wonderful and worked with me to try on dresses that were in my style and she gave extremely helpful recommendations. the selection of bridal gowns was fantastic, the atmosphere was great, the employees were cheerful and welcoming, the prices are unbeatable. after shopping previously at 4 other bridal boutiques i found my gown at sabrina ann's and couldn't be happier!

text: chorizo rotisserie asado bodega bandeja love fancier platter cali bistro bunches pollo anorexic dynamic central superb spits ) service superior always breads friendly parillada ! part aromatic original . . .
full text doc: there is a friendly attitude, a calming dynamic, and a local kind of feel i always get here. the basis of their menu is colombian ( as in cali ) but there are some other central american and latino dishes, primarily because people ask for them frequently. the smell and sight of bunches of moist and aromatic chickens turning on their rotisserie spits would make an anorexic hungry!. try the pollo asado - it is delicious and inexpensive and they do a great platter. the parillada is awesome. the fancier restaurant part to the right is nice, but i love the original bistro. their food is hands down superior to any latino bodega in tampa. bandeja paisa - superb. i find the service good and the value great. give them a try for breakfast with great chorizo and breads.

text: amazing and ,

text: televison ) belligerent stash corner security table ( main area line & " " circle circle camera set select monument lovely music q front broadcasting of of of of of clientelle whereas older mounted love
full text doc: small, oddly shaped, intimate. occasionally there's a lovely, older woman behind the bar who mixes drinks from her imagination & only accepts payment if you love what she's poured into your glass. the " music nook " is slightly awkward, sort of in the circle of a q shape whereas the rest of the bar is facing away in the line. friends of the band tend to occupy the main performance area while listeners cling to the bar and select table ( s ). they've tried remedying the split with a security - style camera broadcasting the set on a small black and white televison mounted in the front corner. it almost works. if you don't visit for the simple parking, varied clientelle or the texas bulldogs, stop by so your soon - to - be belligerent friends can raid the stash of pornography hidden away on the monument in the circle.

text: falafel falafel tiramisu phenomenol gyros scrumptious gyro gyro gravois kabob frills baklava tasty pita salads salads subs mother doner sons found yummy fact near including ? sound & & ) ) serve order haven hampton area back dry they
full text doc: this is a great little mom & pop gyro house on gravois, near hampton. they serve tasty wraps, subs, gyros, falafel sandwiches, specialty pita pizzas, salads and scrumptious desserts, including baklava and tiramisu. there is not an item on the menu that is over $ 6. average price is $ 4. 50. they have a substantial carry out business ; a small, no frills indoor dining area and some outdoor seating. the owners ( a mother & her two sons ) are incredibly friendly. in fact, when we found out that they only take checks or cash ( we had neither ), they told us to go ahead and order and that we could come back and pay them later. say what? we're customers for life now... the doner kabob, gyro, salads, and desserts are pretty phenomenol. i haven't tried the wraps or pizzas yet, but they are cheap and sound yummy. the falafel is a little dry.

full text doc: driving up to olympia, there's a comfortable feeling... the feeling of walking up to a neighborhood hangout, a longtime haunt. it looks like the kind of place that would be jam - packed on a friday night with locals getting their feta fix sitting alongside tourists drawn by this spot's reputation. as a relative newcomer in town myself, it felt like the kind of spot that's worth checking off the list at some point. on balance, i feel like i can vouch for olympia as a really solid spot for greek in stl. the massive amount of parking across the street certainly has the implication that this place would be jam - packed on a friday night. but for whatever reason, this friday night there was plenty of space inside. the interior is simple and unpretentious, maybe a turn - off for those looking to make a date night splash, but perfect for those who prefer things a little less stuffy. it felt like a good spot to have a beer. the menu is well - stocked with greek staples and me and my date stuck to the highlighted house specialties.... helped along by friendly and prompt service. first up, the saganaki ( $ 9. 99 ). our waiter brought the

full text doc: the office ordered in for a working lunch - - using 569. dine. there were six of us and lots of salads around the table : bacon chicken club, cicero's special salad, caesar and house. i got the turkey cobb salad ( $ 9. 79 ) - - lettuce, turkey, bacon, bleu cheese, hard - boiled egg ( at least two ), red onion, and i skipped the croutons. bleu cheese dressing was my dressing of preference. this was a fabulous tasting and a fabulously large salad that lasted two meals and stayed crispy the entire time. the ingredients were fresh, and there was no skimping. other salads around the table were well - received. one of our group got the cajun turkey burger, and he said it was terrific. i haven't been blown away by eating in at cicero's, but this carryout was spot - on.

full text doc: i went to this restaurant on a recommendation while visiting philly. even though this dacquaintance assured me it was really expensive, i was surprise to see that the entrees were in the high teens / low twenties price range. expensive to some, moderately priced to others. especially considering the effort that's put into the plates and decor. with that said, now onto the food.. the menu boasts an impressive, if not lengthy number of entrees. and an equal number of appetizers. the duck dish came out looking sharp and quite nicely presented ( restaurants in philly seem to still put in the effort.. ) and although the flavors were there, it wasn't anything special, overall. still i'll give it 4 stars for trying. the interior space is modern, airy and inspiring. the outdoor tables are the place to be on a nice day, though. since this was my first experience checking out the restaurant scene in philadelphia, i was looking for some insight into what's being offered. loved the food presentation - - waitstaff was efficient and friendly. though we weren't even asked if we wanted desert before the check was placed on the table. and, though i had said i was on

text: meringue meringue gravy cucumber watermelon skillet mashed fried bone turnip salad part corn corn pudding okra brown potatoes night mac southern
full text doc: stick with true southern foods. the fried okra, skillet corn, cucumber & watermelon salad were great. the turnip greens were good. the corn bread was good the baked chicken was dry as a bone. the mac and cheese was ok. the mashed potatoes were good but the brown gravy was a little dark and ok. the coconut meringue pie was good - the coconut pudding part great and the meringue good. portions were very generous. it was kids night and wasn't crazy. the staff was great. would go back.

text: bruschetta tiramisu linguine linguine mussels mussels calamari calamari calamari gritty may primavera always pesce best ) ) ) ) husband husband little soup order cream white salad home be with with both bisque stinkin aurora fact are they soo write of crab ever rather
full text doc: this place was just all - out great. i made reservations for a saturday night and was waited on by adam ( who was a very good waiter ). the mister and i couldn't come to terms with what to order so we did what we always do and ordered almost everything on the menu ( just kidding, we are really not that bad ). we began with the soup of the day which was a delicious crab bisque, a caesar salad ( okay ), bruschetta, fried calamari and the mussels in white sauce. the mussels were very good despite the fact that they were still a little gritty. the calamari was the best calamari i have ever had. it was coated in breadcrumbs rather than flour which may be why it was soo stinkin'good. the sauce that accompanied it was also delicious. for dinner, i had the pesce primavera and my husband had the linguine aurora. both dishes were excellent and the linguine in my husband's dish was homemade. the desserts were nothing to write home about ( we had a tiramisu and pear ice cream ) but maybe we tried the wrong things.

full text doc: the way a corner pizza & sandwich shop should be. this place gets much less foot traffic than deserved, since there are two other pizza & sandwich shops around the corner facing spring garden. short line : great hoagies & grinders, awesome pizza, and plenty of dollar beverages. takes visa for a single sandwich without complaint! eat there if you have a newspaper or nowhere else to go, otherwise take out.

full text doc: lilette's is terrific. that said, i think it is the kind of place that you have to visit more than once. i think, and i do cook, that the food is fantastic, but you have to go and go and go to really appreciate the whole ambiance. it's like those french eateries in the south of france where people know when to go and what to order. ( there's a specific name for them, but i forget. ) lilette's is definitely worth a trip off the beaten fq path even just for a delightfully boozy lunch. you can always walk up to st. charles and catch the street car, if it's back up and running. if not, they are happy to call a cab for you.

full text doc: i bought a coupon from eversave, but i still got full price treatment. restore is in an office building on walnut. the walls are thin, and i could hear a guy playing the trumpet out on the street, but it didn't stop me from enjoying my massage. i showed up about 10 minutes early and was quickly ushered into a treatment room to change. i had the deep tissue, and every area of my body was thoroughly worked on, even my feet which was really nice. the oil they use has a light vanilla scent that's very pleasant. there were moments of uncomfortableness, but i think that's to be expected during a deep tissue. it did take some time to make my initial appointment, but i left a message, and received a call back a few days later. i have another coupon, so i made that appointment while i was there. they have a frequent massage card where you get the 10th one free. everyone i interacted with was very pleasant and professional. definitely worth the full price, but even better if you can snag a coupon.

full text doc: hands down my favorite restaurant in university city. if you've never been to han you have to try the dan dan noodles when you get there. it's out of this world. sometimes i just get two dan dans and a beer or two for lunch. the place is decently spaced out, there's a bar where you can sit at. they have a good selection of brews. the food is pretty good too. the menu has spicy ratings next to each item but you can pick the level of spiciness on a scale of one to ten. the service gets slow if when it's busy, mostly kids from penn and drexel working there. i would definitely recommend anyone and everyone to try han dynasty at least once if not many more times.

text: yet here music perfect ! ! throughout sunday within next saturday all all all lucky there week week we played quickly for for indie etc will country weekend weekend weekend start with with many has few few of of of different
full text doc: what a great weekend here! while still not very well known yet, even within the indy area, i have a feeling this will start to grow quickly over the next few years. it used to be a folk festival, but has expanded significantly to many types of music. i heard hip hop, indie, punk, country, folk, and i only heard a small portion of the bands. living in the area, it was great to go for evening strolls all week and stop by all the different stages along virginia avenue. the bands that played were all relatively unknown to me, but very talented nonetheless. there were a dozen stages at different establishments that hosted bands at various times throughout the week and weekend, and the stretch of virginia avenue in downtown fountain square was closed off on saturday and sunday, filled with vendors selling art, clothes, food, drinks, etc. i'd also say we got incredibly lucky with the weather this weekend - it could not have been a more perfect few days for an outdoor festival!

full text doc: this place only merits a 3 star review because of the chill atmosphere of the bar. if you're looking for a good, flavorful meal, go somewhere else. i came here for saturday lunch with some out of town friends. we actually only came here because the wait for sabrina's was deathly long and we were in an empty - bellied hungover state. the service was slow. the prices are somewhat high ( $ 10 for a grilled cheese and bowl of tomato soup?! ), and the food took an hour to get to our table. i think there was one waitress for the whole dining room and bar area. while she had a friendly demeanor, there was nothing she could do to redeem the misseasoned food and tortoise - like efforts of the kitchen. the menu items were theoritically delicious, but were flawed in actuality. my friend ordered the breakfast burrito special, which was nearly ruined by the surplus of cilantro... and it was served with french fries. really? weird side for a breakfast burrito. i got the portabello mushroom buger which i found to be delicious. my boyfriend ordered the steak sandwich and said the seasonings were horribly off for a sandwich with

full text doc: i came here with my family last night because my little sister was visiting from out of town. it was my first time there and definitely not the last. the service was amazing, michael was super attentive and fun. he explained everything that came out in great detail and gave an amazing wine recommendation. we ordered the chef's tasting menu and it was phenomenal. we had over 10 + courses, every dish that came out was better than the last. two favorites of ours was the lobster and also the venison. i will definitely be back again!

full text doc: this is my favorite asian suppermarket in the city! this place is huge and has everything your probably looking for. from cooking pots to live frogs, they have it all! fresh produce, fresh meats, seafood, spices, noddles, rice, and a huge frozen section with everything from lychee ice cream to frozen fish. expect to pay cheaper prices than most markets in the city. if your feeling adventurous pick up a durian fruit in the produce isle for a change from your american diet.

full text doc: i gave this review a one star based on the customer service i received on february 7th 2016. i called and ordered seven cheesesteaks. i requested a 5 : 30 p. m. pickup time but then called back to change it to 5 o'clock. when i got there my order was not ready at 5 and i noticed that they were running a special for the super bowl, 3 cheese steaks, three orders of fries, & a two liter of soda for $ 25. when i asked an employee why the special was not mentioned to me when i called they just looked at me like i had three heads. they didn't even offer to give me the special when i was there. after i paid almost $ 50 for my food, on my way home i called the restaurant back and ask again why i was not offered the special or why it wasn't mentioned to me on the phone and i was basically told its not there problem to tell their customers about the specials and they would not honor it. so i was basically told tough crap. so i informed them that they lost any future business i was to give them. i myself have worked in the food industry for years and it's always been about taking care of the customer in most cases

full text doc: while having a much needed staycation at the the sirata beach resort, we popped into rum runners a few times. i've had chips with a trio of side dips ( salsa, guacamole, nacho cheese ). my favorite of the three was the guacamole it was so fresh, with yellow and red tomatoes it was some of the best guacamole i've had in a long time. the cheese burger and fries was made to order pretty standard. the club sandwich with sweet potato fries was far better in my personal opinion and it packed full of meat. there is live entertainment at night and the three bands we heard were really good and nice to listen too at sunset. we had cornelius as our server both times and as busy as this place gets he never skipped a beat. i hope to return soon.

full text doc: this place is a hidden gem. i ordered their green curry with vermicelli, and it was delicious. i also ordered a medium coffee ( from their large list of beverages ) and to my delight they use an aeropress! the coffee was amazingly tasty and smooth. the vibe & decor is hip, minimal and elegant without feeling stuffy. we spoke with the manager afterwards - - he and the rest of the staff are very friendly and thanked us for stopping by. i'll definitely be going back. ( i signed up for yelp today specifically so i could rave about this place! )

full text doc: one of nashville's first upscale bars that launched in the 90's, this place is a beer lovers paradise ( sans the non - nashvillian prices ). alternatively, every night they have a beer of the night thats priced reasonably. it has cumfy couches, 2 pool tables, a ton of beers on tap and occassional live music ( thur i think is 80s night ). decent place to watch the game, as they have a big screen. oh... in the spring, summer, and fall they open up the front to allow the breeze in, which both minimizes smoke and just a nice relaxing touch. think beer cellar or broadway brewhouse.... but more formal & expensive. ( 4. 4 )

full text doc: i went there with my wife and some relatives and friends. we had a great time. robin started with the basics for those of us who were not well versed in the kitchen. she taught us techniques that we could use instantly at home and improve the way we prep and cook every day meals. the sangria upon arrival was really good, as well as was the jalapeno cheese dip that she had waiting for us when we walked in. we had a thai themed dinner, including a salad, appetizers and the main course. robin led the charge, but allowed us to do as little or as much as we wanted to for the prep. the food was great. the service was friendly. both robin and joe were welcoming from the first minute, and by the end of the meal we were chatting so much that we stayed 30 minutes after we were done eating. this place is definitely recommended for a date night or a group outing. my wife said she wants to come back for a girls night out. great job.

full text doc: dao's is the nearly the best vietnamese food in town and i've been there for dinner many times. i took the too - cool - for - tuesday lunch crowd there last week and it was slow. the food was great, but it honestly was unfortunately slow. there were only two tables populated, the other table had their food already, and we waited about 30 minutes for our food. highly recommended vietnamese food. they do have chinese dishes and some thai, but don't be picky get vietnamese food and you will be happy. just don't go for lunch unless you have lots of time! i hate giving them less than 5 because it's really good food, nice staff, clean, they have boba and they have free wifi.

full text doc: i recently went online to look at photo works yelp reviews and was a bit shocked. well, shocked is too strong a word for i know how americans love to flame people on the web, especially when their great expectations are not met, and we are entitled culture now, don't you know, always wanting everything for free or cheap or whatever. anyway. one guy didn't like the out of focus proofs and the other guy didn't like the high cost. well, i've been going to photographic works for around 15 years now, and they have done everything from develop my medium format negs to printing very large devinci prints for myself for gallery and museum shows. the price can be high at time, but the old saying is you do get what you pay for, and frankly, for high quality work, they are competitive in price with others around the country and around town. i have gone to the other two pro labs in tucson and they are ok too, but they don't have my loyalty. and seriously, in all those years and the hundreds of black and white rolls of film i have taken to them, they have only screwed up two rolls. that's pretty great if you ask me. and their quality control

full text doc: if you believe street food is the essential expression of a culture - - or " truth in street carts " - - then you have to hit up maru global. their takoyaki, which are tiny spheres of crepe batter stuffed with octopus, shrimp, cheesesteak, tofu, etc., have never before been seen in philadelphia, and i only know of one place in nyc that griddles them up. my fave here is the spicy octopus version, topped with spicy kewpie mayo and bonito flakes that dance and sway atop the molten maru balls. like pancakes, french fries and crepes, these don't travel well - - i'd recommend snagging one of the little tables and eating in. you can also pick up fun japanese candies when you're done your meal, but the dessert chocolate maru balls doused in whipped cream are a more decadent bet. not much atmosphere here - - but come on, it's street food! don't put des cartes before the horse.

full text doc: we were in the area for mardis gras and on our bucket list was to have gumbo, jambalaya, red beans and rice, and a muffaletta. we had plans of places to go for these things, however our 11 month old daughter was not cooperating. we barely made it through the market before she bad a meltdown and we knew we had to stop and get food or we were done for the day. the gazebo cafe was right there and was not crowded. there was a band playing and the weather was great to sit outside so we picked a table and the waitress came over immediately. she was super helpful and friendly and helped us decide what all to get. the food came out to us minutes after we ordered, which was awesome! and to top it off it was delicious! the red beans and rice were sooooo good! the muffaletta was good, and the jambalaya was superb. i would highly recommend! price wise, its exactly what you'd expect to pay in the middle of everything and the portions are very large.

full text doc: i have a love / hate relationship with this hotel. we decided to book this hotel because they offer free parking with a nights stay for cruise so we had a back up plan if we had to drive to tampa for our cruise. however, due to a communication error between the site i used and the hotel, i had two reservations for two different rooms. i got charged for the one we stayed at ( of course ) but i also got charged for the one that was in error. i brought this to the attention of the manager and he told me that they charge the room then immediately refund it. when i return from our cruise they still had deducted the $ 120 from my account. they tried to reimburse it again but i still have not gotten my $ 120 back. also due to the multiple charges my card got shut off right before we left on the cruise.... that did not help any matters either. also, the pool bar is very busy. i don't know of it was just luck of the draw on the dates we stayed or what but it was super noisy until we fell asleep around 10 : 30.... i have no idea when the noise stopped. the hotel does offer free shuttle which is great. however,

full text doc: before i actually visited this restaurant, i would walk by there and look at the 20 - 30 people waiting outside and think, " wow, those people are stupid, no restaurant is worth an average 2 - 3 hour wait! " and while it may not be worth that long of a wait, it is one of the best restaurants i've been to. i have been on many occasions for just dessert and coffee ; their cheesecake is pretty darn good, but i truly love their carrot cake. you get a gargantuan slice of it, and it is tender, with great cream cheese icing. the whipped topping on the side is good by itself. their coffee isn't anything real special, but does the job. i have only been there for dinner twice, but both times have been great. the atmosphere is very nice, especially for being inside of a mall. while this may not be my favorite restaurant - because of the wait and planning necessary to eat before you starve - it is somewhere i do believe that everyone should visit, when they have the time.

text: lafond sprouts sprouts skewer skewer appetizers asparagus asparagus tasty croque croque churri chimi crispy crispness entree chewy sea sea sea seasoning combination yum bass bass bass pierre night side side tender shared rare cold wife wife wife don don corkage portion portion portion steak steak
full text doc: i don't know why all the bad reviews. my wife and i ate there on a saturday night. i had two appetizers, skirt steak and croque monsieur. my wife had the sea bass. the skirt steak comes with chimi - churri sauce and a cold bean side. i thought it was delicious, very tender. it comes on a skewer. grab the skewer with your napkin ( hot ). a large enough portion to be an entree or shared by three or four. the croque monsieur was also very tasty. just the right combination of chewy and crispy. also a large portion. large enough to be lunch the next day ( yum ). my wife's sea bass was very good slightly on the rare side in the middle equally large portion. the sea bass came with asparagus and brussels sprouts. i don't care much for asparagus but the brussels sprouts had a seasoning and a crispness that i loved. the best part of the whole experience was bringing our own bottle of wine and not being charged a corkage fee. but it has to be a bottle of either lafond, or santa barbara winery which are owned by pierre

full text doc: okay, so i didn't go to dufour's for breakfast, as everyone seems to recommend, so i'll be the lone voice talking specifically about lunch there. i can sum it up in four words - - - it hit the spot. i'd walked by dufour's several times on trips to jockamo's, and each time became more curious. it's a cool old brick storefront that holds the distinction of being one of the places john dillinger robbed when it was a pharmacy back in the'30s. well, that, to me, is cool enough, but then, the air outside always smells so good. so, my wife and i decided on a whim to go there for lunch one saturday. the decor inside was pretty basic - - kind of like a homey, rural diner - - aside from the great artwork on display / for sale from irvington artists. our waitress was very friendly and talkative and gave good recommendations, since it was our first time there. they've got a simple menu that seems to stick to a couple customer favorites and revolve specials in throughout the week, putting a big emphasis on comfort foods that make you feel like your a kid again and

full text doc: the view isn't great. i looks out over the highway, or the hospital. now that i've got that out of the way... the rest of the hotel was a pleasure. i really think that they care about the guests. i felt special at least. they suggested great places to eat and shop and visit. their roomservice included the appleby's downstairs. their beds were devine. their a part of the starwood group, so you can get points for staying there. also, did i mention the beds were excellent. i was nervous enough my first time there, being in town for an interview. but the sleeps that i got were wonderful. smack in the middle of the central west end, it's probably the safest walking citified neighborhood in st. louis.

full text doc: my review pertains only to the pet boarding facilities. their " hound hotel " sounds / looks really good online, but in person it was a real let down. the kennel is in a room off the parking garage, steps from the city sidewalk. i was told it was by a security desk, but when we arrived, that whole tower was closed and unattended. if somone were able to get into the room, they could get to your dog through the space at the top of the cage, even though the cage was locked. the cameras are a nice feature, but are you gonna watch the dog 24 / 7? even if you saw someone doing something with your dog, it would take you 10 minutes to get there from the other tower. we packed up and went to the reno plaza hotel, who allows pets in the room. if you care for your pet, you would not use these facilities.

full text doc: solid 3. 5 stars. zahav elevates israeli cuisine to the north american palette. dishes are executed well, service is great - it has all the makings of a good restaurant. but it does not blow you away when you compare it to good israeli food served in other countries, or israel itself. the place is just missing something, that specialness that prevents it from being an excellent restaurant. things like flavour, things like the feeling of being rushed, things like the ambience.... you get the picture. good experience, but nothing to write home about.

full text doc: this is such a fun place to be on a saturday afternoon. you can chill in the tasting room, where they are pretty generous with samples, and then take a tour of the brewery. ( and then maybe head back to the tasting room... ) this tour is probably the most involved and detailed tour i have had at a brewery and they managed to make it interesting the whole time! the people who work there clearly enjoy their jobs and highly regard the products they produce. oh, and they have a pig tank! in terms of the beers, i very much enjoy their more unique brews, such as fleur de lehigh and joe coffee porter. if you are ever looking to sample and the brewery is closed, just go across the street to atlantis. they have all pbc on tap.

full text doc: being a kid at heart, you know i've gone into build a bear a few times " pretending " to build a bear for one of my kids - but really it was for me! shuuuuu dont tell anyone but i still sleep with 3 teddy bears every night! yeah i'm weird i know i fully embrace this about myself! : - ) they have made this store a fun place for kids and adults. its a little pricey, but if you love teddy bears like i do, you'll get a kick out of making your own, from the stuffing all the way to buying all different outfits! these bears makes great personalized gifts! they have all kinds of uniforms you can dress your bear in, so if you know a cop, firefighter, nurse, you can make them a bear that they'll love! tons of accessories for the bears! i love the little bear sunglasses! so cute! if your not careful you'll be so enthralled with all the clothes, and accessories, you'll be having so much fun you forget to watch what your spending! i think my last trip here, i spent over $ 100 on 2 bears but they are so cute!

full text doc: love love love mariachi grill! the food is fresh and delicious, the staff delightful and accomodating. free chips and the best spicy salsa ever while you wait for your food. my personal favorite - the chicken quesadilla is a huge portion - enough for two easily! my co - workers and i pile into mariachi grill for lunch at least once a week - maybe more.

full text doc: i have been here three times and have had bad experiences twice. the beautiful range doesn't make up for the fact that the range staff is incredibly rude and condescending. i had one staff member take a loaded revolver out of my hands because i was shooting high on the target. my husband was in the middle of shooting a magazine when the same staff member came up and tapped him on the shoulder. the staff talks exhaustively about safety - such as carrying rental guns around in a basket - but has no problem startling someone with a live weapon in their hands. my husband is a retired marine and an expert marksman. the staff consistently interrupts with'advice'that is inaccurate at best. i don't feel safe at this range, i feel watched. i will not be back.

full text doc: on a recent trip to new orleans i sought out and found, after a bit of confusion, this wonderful little shop on pirates alley. the operators were great, the selection was jam packed and varied and the history of the two small rooms was palpable. altogether a wonderful treat for any reader and especially for the faulkner fan. the efficient use of space in which the proprietor houses the immense collection is truly impressive. the owner introduced himself and impressed me with his friendliness and keen knowledge of the most obscure titles and authors ; a true connoisseur. as an aside, the recommendation he made for lunch ( he recommended muffaletto from central grocery ) became the 2nd best highpoint of my visit to no. lastly, the female bibliophile on duty marked a passage in the faulkner book i bought which contained a beautifully descriptive of jackson square at dusk. i sat in the square the next evening and quietly enjoyed the passage, absorbing both the atmosphere of the square and the evocative writing.

full text doc: the good : super, super, super friendly staff. they explain the whole menu to you before you order. burgers are made with ground sirloin, so they are not juicy. i'm one of those people that thinks juicy = greasy, so i loved them. decor is kitchy and kind of cute, considering the dismal strip mall it is located in. the cookie tasted exactly like the ones i make at home, which are pretty good if i do say so myself. the toppings are fresh and the bacon crispy. the not - so - good : burgers only come in 1 / 3 lb. i am assuming that is because they only have one bun size. i can only eat so much, so i wish they had a smaller one or a kids version. everything was hot and super fresh, but really lacked any kind of noticeable taste or seasoning. it wasn't bad at all, but just kind of there. i was excited to see two strips of crispy bacon on my burger, but when i tasted it alone, it didn't taste like anything. same with the fries. they were hot and crispy, but just kind of blah, even with the addition of some salt at the table. last

full text doc: as other reviewers have stated, this is your standard ( and good ) mexican food. the menu is plentiful but also a little convoluted. location is fantastic and price is probably the best you'll find in an area like indian rocks beach. unfortunately the service with both of our visits was below sub - par. you'd almost have to intentionally try to ignore someone to pay any less attention to customers. i'd consider giving this place 3 - 5 stars if they put a lot more effort in serving the customers. it took us 15 minutes after being served our meal for the server to return. and when she did and we asked for refills and more salsa, she seemed annoyed that we needed anything at all. maybe she was having a bad day, but our visit before this one was only marginally better. unfortunately we will only be returning when the service end of this business is spruced up. the lack of friday night business tells me that we're not the only ones that feel this way. the place was nearly completely vacant when we were there around 8pm. so be aware, good food, bad service.

full text doc: i feel pretty strongly that i would be happy to dine at a place with great service and decent food, rather than the vice versa experience. however, at public greens, it never seemed to be a choice between the two. instead, you'll find really great people fixing up really great food. stare at the simple yet captivating menu board, drool over the baked goodies on display, then walk up to the counter and place your order with confidence... because this truly seems like the kind of place where you can't go wrong. i had zoodles, grilled chicken, and a cup of tomato soup ; simple yet so good ; even left with half of it to enjoy for lunch the next day. but let's hear it for the real hero... their compostable to - go containers! public greens is a wonderful option for nearly any dietary preferences. the menu is clearly marked for vegan and gluten free, and i also heard the question " is there anything your allergic to? " asked to every single person i overheard place an order. ( slow clap )

full text doc: i came here last night for the first annual cinco on congress and it was pretty fun! when we arrived they had a live band playing on the stage upstairs and a dj spinning top 40s downstairs. there are 3 bars ( 1 in each room, 2 on the top floor ) and drinks ran at about $ 5. 25 per shot, $ 7. 50 per mixed drink, and $ 2. 50 for tecate ( special of the night for cinco de mayo ). no one was really dancing downstairs except for my group so we headed back upstairs and by then they had switched to a dj playing an upgraded version of top 40s and house music. they have two stripper poles and if you stand right by the ac units it's a nice spot to dance in [ : i would return here again on a regular night to see what's up with this place because so far i like it! the only negative thing would be the pace of all the bartenders.. they are all superrrr slow to serve up drinks.. - 1 star!

full text doc: you must eat here!! so absolutely delicious that it always shocks me how few people are in there. i guess the price could be a detergent but the servings are large and there is no flavor comparison around. i've only been there in a group of three or more but it works well for how the plates are served. we each chose a meal and then order a large coconut rice. we share everything and make it a tasting experience. tonight we had calamari to start. even my so who doesn't like sea food had more than one piece of it. every time it is cooked to perfection and the mango sauce is an unexpected but wonderful pairing. our dinner consisted of coconut rice, yellow curry, honey garlic pork, pad thai and cashew chicken. four of us barely finished everything. the chicken was delicious. the curry was done to perfection. my favourite of course is the cashew chicken. the sauce is complimented by the rice. i can't wait to go there again!

full text doc: i really like this liquor store. it's right next to a newly re - done mac's convenience store which is handy for purchasing some cola to go along with the vodka. they've got wine tastings every friday. i used to work near here and attend the wine tastings each week after work. it's a great way to check out different wines without having to pay and pray. my favourite thing about this store is that they carry root beer schnapps! it's the only store i've seen it available! i bought a mickey of it the first time i saw it and have been back to purchase the big bottles ever since!

full text doc: this was an awesome way to spend a saturday! my husband and i were able to snag two vip tickets through yelp. we got there an hour before the general admission, which was perfect for me. we went to almost every brewery tent to try their unique brews. i find that i'm more partial to the lighter and frutier ones, while he likes the darker brews. there were bottle openers, business cards, coasters, and stickers that you could take to remember which bars to visit later. i have quite the selection now we had lunch in the tent... the spread was amazing! i tried, or tried to try, every chili that was offered. i'm not a big fan of spicy food, so i tried to eat some of them. i think my favorite was the chili verde with a little sour cream. the cornbread muffins helped absorb some of the spiciness. i didn't have any of the dessert, but my husband tried a pumpkin mousse. there was also a small bar inside serving bottled water and mixed drinks. the tent next to this one had a cash bar, so we didn't drink. but we did catch bits and pieces of the football

full text doc: the florida aquarium is great. i am a season pass holder and i hate commmitting to passes like that for any type of facility. i usually never think that they are worth the monetary commitment, however this is the first time i would highly recommend that anyone gets the seasonal pass here. this aquarium is quite lovely. it's just the right size and it's too overwhelmingly large to get through in a few hours, but it's also not too small where you can just zip right through. this aquarium is very well laid out, spacious, with plenty of associates around to guide you, answer questions and ensure that everyone is having a safe, educational, and enjoyable visit, they have plenty of sitting areas as well as petting zones for children and the few times i have stopped to ask questions and discuss the exhibits with their staff, it's clear that everyone there is not only highly trained and educated, but passionate about their work and the creatures there. the aquarium here is unique in that they put on many events geared towards family as well as adults, which is a huge perk. it's a wonderful location in tampa, right by the water, which allows it to offer boat rides and water front views of fireworks during events like the

full text doc: i got there around noonish on a saturday and the line wasn't bad. after waiting in line for about 5 minutes the wait to get my actual cheese steak was 10 - 15 minutes...... which is what they told me when i ordered. they give you your receipt with your order on it and call your name over a speaker when it's ready. i had the steak italian with sharp provolone, broccoli rab, hot peppers and fried onions. i think my expectations was high because i watched this place on bobby flay's throw down and tony luke had to get call for back up ( his broccoli rab ). the sandwich was good, but it wasn't as good as i was expecting. going to have to try the original cheese steak with the whiz and fried onions next time.

full text doc: jose, you've done it again. the bf and i went here last friday with reservations ( the earliest available was 8 : 45pm ), got there early ( 8 : 00pm ), and figured we could sip on some drinks and munch on some guac at the bar. however, to our delight, the place was only 2 / 3 full, and we were seated immediately. the server recommended 3 - 4 plates per person, we chose 6 and it was way too much food! we agreed to share everything : guacamole with corn chips, yellowtail ceviche with a sangrita sorbet, truffled cheesy mushroom flatbread, tongue tacos ( not my choice ), queso fundido with soft tortillas, and my favorite dish : cheesy corn rice in a cute cast iron pot. we topped off our feast with rice milk, fruit fruit margaritas, and piping hot churros with dipping sauces. then, we rolled ourselves back home and i complained that my stomach hurt. story of my life. yum, i love you jose garces. so does the bf, he said he would marry you just so that you could cook him dinner every night.

full text doc: it's hard to screw up pizza! unless you're the kind of person who believes pickles belong on it ( thanks papa john's! ). fortunately, pickles are nowhere to be found at pieology. lately, the fast - casual personal pizza concept has exploded all over the place. for that reason alone, i would normally avoid what appears to be a fad... unless someone suggests i try it. my brother ( in california ) made this recommendation. and since the first pieology in arizona is located in tucson, i decided to check this place out with my mother while visiting home. normally, she is the queen of cheese pizzas. so i was impressed when she chose some fairly exotic toppings for her pizza ( gorgonzola, ricotta, artichoke hearts, roasted bell peppers, spinach and mushrooms ). my pizza was a simple, delicious margherita pizza with feta and kalamata olives added. for only $ 7. 99 you get an 11 " pizza with unlimited toppings. compared to other places i am familiar with ( humble pie ), this is a pretty good deal! i consider humble pie an excellent point of reference to measure other pizzas by. pieology measures up

full text doc: literally one if the most disappointing dinners out of my entire life. four friends and i were excited to go out and have a " family " dinner and were ready to spend some dough. upon entering the restaurant we were sat and when the waitress eventually showed up she asked us what we wanted. no hello, no smile, no offer to describe the choices, or to explain how the inclusive meal works. we should have walked out right then. after ordering she dropped one carafe of wine in the table and then disappeared into the kitchen. the half carafe on wine barely filled four glasses and since we had already been told that we wouldn't get any more wine, we wanted to get at least a full glass each. after waiting ten minutes for a sign of service i walked into the kitchen to ask for more wine. while i did receive more wine i also got a dose of nasty attitude. it's only franzia for crying out loud. next our waitress dropped some barely passable soup which tasted like a crappy version of campbell's minestrone. and then all the rest of the four " courses " were unceremoniously dumped on the table at once : greasy beans, wilted salad, fatty oxtails. the main course was ok

full text doc: went for a birthday dinner of about 15 people. wait time was surprisingly not long and we were done eating and out of there pretty quick. food was delicious. i would say the spice level here is higher than other chinese restaurants. i love spicy food so it was good for me. but for some, it was a bit too spicy. we ordered family style with a bunch of dishes. dandan noodles was good. better than han dynasty imo, but not as good as chili szechuan's. it was spicier. the sizzling shrimp dish was delicious. the marinate on the shrimp matched well with the dish. it was a bit spicy as well since cayenne peppers were used. double cooked chicken was flavorful and delicious. a dish to definitely get. there were some other dishes we got, however, i forgot the name of them, but in my opinion, all of the dishes were good and couldn't go wrong. just remember to get alot of rice to offset the spiciness. it was someone's birthday, and they were nice enough to put a sparkler on top of ice cream for the birthday girl. service here is very good and would come here again for both the food and the service

full text doc: a special place! sagami is a magical little gem that has never failed to please. from the moment i first had the fortune to dine at this restaurant over ten years ago, i realized it would be my favorite. a lot has changed over the last decade ; however, sagami has remained timeless. they have added an addition in the back ( in which i don't prefer to dine ), but a simple request when making our reservation ensures that my dining experience is as nostalgic as my first! i love the dark, authentic little room, with kimono - clad waitresses. i love to share the handful of words i know in japanese, and the waitresses are more than willing to teach a new word or two. as another yelper mentioned, it is a great place for special occasions. i went to sagami for a first date ( with who is now my fiance. ) we returned several times that year, but made sure we returned for our anniversary. the waitress graciously taught us how to say i love you in japanese! we still reminisce about that each time we return and its been nearly seven years. the staff and owner work together like a symphony, and we never feel rushed. the food

full text doc: k. o. p. is probably one of the nicest shopping facilities i've ever been to. when i lived out in philly a few years back i actually got a job working for the bose showcase store along designers row ( a whole section for high end fashion gucci, armani, cartier, etc ). they had a starbucks inside of the bose store i was working at ( never seen that before in any other showcase store ) as i would see local celebrities time to time shopping and strolling through the mall. no sales tax in pa on clothing and food is something you quickly get adjusted to coming from a high tax state such as il ( hmm 0 % to 9. 5 % in chicago... ). big on real estate space, third largest mall in america, but i'd have to say the nicest and best kept out amongst all the big malls in the us. the location also has historical significance as valley forge is right down the road, great for a summer drive and hike.

full text doc: i'm orginally from california and i went down to sparks for my godson's christening. i'd heard about sushi pier from my cousins, brother, and uncle & they'd been raving about this and that. i was a little hesitant since it was a sushi place in the biggest little city in nevada. despite it being far from any pier, this sushi joint blew away all my negative expectations. first of all, it was all you can eat sushi for a mere $ 12! a roll by itself is about $ 7 already. so with the mantra of " all you can eat sushi! " in my head, i participated in gluttonous bliss. the sushi was absolutely great and differentiated itself from what i was used to in the bay. they had little twists to each of their rolls and had quirky names like the marilyn monroll ( which i really enjoyed ). if i remember correctly, the marilyn is similar to a philadelphia roll, but with tempura - fried tuna in the middle.. i would also try their spicy tuna handroll.. i don't really have to say anything about it.. just try it. : ) my first visit there was very enjoyable

full text doc: i have been here many times over the years. the food is always good, the service was always up to par, they have always been an easy 4 stars for me every visit, no matter who i was with, no matter when. what makes them a solid five stars for me is the depth of their professionalism. not long ago my father passed away, and we chose the william penn inn as the place to hold the reception as it was a very special place for my family, especially my mother and father. the people we dealt with were absolutely amazing, from the manager on the floor to the waitresses, the chef, even the bus people. the food was probably one of the best buffets i had ever had, and keep in mind, i had no appetite. the bartender was perfect, classy, appropriate and kind, and being client facing, as all bartenders are, he was what needed. this was the tipping point. we had a lot of things on display in honor of my father's many accomplishments, the least of which were his military awards. the bartender inquired about my father, and he knew that he was a lieutenant colonel in the army, which helped us in the transition from the second most emotional thing i had ever experienced

( note to girls : bring a small purse that you can wear and still dance, not a chunky bag that has to be left under a potted plant. ) plus, this place let me in when i was still underage and using my friend's chilean id. cuba libre, te amo.

full text doc: franklin fountain is a must go when i visit philadelphia. i read up on it, and instantly fell in love with a vintage ice cream shop. some places try to pull it off and fail, but in my opinion this place gets it right. they have various sundaes ( favorite sundae : the franklin mint ), sodas, and many flavors of ice cream. you can have a different combination every time you visit. the prices are great, the atmosphere, and the service is all great. a definite must.

full text doc: the cuisine at honey's is a mix of southern and jewish favorites. i was overwhelmed with all the delicious sides offered at honey's. you can get grits or an onion potato latke ( fried crispy to perfection ). they have fresh mixes on traditional breakfast food like omelets with asparagus. the pancakes can be ordered with several different kinds of fruit inside the pancake. i was also thrilled to be able order buttered challah bread with my meal. the restaurant was decorated in a rustic, colonial theme, but it wasn't over the top or too stuffy. honey's has a very young feeling. situated in northern liberties, honey's is delicious, hip, and not far from the neighborhood strip.

full text doc: chris'does a great breakfast. the food is fresh, not greasy. they don't have a variety of pancakes, but they do the basics well and they are very consistent. there's something about their eggs ( love'em ), and they have a variety of options available to those with restricted diets ( i. e. vegetarian, diabetic, low cholesterol / fat ). i'm not particularly thrilled about chris'as a dinner hangout. it's basic family steak house fare and slightly overpriced, unless you want a great place to treat your grandparents to a meal they'll enjoy ( and catch the early - bird specials ). as a whole, this privately owned ( bartolino's ) establishment cannot be compared to a chain restaurant as some folks choose to do. there is definitely a difference in the food, atmosphere and management. the interior was updated a few years back, but still has a dated feel. chris'is popular with families and folks of all ages.

full text doc: here's the scoop, peoples : this little shop in montecito serves up gelato and gourmet sorbet. for this kind of frozen treat, it is my top pick in the santa barbara and greater sb area. this is locally owned, locally run and locally sourced. flavors vary with seasons, with fruit coming straight from the farmers markets. the first time i came here i had fresh pluot sorbet. pluots! it's good, it's honest, your gelato or sorbet comes in pretty cups. on a sunny day with some friends and their kids after a day at the beach or playing croquet, this is the life. a pity it's not in the best location. you'd think a coast village road address would be some pretty passage way filled with flower boxes and strolled by the leisure class. instead, it's in this sunken strip mall area that feels a little damp outside. so just focus on the incredible local yumminess of your sorbet and you will be in the happy place. the owners are very responsive to feedback. my question to them - when can i buy their stuff outside of montecito?

full text doc: the husk is in a beautiful old brick building with a wrap around porch that is hard to miss. the update interior has a lot of natural light with multiple levels for dining. my out of town guest and i didn't think to make a reservation so it was about a 25 minute wait to sit at the bar in the basement right when it opened @ 10am on a sunday. they didn't let people come and go as they pleased in order to give people plenty of room to enjoy their food, which we appreciated. the bartenders were very knowledgeable and professional. we will definitely make a reservation the day before, there were many open tables but all reserved. we split the coddled egg and the country fried steak breakfasts. the steak won. the best part were the fresh and delicious donuts. i would go back for just those alone! i'll definitely be back again when i feel like splurging a bit for a nice southern brunch. advice : make a reservation! it won't matter if you come early on a weekend, it'll likely be a wait.

full text doc: this place offers the worst of the worst of americanized chinese. previously i'd been to the lunch buffet and swore i'd never return, but one of my co - workers insisted that dinner was a different matter. the dining room carpet was still repulsively grotty and the place still smelled of burned onions. i got the special dinner b to go. i started with the hot and sour seafood soup. it didn't have any seafood in it. it was piping hot out of the styrofoam container but bland. the sourness was dull instead of tangy. there wasn't even a nibble of hottness, let alone a proper bite to offset the sour. i followed with the appetizers. fried shrimp, bbq spare ribs, egg roll, paper wrapped chicken. the chicken was the best of the bunch being at least inoffensively bland. everything else was deep - fried and sodden with grease rendering it virtually indistinguishable. the shrimp was vulcanized and it's breading scorched to a dark brown. the flavor of the grease suggests that the deep fryer oil hasn't been changed this decade. the ribs were, i think, burned all to

text: trattoria reiterate aplomb papardelle fennel fennel convivial espelette tarte toothy attentive caramelly crunchy lamb ragu tatin richness richness deconstructed selection lacks grilled fragrant case sharing smoky spanish piedmontese oil bland bites version pale sweet : : : minus few delight store yelp
full text doc: the yelp posts about this restaurant are excellent, so i don't want to reiterate the often described yet again. a few highlights : papardelle with lamb ragu - broad, home - made noodles, cooked to toothy perfection ( as you would find in a piedmontese trattoria ) ; grilled spanish octopus with fennel and espelette aioli - a delight! smoky bites of sweet octopus playing off the crunchy bitterness of the fennel and the richness of the aioli. in addition, the bread ( served with a fragrant olive oil ) is really good and is served generously, and then there is the little wine store where you can buy interesting bottles at fair prices. the friendly and attentive service will serve them to you with aplomb. there is a small but good beer selection. the atmosphere of the busy restaurant is convivial, with happy diners sharing plates. one minus : the strangely deconstructed desserts that don't approach the deliciousness of the original. case in point : the tarte tatin, with way too much pale and bland puff pastry, lacks the caramelly richness of a traditional version.

full text doc: this stephen starr place is a real find. it's special enough to be a go - to destination, but situated in just the right spot and laid - back enough to be a neighborhood hangout. i love the fresh guacamole and chips, the " macho nachos " and the various other tapas - like dishes. you can either eat inexpensively or splurge a bit and go all out. my friends and i like to sample the drink menu and i know a few people ( including myself ) that swear by the frozen pineapple margarita. fyi, the mojitos are good, but very inconsistent. stick with their signature drinks on the menu.

text: beachside drinks drinks drinks of of of of steaks special family slightly types reported well menu menu excellent eaters chicken great less busy noisy has has has order ' '
full text doc: the beachside has been a personal favorite of my family for years. their menu has changed slightly but not enough that i cant still order my favorite. whats great about the menu too is that it pleases all types of eaters. for those who don't like seafood they always have chicken, steaks and even lamb, all of which has been reported to be excellent. for those of us who love seafood, its always fresh and cooked beautifully. it lost one star though... the drinks are less than average. the bartender didn't know how to make well known, easy drinks and their " house special " drinks weren't even that good. that and it can get very busy and noisy, which for a romantic place kinda kills the mood.

" rarely am i pleased with my experience, save for the nine west outlet ( damn you cute shoes! ), golden krust ( patties! ), and new york and co ( redline finds! ). my generous 2 stars are due to these businesses only. i feel like i have entered another world, one in which i must watch out for unruly kids ( why aren't they in school at noon? ) and weird people who would like me to be their friend and / or social worker. i really should stay away but it keeps drawing me back for more disappointment.

full text doc: we had a four top and all thought their meal was great except one. she ordered a chicken dish, and loved everything in it except the chicken. it was bland and could have ruined her experience, but the sauce saved the day and covered for that blandness. the rest of us had pasta based dishes and all were great! the appetizers were excellent, as was the desert. the drawbacks were that it took a very long time to get our bill, and when we did, it took even longer to have it picked up. the owner apologized and said they were very busy, but they were probably only at about 25 % capacity, and i would think on a saturday night you would be ready for a bigger crowd. that, and it was pricey. we can get the same quality freshly made pasta for a better price around tampa. overall - we will be back because the food was good, but not as often as we would if it were a little less pricey.

full text doc: in any given city, residence inn tends to be located a stone's throw - or two - from where the action is, but that's a minor inconvenience if you have access to a car or a good public transportation system. this property is ideal for families or friends who would like some privacy or a little extra space to spread out. accommodations are in studio, one -, and two - bedroom ( two - bath ) apartments, with fully - equipped kitchens and comfortable living rooms with a dining area. amenities include satellite tv with premium channels, video games, and pay - to - view movies, phone with dataport and voice mail, and a fireplace in select units. there's a swimming pool and fitness center with cardiovascular equipment and free weights on - site. rates - which vary by season and day of the week, but generally start at $ 129 - include a buffet breakfast and an evening reception with complimentary cocktails and snacks.

full text doc: standard tap was the perfect pit stop for a post new years eve noonish brunch. the bloody mary's are perfectly spicy and there are some interesting selections on the brunch board. some of the folks at my table were feeling adventurous and ordered the antelope and eggs, which was rather tasty. i stuck with the traditional egg platter. most of the egg entrees came with cheesy potatoes ( yum yum ), your choice of meat ( bacon or sausage ) if meats not already included, and the choice of toast or a biscuit. definitely order the biscuit and butter that bad boy right up! service was a little slow, but it gave us time to suck down some alcohol and reminisce about the prior evenings shenanigans. also, it was new years day so i'm guessing they were quite swamped. i was pleasantly surprised by the quantity of my breakfast plate for only $ 9!

full text doc: this place has great ethiopian food and a nice atmosphere. you have the option of sitting at a traditional ethiopian table ( meaning short stools and a whicker table ) or a western table and chairs. the ethiopian tables are fun to sit at once, but the stools have no back support, so once the novelty wears off you might want to go back to the other tables. the food is delicious! it's good for vegetarians and meat eaters alike. there's also a good selection of beers ( some of which are imported, such as from ethiopia ) and so on. the service is average. it's not great, but i wouldn't call it bad either. the atmosphere is nice and calm, and you can usually expect to see the normal southwest philly kind of folks hanging out here.

full text doc: this restaurant is nicely decorated and very pleasant to sit and enjoy a meal in. the staff was attentive and friendly. the buffet option is quite good and reasonably priced, around $ 10. the selections on the buffet were all unique and actually all had a different flavor unlike some buffets where everything on your plate looks different but tastes the same. the lassis are tasty and very reasonable at $ 3, a lot of places charge at least $ 5. a college student favorite, so the dress is casual. you get your choice of dessert included with the buffet, and they also have a full menu if you want something specific or are embarrassed about your fat ass getting 3 plates of grub.

full text doc: one of the most popular pizza restaurants in boise by far. flying pie is a cool spot to unwind with the family and friends anytime during the week when you're craving a good slice of pizza. the toppings are fresh and the dough is the right consistency - not too thin or thick. they feature several unique beers worth trying and the familiar ones with'drinkability.'the people who work there are fun and funky which matches the atmosphere. where else can you get pizza that features a giant gong that workers hit whenever they get tipped? also, where else can you go to draw your own interpretation of a pizza face? flying pie gets flying praise from this chick.

full text doc: i'd say 8 out of 10 times is a great experience, so we keep going back, although not as frequently as we used to, because parking downtown can be a challenge. good food, good atmosphere. they changed their cocktail menu a few months ago and my favorite drink was removed. as minor as that sounds, the drink was part of the appeal, and our server didn't offer to have the bartender make it, so that was disappointing during our recent visit. still, a very good restaurant, but offering to make the drink would have given them 5 stars.

full text doc: such a fan of this place. the food is good and the bar atmosphere is great with comfy seats! the dinning area needs some work and an ambiance established. i have been there about three times now and i have recommended it to many friends who have enjoyed themselves. i love the small plates they have. very flavorful and good portions. i have bad their salad, pork tacos, sol du jour, pasta and their tiramisu and it was delicious. i did not have their alcoholic beverages so i cant comment. the service was solid but could have been a bit faster and more attentive at the bar. the only problem is the location. it is out south of town and not much is developed out there. good quality of food for a decent price.

full text doc: booooooooooooooooooooo! but since i'm in a good mood, a few nice things to say about the crappiest stadium ever. 1. short lines at the concessions.. 2. dippin'dots ( not unique to a baseball stadium, but i needed them come the 6th inning ). 3. no problem getting tickets on game day. 4. the foul ball game, where you play a certain amount of cash with a handful of friends every inning, pass the bankroll on every foul ball, and when the third out is made, the person holding the cash wins! cheers to the creative teenagers in front of me in right field who were playing. thanks for an idea for making a dreadfully boring place more exciting.

full text doc: great dining spot on the canal in broad ripple with a nice scenic outdoor patio seating area, a large indoor restaurant & bar area, good service and great food. i will probably update this review when we return since our first visit consisted of appetizers & beer. there were 4 of us and we had hummus, baba ganoush, falafel, fries with garlic & feta and dolmathes. we loved every single dish. a lot. my personal favorites would be the baba ganoush made with rich olive oil and smoked eggplant. and, the falafel, made with fava beans (! ), was moist inside and crispy but not greasy on the outside. this falafel makes all other falafel i've had taste like fried paste. hopefully, when i return, the entrees will be as good as the appetizers. i know those platters of kabobs that kept passing our table looked delish.

text: frosties frosties fastfood definately another no changes chunky not not not replace ago see how what type do do but mass loss made ice near their can that that that verdict icy or & & &
full text doc: i can definately say i am not into fastfood. i have always really enjoyed wendy's frosties, truthfully that's all i have ever had from a wendy's. a few years ago the wendy's near my house, the frosties started being different & not in a good way. as this was something i enjoyed i vowed to try other wendy's and see if they had made changes to the product or if it was just the one store. now that i have been to multiple different wendy's in the last few years, my verdict is clear. they changed their refreshing ice cream type product. it is no longer smooth & silky, but too icy & chunky. not the same as the original at all. that is another sad loss to mass marketing. what's a girl to do? how do you replace a frosty on the road, go healthy & get a smoothie.

text: always best best philly starr each favorites remember already ! will add end class sum quality one one first with both friendly now there return of of of consistent just fresh any for for latter service stephen . . . . .
full text doc: i know many have already reviewed this philly high end hot spot, but i just wanted to add my two cents worth. it consistently shows up on best in philadelphia lists, and well that it should. for years now it has been one of restaurant impresario stephen starr's many successes. what is especially noteworthy is this restaurant's consistent quality and service. we have been there at least a dozen times, and have had our favorites over and over again. each time they are better than we remember. the calamari salad is in a class by itself ; first courses are huge and filling. we like the pad thai and the lobster fried rice - both great bargains, with perfectly cooked shrimp in the former, and plenty of maine lobster in the latter. outstanding entrees include the salmon and any fresh fish. always leave room for dessert ; the chocolate box is a classic, and the " dip sum " donuts will assure your return. the staff is friendly and attitude - free. i say this place is one of the best deals in town!

full text doc: my sole complaint with truckee bagel co is their hours of operation. they're open from 6am - 5pm daily but being a vampire, it's probably a crapshoot as to whether or not i can get here during their business hours. my bro introduced me to this place one morning some months back when we were on our way to day four of a combatives seminar during which time i ordered a bagel with roast beef and cream cheese which made for a light but satisfying breakfast. just the ticket to start a day where i didn't want to be sluggish from a heavy meal yet needed the fuel for a full day of physical activity which, at times, bordered on interval training intensity. in addition to a whole line of bagel - centric meals - all made fresh daily on the premises - they also have more selections of smoothies than i knew ever existed. their home blend latte also comes highly reccomended but i can't confirm this firsthand since i get my caffeine fix via energy drinks. last - but definitely not least - last time i was here they had a bunch of extremely hot looking young ladies working behind the counter which is always a plus no matter how you look at it.

full text doc: our air conditioning wasn't working in june right as it got really hot! in a panic, i called envirotech based on the reviews here. felix was so helpful and nice, guiding us through a series of things for us to try before he came out to take a look. i was super impressed by him. our problem was beyond the realm of simple fixes, unfortunately, so felix came out and took a look, showing up on time. he diagnosed the problem, which required a new part that he had to order. he was mercifully able to do a semi - fix so at least we could stay cool while the part was coming in. doesn't this sound like a great review so far? so why the two stars? felix called to let us know the part came in, but we were headed out of town. he said he would call us again the following week to schedule the installation. we never, ever heard from him again. i called him every day for a week, left a message every time, and never heard back. it's been over a month and half. now i have to call someone else, explain the problem, and wait all over for the part. i am so unhappy with this service,

full text doc: carmine's is rather prettified by my standards ( and my god, the menus are laminated ) but the wide open warehouse space the restaurant sits in is certainly inviting. we all began with a millky and extremely potent cafe con leche ( $ 2. 95 ), which had a delicious caramelized flavor and enough caffeine to make me a happy puppy for the rest of the evening. you can, of course, also order booze. beverages aside, i quickly decided on the cuban sandwich, with the devil crab to start. the cuban sandwich, ( $ 6. 99 ), fair mistress of tampa cuisine, is carmine's bread and butter, and it does my floridian heart good to see the rows of unpressed cubans aligned along the counter here, ready to be slathered with butter and smushed under a hot iron for a bit. the cuban came out fairly quickly, and although i was somewhat nonplussed by the inclusion of ( gasp ) lettuce and tomato, the sandwich worked well, with the requisite crunchy cuban bread and plenty of delicious, delicious mayonnaise. only critique : it wasn't pressed flat enough to my liking, and fell apart just about as

full text doc: i went in for a recall repair on my sportage. phone contact with service went very well, they robo - called the day before to remind me, which i appreciated. service department was very fast for check - in, i had them throw in an oil change while i was there. i was told it would take roughly an hour. the waiting area is in the showroom, a tv is on for waiting customers. a radio was also on, causing a bit of a conflict, but otherwise, no problem. at almost exactly one hour, the service department guy brought my keys, and paperwork to the cashier in the showroom. i was on my way 65 minutes after i arrived. very efficient, friendly, clean, reasonable price. i'll be going back.

full text doc: with its prime location at euclid and laclede, stlcomc wins the awards for best people - watching locale and longest restaurant name. many a lazy sunday morning has been spent on the excellent sidewalk cafe. but as i write this in february, that warm, shady spot is a distant memory. so can the oasis bring in the stars without relying on its lovely vistas? yes it can. every time i go there, the owner greets me like an old friend and is quick to take my order. a caution about the service though : the owner is a one - man show. because he does his own busing, waiting, cooking, cleaning, etc. he doesn't have free time to check up on you. but just wave your hand and he'll be right with you. the food is unique yet entirely accessible if you're not used to mediterranean, and it's delicious to boot! the indoor outlets and quiet atmosphere make it a decent study spot too. you can wait'till warm weather rolls around before trying the oasis, but i'm heading there now.

full text doc: after arriving at phl, we had to wait a half hr for a shuttle, i continued to call the location we were going to and no one picked up. after seeing every other rental company at least twice, we were finally picked up. 2 people waiting for avis, were also allowed to board our bus when i had just seen 4 avis shuttles go by. once there, there was a wait of 10 people deep with only 2 reps who were moving incredibly slow. after 10 hrs of traveling and arriving at midnight, waiting 30 minutes for a shuttle, waiting 30 minutes to get a car, this was the last thing i wanted to do. after finally getting our car, there was a line of people trying to exit the parking lot, that took another 15 minutes. so after arriving a half hr early on our flight, we ended up finally leaving an hr and half later. the only saving grace was that the shuttle driver was a very nice lady. we will never use budget again.

full text doc: living in the backyard of blue bottle coffee roasters, i was pleased to stumble across green street's cafe one block away from where i was staying ( clinton st b & b ) while i was in town for a week in september. the bay area pour - over coffee culture can be rather snobby at times, so i was pleased to be greeted with zero pretentiousness. the owner, tom, worked in the cafe himself quite a bit, too. he was eager to talk coffee, roasting, and pour - over technique. he introduced me to some methods i had not tried before ( including the " sock " or nel drip, which i guess is so passe in japan ). the baristas on staff were all friendly and wonderful folks too, eager to chat when there was a little free time and recommend other things for me to do, see, and try. this was my go - to coffee shop while i was visiting for a week. well worth it. great roasts, well - executed drinks, super friendly staff, nice vibe.

full text doc: one of the best mexican restaurants in philly hands down. although it's not traditional mexican they do a great job of cooking up innovative new takes on the classics such as crab and lobster tacos with mango salsa. they also make fresh guacamole to order, though at $ 12 a serving it's way over priced. there is definitely something for everyone here with poultry, meat, seafood, and vegetarian options. the drink menu is solid for a mexican place with the required margaritas and tequila. the restaurant again takes a new twist on the old favorites with blood orange margaritas, pomegranite margaritas, no tequila margaritas, and some interesting sangria combinations. service was pretty attentive except for refilling the water. the only things that keep this place from getting 5 stars is that it is amazingly loud and there are way too many smokers for my taste given that the bar is in the center of the tables. be sure to check out the photo booth if you go in.

full text doc: love it! small intimate & warm place. we had tasting menu with wine pairings ( where they give you a choice of 3, 5 or 7 courses, and you can choose from menu which options you want! ). i had 5 course - with foie gras, arugula salad, rock fish, parpadalle with mushrooms and then pork belly. then had a bite of my friends grapefruit sorbet. everything was great. my only comment is that the pork belly was a bit fatty ( which is common with this cut ), but still delicious! wine pairings were fantastic too, especially an unusual dry riesling that was served with arugula salad. a few things to note ; wine only ( no liquor bar ) & reservations needed although they appear to have 5 seats at bar that maybe used for last minute seating ( all were full ). yum, definitely will go back!

full text doc: my parents and i have season tickets to the walnut street theater, so we discovered marathon within walking distance and almost always eat dinner here before our friday night shows. they have a large menu with lots of variety and i've never had a bad meal here. sometimes we get a table and sometimes ( if we are running late ) we just sit at the bar and order food with our drinks. the bartenders in particular are almost always very friendly and chatty with us. our servers are also good about getting us out in enough time for our show. i can't remember specifically the food we've ordered here, but it's run the gamut from salads, soups, sandwiches, burgers, steak, apps, dessert. food has always been good and we will continue to eat here.
