full text doc: overall, it was okay. i had expected more but i should have listened to previous reviews. the service is hands down one of the worst. the hostess mentioned ten times that they are " really busy " today before we even sat down, even though there were plenty of empty tables inside and outside. we waited for about 20minutes for a table, even with reservation and empty tables. we were handed a drinks menu, and our waiter showed up about 20minutes later asking for our food choices. we then mentioned that we may need the food menu first. so imagine the same procedure throughout our brunch. the food was good, but you could get similar quality and other places for less money and better service. on the plus side, the live music was great and sitting outdoor on the porch was lovely. but that's probably the only reason that they keep on having guests there.

full text doc: our first visit to bar louie was for lunch on a beautiful october day. we sat outside and people - watched, which was very pleasant. the service was ok, but kind of slow. overall, nothing spectacular, but nothing to ruin our lunch experience. our group of four ordered a burger, the cuban flatbread, the wisconsin grilled cheese, and the hummus - tabbouleh - tzatziki appetizer. the fries were tasty and the burger was enjoyed. i had the cuban flatbread, which was pretty tasty. i've had way better cubans before, but i wasn't massively disappointed or anything. the grilled cheese wasn't that great. however, the hummus - tabbouleh - tzatziki appetizer was very tasty! very flavorful and enjoyed by all in our group. i'd suggest this for a casual lunch spot on a nice day, where you can sit outside and people - watch. overall, i wasn't that impressed, but wasn't turned off either. i would have no problems with visiting this location again.

full text doc: great place to come for any cake decorating or baking needs in general! you can find dried fruits a plenty - cranberries ( and in a variety of flavors like cherry, pomegranate, blueberry, strawberry ), blueberries, raspberries, etc. they hundreds of bulk bins of nuts and spices and baking goodness! if you need it for baking - they probably have! you can also grind fresh - all natural peanut butter or almond butter right in the store. they also carry reasonably priced cookie cutters and baking supplies. i have realized that some items like plain almonds or tamarind almonds are quite a bit cheaper elsewhere - but i still give bulk barn 2 thumbs up for their amazing variety!

full text doc: this is about as close as some of us are ever going to get to positano. and it is almost exactly like the real almafi coast. aldo lamberti has done a great job recreating the feeling : hand - painted tiles, lemon - filled vases, stone fountains, wall landscapes of the coast and flowing white curtains. this is such a chic place to take someone for a drink, or even dinner if you like them that much. i recommend hitting the sopra lounge where you can order the positano lemon drop or siciliano ( peach vodka, cranberry juice and amaro averna ). oh and how could i forget to mention the singular menu item that makes positano coast different from any restaurant : crudo. crudo is an italian delicacy that you can't really find in the states. i passed as i perfer the japanese sushi to the italian version. but after a few siciliano's, why not?

full text doc: queen village animal hospital contacted about 15 days after stella's surgery to take a look at how it was healing and take the stitches out. they immediately asked for me to remove this review. i told my fiance i would not remove it because i would never want anyone to go through what we did. in response to qv's work on her eye, it is possible that a " trained vet " could see that her lower eyelid needed to be corrected ( and it will never be known to us if it was a mistake made or just a last minute switch ) but the point is any professional vet should have informed us of the change. last night qv actually had the nerve to call my fiance last night ( which is what prompted me to write this update ) and threaten him that if he didn't have me take this review down they were going to file a lawsuit against us. my fiance actually had to hang up on them and they still called back to leave a threatening voice mail. my advice? take your business elsewhere. stella's eye still has a blue tinge but seems like it's healing. we will be taking her to a new vet.

text: indyartsguide ) ) ) hoosier her brought back his works cat faces who vonnegut vonnegut vonnegut vonnegut see see series 1922 she deep key bowl touch slaughterhouse holding . . . . . . . . . . . up paint cradle which which https https artist artist
full text doc: in preparation for super bowl xlvi, the arts council of indianapolis commissioned artists to create a lasting tribute to the celebration and to indianapolis called " 46 for xlvi ". hoosier artist pamela bliss was selected to paint this mural back in 2011 ( she did touch up in late 2016 ). the mural is officially called " my affair with kurt vonnegut ". bliss has been a key contributor to the public art scene in wayne county ( richmond area ) by holding a series of annual mural contests which brought public art to every town in the county. this mural was made from a composite of photographs of the author and faces northwest. vonnegut was an author born in 1922 who wrote such famous works as " slaughterhouse five ", " cat's cradle ", and " breakfast of champions ". many of his books mention indianapolis which vonnegut had a deep connection to. for more about public art in the indy metro area, see the arts council of indianapolis public art directory ( pad ) : https : / / www. indyartsguide. org / public - art / my - affair - with - kurt - vonnegut / for more about the artist, see her facebook page : https : / / www. facebook. com / pg / pamela

full text doc: i'll admit it. i originally was a skeptic. i'd hear friends make plans to go to tria and profess my disinterest. how could a place that served simply cheese, wine, and beer be that fantastic? and then i tried tria for the first time about a month ago, during a recent snowstorm ( the first major snowfall of the 2009 - 2010 winter season ). since that visit, i've been back almost weekly, eagerly awaiting the tria email each week telling me what ridiculous sunday school special i was about to have the pleasure of enjoying. the cheeses are amazing, and the varied beer selection rivals that of monk's, with equivalent variation and numerous rotating rarities. my name is frank, and i am a triaholic.

full text doc: i'm going to have to say that my visit to foothill pet hospital was the most pleasant veterinary experience of my puppy's entire six - month existence. the exam rooms were very clean and there were no mug - rings on the exam tables, the guy at the front desk was super - nice to my scared little puppy, and, most importantly, nobody called my little man a " she ". beyond the comparative excellence of foothill pet hospital compared to the other places i have visited, dr. rittenberg was super - nice and very knowledgeable about all of the most recent pet - care advancements ( heartworm preventatives, flea control, canine influenza vaccines, etc. ). due to the fact that i don't like to see my beautiful little boy in pain, i hope i don't have to visit too often. however, if my puppy ( or soon - to - be dog ) is sick or in need of some veterinary attention, i certainly would not hesitate about bringing him to foothill pet hospital.

full text doc: if you've not been here, i can't imagine why. the chef searches out fresh, seasonal ingredients and spins them into tasty dishes. the menu changes constantly to reflect his recent finds and he proves he knows what he's doing with them time after time. unlike many places in st. louis, this reminds me of fresh, regional ( i. e. northern italian ) cuisine. rather than the chef - boy - ar - dee southern italian stuff that is everywhere around here. this is a smallish and popular place, which means it can be crowded. but the front - of - house staff are as competent as the cooks and things move along efficiently and pleasantly. the cocktail menu changes with the seasons, the wine list is affordable and solid. the outstanding servers can guide you with any indecision you might have on anything. the small bar at the front is cozy, the bartenders are both great. but don't eat at the bar, folks, that's my spot. : - )

full text doc: the museum and exhibits themselves are small. annoying that you're not allowed to take pictures. i'll never understand this, what is being harmed by allowing photography, maybe the flash can distort the pigments in paintings, but physical artifacts??... in any case, it didn't stop me. i only visited because its near three other museums, and i'm a huge geek and have to see everything of interest while traveling. but i don't recommend this as a must see. i also couldn't help but feel awkward in a museum dedicated to the side that, rightfully so, lost the worst war in our nations history. call me a northerner, but i'm just not down with slavery and remimiencing romantically about a culture that allowed it to exist. pretty to cool to see the field dr's amputation kit... ouch and gross.

full text doc: i have a soft spot for the mexican stylings s of el zarape because, unlike a lot of the other taquerias popping up all over south philly, this place uses bacon and mozzarella cheese in some of their dishes, and who doesn't like that? my favorite lunch is the " gringa " quesadilla - lean pork ( not those fatty cubes of pork you often find in the more traditional taco joints ) marinated and grilled, with mozzarella cheese & grilled pineapple. pork, cheese and pineapple? it works i tell you. the side of beans ( i forget the name they have for it but there is definatly a " frijole " in ) it is much more like a delicious bean & bacon soup that comes with warm tortillas that the usual glop of refried beans. try it you like it. same goes for the homemade horchata. the price are much lower than that gringo place across the street and you get something more authentic with a friendly and funny staff.

full text doc: bachelorette party thoughts : honestly, these reviews really say it all. i am so happy we booked dee. i honestly felt like we saw things that we would have missed other wise if we decided to venture on our own. tour : dee picks you up from your hotel and off you go... she has such a sweet, awesome personality but she's so hip and cool at the same time. she starts out with some awesome rock music to pump you up. we opted to take off the hood and it was awesome! me and my friends had a blast in regards to limo experience. picnic lunch is included and we ended up doing 3 wineries / 1 beer brewery if your group wants to opt for that or you can do another winery, a minature donkey farm, solvang, and olive and vinegar tasting on a farm. tips : tips are appreciated and by the time you finish your tour, it is much deserved. dee had her own personal touch with everything. she provided a card and small gift to my friend and even gave everyone small snacks to start including water. the best were the cupcakes at our picnic... yummy! never felt rushed and i thoroughly enjoyed my time with the dee and her tour. side note :

text: sauteed rangoon rangoon salads kebab palate sauces lentil spring dish preparation seeds enjoys stir mild strained crispy clientele tamarind bell dip fries starting chili bean dishes dishes variants while paratha diced local marinated ginger some well which entrees burmese service spicy spicy spicy retains milk popular options
full text doc: burmese food has influences from india ( curry and lentil dishes ), china ( stir fries, noodles, spring rolls ) and thailand ( spicy, sweet and sour coconut milk and tamarind sauces ) but still retains unique preparation techniques and flavors. rangoon makes some concession to the local palate, but nevertheless serves a flavorful meal. the dishes say " hot and spicy ", but the taste usually remains mild. given the adjustments, rangoon enjoys an eclectic clientele and as a result is usually packed. servers are somewhat strained, and while service levels are adequate they are not exceptional. you could do well by starting with the thousand layer bread with curry chicken or potato dip. inspired from the indian paratha, variants are also present in malay food. the string bean or ginger salads ( both with sesame seeds ) are also popular. in entrees, you have a number of excellent options in chicken. i've really liked the chicken qeema ( sauteed, minced chicken over homemade bread ) ; chili chicken ( crispy, diced chicken with bell peppers and onions ) which is spicy, but different from the chinese version of the dish ; chicken mint kebab ( marinated chicken ) - - - all are delicious.

text: always love every every every each each ever favorite longwood longwood new new will forward own pont touch minutes minutes with changed from from from ones summer ? opening yes time time both years . . . . . . . . . . .
full text doc: the vision of pierre s. du pont has been carried forward perfectly. for 7 years i lived 5 minutes from longwood gardens so it was quite easy for me to take advantage of their annual pass and visit nearly every weekend. that often? yes, the gardens changed some aspect of the displays almost every week so each time there was something new to see and photograph. the amount of flower and plant species cultivated and displayed is quite remarkable, both inside the monstrous 4. 5 acre greenhouse, called the conservatory, and in the over 1, 000 acres. the conservatory alone houses over 5, 500 types of plants. each season brings its own unique touch to the gardens and they differ from year to year, thus, always something new to even those of us who were frequent guests. summer was a favorite time for me with the opening of the beautiful lily and lotus ponds. and the holiday season brought surprises every year. if you enjoy water fountains, you will love the ones at longwood. located about 45 minutes from downtown philadelphia, if you are ever close and enjoy flowers and plant life then this is a must - see attraction.

full text doc: called them because my ac wasn't working. i was quoted over $ 800 to rebuild the part that connects the furnace to the air ducts. the repair person didn't even turn on my ac because he said it wasn't warm enough outside. i had to pay the fee for the repairman to come out, but i rebuilt the air ducts myself. of course the airflow wasn't really the problem. so i researched the issue on the internet, and found out that the problem was low freon. a second repairman came out, and after a big hassle, he filled the freon. that fixed it. i asked to be refunded for the initial repairman's visit ( since he was completely incompetent, and didn't even turn on my ac to try and find the problem ). williams did a review, and refused to pay back the repair fee because i didn't follow the repairman's recommendation. so, they wanted to charge me $ 800 for a repair that would not have worked. then refused to refund the service call when it was not only proven it wouldn't work, but the real problem would have been found if he actually had tested my system.

full text doc: great seafood, great atmosphere. not terribly pricy for the beachfront location. i am giving this 5 stars because i am heavily weighting the location... on a typical sunny st pete day you get a nice view of the vinoy, the park, and you're super close to other bars, gelati, etc. oysters are great! the scallop entree is melt - in - your mouth amazing... salmon is great too! beer is cold and delicious! plus, it is a good place to check out some beautiful women dining outside. i will take pretty decent food, great beer, and a fantastic view anyday. there is a lot of good dining competition in the area, but this is one place you should keep in your rotation once in a while.

full text doc: walmart is pretty much a dump. customer service is non existent, associates are rude and slow, and in many cases the prices are higher than other stores. grocery staples like milk, eggs, oj, etc are priced higher than at my local schnucks or dierbergs. i won't even begin to discuss the quality of their " meat ".

text: quaint wailing gumbo depth bustle flavor hustle light impressed tucked tour delicious walls transported
full text doc: super quaint restaurant, tucked away from the street you feel that you're transported away from the hustle and bustle going on outside their walls. while only here for a light meal before our wailing tour, the food that we got was delicious. was really impressed by the depth of flavor in their gumbo, one of the best i've had.

full text doc: it's cute, clean, and it's hot and humid, so i stop to get a scoop. i first try the cucumber basil sorbet. sadly, way too sugary to be a palate cleanser. i tried another of their creations - the vin santo gelato : italian dessert wine with bits of biscotti. pretty good. lastly, chocolate azteca - dark chocolate with cayenne. it was wonderful, but it was too hot outside. i selected the vin santo, and left. unfortunately, as i ate more of my gelato, the taste of the freezer overwhelmed the ice cream. i should have known better ; the person who convinced me to select it also wanted to be rid of it, as it was the last in the container. there were two women having lunch, and their sandwiches looked fresh... sigh.

full text doc: my wife and i tried left bank cafe for the 1st time today. my first impression was mixed. there were several families with kids, but they were well behaved and i noticed they were pet friendly ( at least 4 - 5 people were there with dogs, big plus to us! ). they didn't seem really busy while we were there, but evidently were just prior to our arrival, so it took a few minutes for our waitress to get to us. once she did, she took good care of us & was very friendly ( thank you jodi! ). my wife got the cheese steak panini & liked it very much. she thought is was a little dry, but acceptable ( and she is very picky ). i had the andouille flatbread and i liked it very much. sausage had a little kick to it and mixed well with the sauce & onions. we both had sweet iced tea, but as we were on the deck / patio / outside, in the sun, the " iced " went away quickly. the tea was okay, but if you are used to " southern " sweet tea, plan on adding sugar. for desert, jodi ( our waitress ) suggested the nutella, strawberry, banana crepe. oh

full text doc: this is one of the best restaurants i have ever been to. i am surprised at the number of people that have rated this under five stars. i had an amazing blue cheese pasta dish and salad. i can't remember what else was on the menu. i do remember though, seeing a good selection of unique items not normally seen on menus. as everyone says, the decor is beautifully elegant yet never trendy. it's been awhile since i have been here and i can't wait to go back. you will need to trot out some business casual attire or maybe even a jacket, but it will make you feel like it is a special occasion. i apologise for not being able to provide a more detailed review, but i think this restaurant is a little underrated and wanted to give it credit.

full text doc: i went in for a full set with dip not acrylic with tony. he had great customer service skills but my nails vary in shape... was supposed to be coffin / ballerina ( see pics ), some of the sides on my nails have no color because he filed it off. he did attempt to redip those areas but it still didn't stay. the gel applied on top has begun to peel. pros : cuticle trimming included, variety of dip colors on nail wheel available so you see the finished color, great & humorous conversation cons : varied shaped nails, gel bubbling & peeling, + $ 5 for tips, + $ 5 for shape the pedicure from andy was relaxing but the tips not so much. tony has a good attitude, provided good conversation and made me laugh but his precision was off. so far the best set, acrylic or dip, remains super nail on grant & alvernon.

full text doc: i hadn't seen roller derby since i was kid watching it on tv... back in those days, it was pretty much as fake as wwe : - ) went tonight with friends to the pepsi coliseum at the indiana state fairgrounds to watch the final bout of the naptown tornado sirens & warning belles kick butt. lots of fun... but i have to admit i had no idea what was going on until one of the skaters - jostleynne hoes ( andrea ) - who is a friend of one of the friends i was with, sat with us for a while and explained the strategy, how points were scored, and generally what the heck was going on. these ladies are athletic and have a lot of skill. fortunately, we didn't see any injuries tonight. i thoroughly enjoyed the evening and can cross seeing a live roller derby event off my bucket list... but i'm sure i'll come back next season.

full text doc: i have only been to bb kings for events that have been held here - - it's great for that. very large space - - there are several rooms, and several bars, as well as a stage and pretty big dance area. the food is decent - - again, i've only eaten it at events so i'm not sure how different it is if you sit down for dinner. it's basically upscale bar food though. lots of fried stuff! the bands there are fun - - a lot of blues and jazz, as the name implies - - but you can book any band for a private party. this is a great space for groups because of the size, and it's not as cheesy as some of the other establishments on 2nd avenue!

text: ceviche alma fact entrees we week ) room service service soup main bean the the the the the the the the the the the the the the the . . . . . . . .
full text doc: the decor of alma de cuba is top - notch. everything from the entrance to the main dining room is gorgeous. the service was polite, but a little slow. i had the pulpo ceviche, which was delicious. my wife couldn't watch me eat it ( something about suction cups ) and stuck to her black bean soup. for entrees we had the skirt steak and the pork. the steak was cooked well - done, but still managed to be tender, which a crispy, charred outside. the pork was wonderful. i had never had pork with the skin still on it, but it seems like the way to eat pork. the crispy skin keeps everything moist and adds a great texture to the meal. it is a large portion, so you definitely get your money's worth. i'll chalk the slow service up to the fact that it was restaurant week, and would definitely go again.

full text doc: stopped here by accident! the husband & i were trying to go to the place up the hill but couldn't exactly find great parking for a truck & trailer. came down from the stop sign and here there was a large, open parking lot! great for us having to park a car, truck & trailer! we were quickly seated, our waitress came right over to take our drink order and chips and salsa were delivered. chips were warm and salsa was cold. the salsa was a little bland, we asked if they had another spicy salsa & the waitress so no. it would be nice if they offered up another if you requested, but we made due & added some green hot sauce to kick it up a notch. not being from around the area, we asked the waitress what she'd recommend and she said she doesn't like spicy food and hasn't eaten much but would recommend the fajitas.... which are basic, in our opinion. so we continued to explore the menu where we found authentic mexican tacos! we ordered an appetizer of ceviche, tacos nortenos and al pastor. the ceviche came out quick & taste was good. it was served on a tostada w / lime wedges

full text doc: atmosphere is pleasant but quite dark. this is added to by the dark, i think black, uniforms of the wait, bus and bar staff. male waits had long sleeves, waitresses had black pants, sleeveless but strapped tops with black bra straps showing. female bartender on duty had the same as the waitresses, but a large spiderweb type tatoo on her right shoulder and arm. i am not againest tatooes, but this would only have possibly been appropriate on halloween. the whole uniform bit did not fit in with the decor or expected type of restaurant. we ordered a martini - straight up and a blended margarita. were told they had no blender so margarita would be served tall over ice. minimal ice in the margarita and the martini was warm. food was served well and was plated very good and was quite good. ( seared scallops with lobster mashed potatoes and pumpkin raviolis ) white wine good, but served on the warm side so i had to ask for it to be in an ice bucket. overall, good, but not up to price range and expected quality of an upscale establishment in a major hotel / casino. we will try other places befoe returning here.

full text doc: located towards the " end " of bourbon street, past the gay block ( s ), sits lafitte's blacksmith shop. it looks like some contrived building you would see in disney world to set an old world mood, but it's actually the real thing. it can be a bit touristy, but locals love it as well. there's a piano and if a seat is available around the piano, grab it and sing along with the pianist as well as make suggestions. my go to drink there is the " purple drink " or that's at least how i refer to it. the bartenders will know what you're talking about. it is quite tasty and not as sweet as one would suspect. but watch out! it goes down easy and is full of everclear so it will sneak up on you. also, there is an outside patio and if you go at night, the interior is dimly lit which adds to the mystique that is lafitte's.

full text doc: yet another review that disappeared. i can't recall all of what i ate, but i do know that we were all impressed. i was skeptical, expecting a tourist trap. but city tavern tries to offer an historic dining experience. the decor, while sparse, is closer to what colonials might have experienced. so is the food. ingredients tend to be those that early philadelphians might have enjoyed ( if they had lots of money ). so you'll find grains like barley instead of pasta or rice. it was delicious with a good texture. it was all well - prepared and tasted good. each of us tried a shrub cocktail, which was pretty enjoyable as well. in all, it was a fun historical experience that was low on cheese and taught us a few things, all while enjoying a good meal.

full text doc: as someone who has worked in a lot of restaurants in my time, i tend to be a very tough critic. that being said, i can honestly say i was blown away with my experience at mango last saturday evening. we were there with a group of girls ( 8 ) and we were treated perfectly from the moment we arrived until we left several hours later.... ; ) so here are my thoughts : service : our waiter, a darling lad named elliot, was perfect. he was very attentive, helpful, and polite even though we were probably driving him absolutely nuts! he had a full section and still managed to make us feel like we had his undivided attention. food : in addition to my dish, i snuck a bite or two of just about everything my friends got - i was impressed that each dish was equally good! i especially loved the arroz con pollo - the perfect amount of cilantro. and of course, the cilantro dipping sauce that comes with the plantains is really all a girl needs to be content! drinks : hands down best sangria i've had - the fruit was crisp and tasty and the balance of spices was exact. i was also a big fan of the blue peach martini

full text doc: service is typical of any vietnamese restaurant, very lax & non attentive. the pho broth here is just average, but the bowls & the bowl holder is adorable! the one thing that makes this restaurant amazing is their fried rice cake with egg appetizer. this is something that i have to order every time i come here. crispy rice cake cubes with an ooey gooey center, with a sunny side up egg which leaks eggy goodness, served with a soy sauce to compliment it perfectly. be warned that the restaurant is pretty dingy, nothing impressive, & it can smell bad sometimes, but this is one of my more frequented vietnamese restaurants. if the asian people in a viet restaurant outnumber the americans, then you know you've got a winner.

full text doc: we watched the 4th of july fireworks from citygarden and it was perfect because my daughter could play right up until the fireworks started. it's an interesting enough space and i love that the jet pops are lit up and they go off constantly unlike the ones at tower grove park that take forever in between spurts. i think there are some issues with the place. the wading pools are surrounded by marble retaining walls. marble is extremely slippery when wet. this is a serious safety hazard. my daughter was playing in the water and fell and when i went to pick her up it was impossible to not slip around on the marble wall. a lot of other parents were complaining about the same thing. it makes it dangerous for kids getting in and out, too. another issue is that there are no barriers keeping kids from running out into very busy traffic on market. despite these issues, we love citygarden and would like to see more places like it.

full text doc: highly recommended mechanics. manager ed was referred to me by the storage place when my car broke down off sr 41. i called to tell them my car was being towed in, most likely due to the alternator, in line fuse or a few other likely culprits common with my cougar after it passes 98, 000 mi. anyhoo, he welcomed me over and once i got there i was treated like a person - i did not get the " little lady " treatment! when ed knew my alternator had been replaced a mere 12 months prior, he called the mechanic that installed it ( bill's family garage - they're awesome in tampa btw ) they warranty'd it out and only charged me labor. i was grateful he put in that extra effort that i don't feel a lot of places would do. it was done the next day for a very reasonable price. highly recommended!

full text doc: this place isn't half bad. my best friend was in town visiting me from nashville, per his request, we hit up ernie's for some late night fun & scouting. ernie's is neat. they've got a freezer where you can pick out your vodka and take a shot while you're in there. option for $ 5, $ 6, or $ 7, their vodkas have an array of different flavors, and quality picks. i settled for a black cherry van gogh vodka shot. it was wonderful! i think it would be great for a mixer too. smooth and sweet. and this info is coming from someone who can't handle shots too well. that one worked just fine without the requirement of a chaser right after it. bathroom is null. there is one. in the whole place.... co - ed. this being a gay men's bar, they should have a bathroom to accommodate the hags that join them! i. e. me. all the bartenders are topless. fit and topless, and absolutely delicious to look at. how unfortunate that they are batting on the same team as me.... oh well, eye candy it is. they have an outdoor bar

full text doc: one of my favorite pizzas in tucson. i would say brooklyn has consistently better crust ( i wish i knew how they did it ), but empire is consistently tastier due to their superior sauce. every time i go in for a slice, i find myself thinking " damn, this is really delicious pizza - i sometimes forget how good pizza can be. " a quick note about devon's 1 - star review : i don't think devon understands how slices work at a pizza place. is he under the impression that most places cook up a whole pizza, cut out a slice for you, and throw the rest away? empire does it the way everyone does it and it's perfectly fine. finally, a shout - out to geeks who drink, without whom i would not have been aware of empire pizza much less grown to love it!

full text doc: i have been to edley's a couple times, most recently this past wednesday night. it was packed at 7pm with a line almost out the door to order and only one lady taking orders. we didn't know we were supposed to order before sitting so we did just that and were able to get a pretty good table on the patio. waited in line about 10 minutes to order. the lady taking orders was not super friendly but that was probably because it was so busy. apparently fries are not a side but an appetizer so keep that in mind when ordering. if you want fries you have to pay the appetizer price rather than having it included in the price of your combo. the food was ok. i got the wings and fries, my friend got the pork sandwich, fries and coleslaw. the wings were not as good as i remembered from a previous visit. not sure i'll go back any time soon... maybe once they are done with construction and hopefully have a better ordering system.

full text doc: wow!!!! i am so glad we stopped by! took my parents here for a lunner ( lunch / dinner ) date after a trip to caladesi island. my parents sometimes are hard to please. they like a great value and amazing food which is very hard to find. well we found it here!!!! the beer selection was really impressive, i figured they would have a few specialty beers and that would be it. i was having a hard time figuring out what i wanted because of the large selection. i was really impressed by the bottle selection because most restaurants only have a few. i had the haus pub burger with a side of sriracha mayo. this burger was really good, extremely juicy and the roll was amazing!!!!! the pork belly was a nice added texture and different from regular bacon most restaurants use. the fries were way different!!! they were not shaped like normal fries but seasoned very well. just an fyi..... this burger is a mess to eat!!! get extra napkins, you will need it. as for my parents, they don't yelp ( boo ), but my dad says this place serves the best blackened grouper sandwich he has had

full text doc: a great lofty space in west philadelphia, right off the 34 trolley line! so easy to get to and super friendly staff. started taking pilates, with instructor julia, at studio 34 when they first opened and won't go anywhere else! julia is an extremely perceptive and talented instructor. she knows what areas i need to work on before i even tell her. i've had a few lovely private pilates sessions on the new equipment with julia as well. studio 34 has all new pilates equipment, a spacious common room with teas and reading material, and offer great community art events. plus, $ 5 pilates classes on tuesdays and fridays ( you can't beat that )! i love this place!!

full text doc: if you're looking for decent sushi at a decent price, this is one place to consider. a friend and i went to edomasa for the first time tonight, and even though i've had various sushi rolls for many, many years, i'd never really tried sashimi until now. we split the sashimi appetizer. not having had previous sashimi experiences to compare to, i can't say first - hand how it ranks, but it tasted great to me and my friend had nothing to complain about. we also split a rainbow roll and marina roll ( crab, avocado, eel and cucumber ) which were quite tasty, although i should have known better than to get to rolls that have the crab / mayonnaise mix ( as i don't really like mayonnaise ). the other rolls that were on the menu all also sounded really good, and i hope i have a chance to come back here and try more. we were there rather late in the evening, but the staff was quite friendly and helpful - - especially when our server discovered our table was uneven and rocking quite a bit and he immediately helped us move to an adjacent table.

full text doc: the latest incarnation of this 9th and bainbridge java house is by far the best. no longer does one have to wade throug piles of disorganized second hand clothing to find a table. the seating is probably the best in center city with comfy couches and armchairs. and there is no beating the fireplace. their coffee is nice and strong and they have a decent extended drinks selection. also, their wireless is reliable. it's a little too clean and modern for my aesthetic tastebuds. i like my coffeeshops served up with a slight dinge. but kudos the first set of owners to make that location work.

full text doc: nixon's is a great, reliable neighborhood place. it's a quaint little shop with tons of food options, which are all prepared excellently. i have never had a meal here i didn't enjoy. on my most recent trip, i had a grilled cheese sandwich and french fries. it seems hard to mess up, but i have definitely had the same meal at other places and been less than thrilled. the staff is always friendly and kind. this is a great local business that everyone in the area should support! there is something for everyone here.

full text doc: brunch! the bf's cousin took us here - and we were pretty excited because it had already been recomended to us earlier in the weekend. the tiny little cafe sits about 10 minutes from the quarter - i believe in " uptown " but i could have the neighborhood wrong ( what? i'm a tourist! ) i love that they grow some of their veggies and herbs across the street and that you are expected to order a mimosa while you wait. well, yes please! we sat after about 10 minutes of waiting outside ( hot! ) and were seated by a friendly waiter who quickly brought us coffee and water. hangover half - way cured - thank you very much! we decided that since we hadn't eaten enough this weekend ( lies! ), that we would order the bananas foster french toast as an appetizer 9sorry, had to at least try it ), scrumptios - - and i ordered an eggs benedict of some sorts with breakfast potatoes on the side. my concern was that the breakfast potatoes don't actually come with your breakfast - but whatever - they were worth the extra thousand calories. i really enjoyed the casual atmosphere and great, fresh food and hope to go back.

full text doc: we went to the melting pot for a romantic first wedding anniversary, and they delivered. yes, they are expensive for a full meal. yes, you'll have to deal with annoying kop girls waiting for a table with you. but grab an overpriced, delicious drink at the bar, and before you know it, you'll be having an experience, not just a meal. we sat in the romantic section in the back with 2 person booths, but i would imagine it would be fun for a larger group, as well. our server was great about explaining everything step by step, and we had plenty of time to talk while we ate some delicious food. skip the refills on the dippers for cheese. you'll be more stuffed than you can imagine by the end of your meal, and you don't want to miss any part of the dessert. we had the special menu and the coq au vin sauce for the entrees. the best combo of the evening was the balsamic sirloin in the coq au vin. we had the fondue selection of the special menu, the tiramisu. i'd recommend something else, as it ended up just tasting like plain chocolate. we came back

full text doc: you know it's been a while since i wrote a review. i thought i would log some of the things i haven't yet starting from the beginning of the year and work my way back up lol. this was a damn cool experience, but i have to say, if you are afraid of closed quarters " claustrophobic " you will poop all over yourself and pass out trying to get to the top of this thing. basically you board into retro space pods from the 50's and they were built for a much smaller people than the people of today lol. i mean i'm 6'2 but i was literally hunched over for the entire 4 minute trip up. at the top though you get one hell of a view. it's beautiful up there, and if you get up there and realize you forgot your camera, you will hate yourself for at least half a day. it's only $ 10 which in my book is a good price for a tourist attraction, so have at it. there's also a pretty cool museum down below that i enjoyed as well. i give the gateway arch a fun 3 out of 5 stars.

full text doc: on a recent cross country road trip, i had the pleasure of spending an evening on " lower broad " and happened into the legends corner bar. it is a fantastic bar that has no - cover live music from the early evening until the early morning. the bands tend to play for tips, and have an amazing ability to play request on demand. you will be hard pressed to find better musicianship or setting for relaxing with your friends, having a friendly drink ( or two! ) and striking up a conversation with any of folks within earshot. as for food, it is typical bar fare.. but the pizza was pretty good after a long night of honky tonk fun!

text: vallesana tortillas tortilla cunetto tacos tacos tacos kitschy tastebuds undeterred ' ' ' ' damned de served expecting paso pico places beef beef el : prepare someone my my my menu mexican mexican spent la maya maya lily restaurant restaurant authentic oily chicken seasoned judging sight grilled
full text doc: cunetto's be damned! it's maya cafe that just might be the most overrated restaurant in st. louis. someone once told me that a mexican restaurant is only as good and authentic as the tacos they prepare. acting on that advice, my friend and i shared the beef and chicken tacos. when ordering, we were a bit surprised that they only came in a corn hardshell or a soft flour tortilla. no soft corn tortillas in sight. we were undeterred, though, as we'd heard such good things about the place. once our food arrived, however, we were shocked. the beef tacos were reminiscent of the mexican fare i downed in the school cafeteria. the meat was ground, oily, and seasoned with flavors not unlike old el paso. i was at least expecting strips of grilled flank steak, especially judging by the prices on the menu. sorely disappointed. i think my money is better spent and my tastebuds better served at places like lily's or la vallesana. maya did have some good things going for it : great, friendly service, kitschy and fun decor, and really good pico de gallo. but these things are not enough for me

full text doc: i'm super picky about stores and i hate being helped... especially by men. i prefer to be left alone. sebastian was the first man i let help me pick clothing for me - ever. and... years later, he still picks jeans for me better than i can do it for myself. if you go into charlie's... he'll indulge you. he'll let you try all the ones you choose... supportively... but he'll sneak in a few others... and you'll buy one of those... or two. i never buy one of the ones i pick. i've stopped bothering. these days when i go to charlie's, i pick up a few t - shirts and if i want jeans, i just ask. it's faster and more efficient. if i like something, i just ask him if it will fit me. he knows. if you want jeans, go to charlie's. ask sebastian. if they carry the brand you want, there's no where better... anywhere.

text: pelican pelican yet yet able since being love love will overpriced spectrum charge has inside first back back usually spot would frou frou be to to to to to to they they they managed off off are brown brown sb sb moved between still could
full text doc: the brown pelican is in my top 5 restaurants of all time. its location right on the beach and beauty are incomparable. i love that they have managed to make the restaurant really nice yet still kept that awesome sb beach atmosphere going on. i would imagine that is a pretty hard thing to pull off. it is right smack dab in the middle of the spectrum between dive beach shack crab stand type places and frou frou stuck up overpriced fancy pants places. it's just a nice, yet pretty laid - back spot. so kudos for pulling that off. the food is amazing. everything i have had there has been fabulous and don't even get me started on their mojitos. service is usually great and you can sit inside gazing out over the ocean or on their heated patio... gazing out over the ocean. oh, and it's not even expensive! they could charge a lot more than they do. i just love the brown pelican and since i moved to the city i've really missed being able to go there. it will definitely be my first stop when i go back to sb to visit.

full text doc: we have eaten at etch, therefore picked it for our valentine date, feb. 14, 2018. we had concert tickets across the street, so we made our reservations in september. when we arrived for our date, we were told by the hostess that the reservation had been cancelled. we had not cancelled. she then went on to say that they did not have the correct phone number to contact us. well, if she had thought about what she was saying, she would have noticed that if we cancelled, she would not need a phone number to contact us. therefore we felt she deceived us. i am glad etch is doing well, but i will not be returning, due to the fact that your reservation could be cancelled on you, and you left without dinner plans. especially on a busy night like valentine's day. by the way, no apology given either. just a simple " who is next! full text doc: i already reviewed another location, but wanted to add to this one. this has got to be one of my favorite treats from childhood! having grown up in new jersey, these were a summer staple among my friends and me. basically, in terms of consistency, water ice is a cross between a slushy and a sorbet. it's not as sweet as sorbet either. it's different from say a hawaiian ice in that its not shaved ice with syrup on top - its made together then frozen and has a much smoother consistency. you have to try it! their custard is also fantastic - - - it's ultra creamy and rich, and in a gelati, it perfectly balances out the water ice. a gelati is a cup with custard on the bottom, water ice in the middle and more custard on top. my favorite is the vanilla custard with the root beer water ice. it's like a root beer float but better! i've also had the chocolate custard with banana water ice and that is great too. i really look forward to visiting the east coast in the summer and getting one of their gelatis. it's a very nice, cool

full text doc: although the revolving circular door in front is a costly bit of nonsense that i cannot fathom, mcmahons has an old school dark - paneled bar room that is a fine venue for happy hour or dinner. i have had many steaks here in the past and have never been overly impressed with their quality, but the ambience almost makes up for it. on fridays, mcmahons packs in the foothills hoi paloi with a sweet happy hour on their twinkly adobe brick patio, and rarely can so much elaine benis - style, rhythm - free body movement be witnessed in one place. the cigar selection is outrageous, and tobacco aficionados are revered here, another rarity. the old school movers and shakers certainly still shake it up at mcmahons, for better or worse.

full text doc: this is the only restaurant that i've been to that has tables on the actual sand about 100 yards from the ocean! me and my best friend had just finished hiking up to the very top of the santa ynez mountains and we were admiring how high up we were yet so close to the ocean. so we decided to eat on the beach next to the ocean so we can say we were in both places in one day. simple burgers, sandwiches, and bar but i will always come here for their bucket of steamed clams. ( not mussels ) during happy hour they sell certain appetizers for cheap, so i reccommend coming during this hour! also the burritos were surprisingly very good. don't forget to bring sunblock when you come!

full text doc: exceeded my expectations. i went in today while on the hunt for a cafe to grab lunch at, with specific food in mind of course. i got the grilled cheese, chai latte, and jewish apple cake. for $ 17, it was a little pricey, but everything was fabulous. the chai was perfect and warmed me while it was chilly and raining. lots of black pepper coming through - - i really like whatever brand of tea they used and the added cinnamon on top was awesome. the grilled cheese was really delish and came with a side salad - - perfect portions. the jewish apple cake isn't as good as my mom's but it was huge, super moist, and really quite delicious. i'll be making this a regular fall / winter stop from now on. my only critique is that it's cold and rainy today and they were serving gazpacho! looking forward to trying one of their hot soups.

full text doc: who would put pepperoni, tomatoes, and caramelized onions on a burger and call it " antique row "? the answer : a genius. this is the typical pizza place with an extensive menu. not only are there pizzas, specialty pizzas, and pastas, there are also burgers, sandwiches, and salads. this much selection is common in many pizza shops in philly / south jersey. what isn't typical about this pizza shop is the quality of food. try a couple of different slices, when you go, and you'll be very happy. really, try anything, when you go, and you'll be happy. they make the food when you order, so it's always hot when it reaches your mouth. and that, i think, is the only way to eat a pizza. the only thing that's a little strange is this : there's a little square between the steaks and the chicken sandwiches on the menu. it's hard to notice and comprehend, so i'll tell you what it says. text: his his the the the the the the the a a a a a a a a an he he for for for were were was was was was was is by in in in in to to to on expected made
full text doc: dark wood, mellow jazz, and candlelight join forces to create a warm ambiance in a large but uncluttered dining room. the menu is primarily american comfort food with a british twist. the creamy potato - leek soup was lighter than expected, as were oversized lobster ravioli in a tarragon - infused cream sauce, leaving plenty of room for tender and flavorful pepper - seared beef tenderloin with dense mashed potatoes flecked with rib meat and onions. a vegetarian special of pecan - crusted thyme pancakes with gruyere sauce and grits was both filling and satisfying. for dessert, the liquid - center chocolate cake with coffee ice cream and mint leaves and the fresh berry souffle were superb. sadly, the outstanding cuisine - in artistically - arranged presentantations - was not matched by the service. an arrogant, pretentious waiter, clad head - to - toe in black, acted as if he was doing us a favor when fulfilling any request, and made sure he took his time doing it. his disdainful attitude was enough to put a damper on the meal, and lose a star for this otherwise excellent dining spot.

full text doc: definitely a nice texas meat place. first off, the service here was amazing. everyone was very friendly, knowledgeable and cheerful. the rolls they bake fresh are very delicious ( although i didn't particularly care for the cinnamon flavored butter ). they also have roasted peanuts at every table ( and also two very large barrel - fulls of the roasted peanuts at the entrance / waiting area ). my parents really loved the peanuts and couldn't stop eating them. the price was really quite reasonable since most of the dishes come with two sides. we ordered a full rack of ribs and side orders of mashed potatoes and steak fries. the ribs were literally falling - off - the - bone delicious. the flavor and texture of the meat and bbq sauce was among the best i've had in a while. the quantity of the mashed potatoes was a bit disappointing since the size was the equivalent of a large spoonful in a small dish. also, the steak fries were only average, although they were well seasoned. it would have been much better if it little was a little more crispy on the outside. we also ordered the grilled salmon with a side of caesar salad and a sweet potato. the salad was very fresh and well flavored.

full text doc: i've been going to this record shop for over 10 years. it's a great place to find comics, vinyl, cds, etc. the staff is pretty nice and helpful. the only thing i have to complain about are the aisles of records. one person can hardly fit through, much less 2 or more. otherwise, the selection in all areas is great, the prices are pretty reasonable, and it's in a great location. the online store looks pretty cool too. all in all, i love this store. i could stay in there all day.

full text doc: to be honest, i was initially leaning towards giving drinkhaus a 3 - star rating. their coffee is good, better than starbucks, at least. their prices are a little less than what i'd be paying at starbucks too, so that's also nice. they're conveniently along my route to work and have easy parking. the space is nicely modern and smartly appointed, but ultimately is nothing too special. but, they had a few issues that kept them from reaching that 4th star. unless you're looking for biscotti or are willing to buy a $ 4 piece of quiche, the breakfast food option are limited. i just want a muffin or a bagel, or something. also, the lids on their cups are very leaky - often leaving a good amount of coffee running down my arm or in my car. i sent an e - mail to the owner about this and promptly received a response. so, the fact that the business owner is involved and handled the situation really nicely leaves me thinking that the business will work out the kinks over time - and that they deserve that 4th star. thanks, kat, for the hard work - keep it up!

full text doc: i spent a lot of time at demarco's - but that's neither here nor there. they make the best grilled veggie hoagie i've ever had. never too soggy, and packed with the vibrant flavors of broccoli rabe, garlic - soaked roasted peppers, creamy grilled eggplant, and aggressive and oily sharp provolone cheese. and portabello mushrooms, if that's your thing ( not mine ) also out of this world are any of their grilled chicken or chicken cutlet sandwiches. you know the phrase " you never know what you have until it's gone "? well, i live in alabama now and i miss places like demarco's like nobody's business. equal to and probably better than primo's - absolutely!

full text doc: i've been going to harrah's in reno for around 20 + years but this is a review of a very recent stay and an overall summary. first, never self park. you aren't going to need your car in reno anyway for the most part and giving a valet 2 bucks ( i personally give 5 but that's just me ) is the way to go unless you are leaving at a very busy time and have to wait which might be an inconvenience. don't bother calling from your room for valet to get your car since they won't do it. more importantly, when i self parked, and i have a car that isn't anything special, the window was smashed and stereo stolen twice. security is a sad joke and when i went to them each time all they said they could do was have me call reno pd to take a report. that's the bad part.... room check in was about 30 minutes at about 3pm but otherwise smooth and hassle free compared to the harrah's in vegas i reviewed awhile ago. the rooms are perfectly adequate but always get the west tower and not the east tower. i don't know the quality difference other than it being lower

full text doc: my fiance and i dined here for my birthday in july. we had been here the year before and weren't super impressed with what we got. during our first visit we ordered the big night out, which to be honest, wasn't spectacular. the main course included steak, chicken, seafood, veggies, pork, but really we only enjoyed the seafood. we were so stuffed after our main course that we hardly touched our chocolate fondue. the second time around we remembered and went a different route. we shared the artichoke cheese fondue and loved it! both of us got the seafood main course and were very happy! the best of all was the bananas foster chocolate fondue which was super yummy. this place is overpriced ( which is why it gets 4 stars instead of 5 from me. ) also, drinks here aren't very strong. you're better off going to a bar after dinner for a good cocktail. overall, i love this place. i just wish they'd lower their prices considering you cook your own main course.

full text doc: love this place! really nice people and great food - deceptively enjoyable atmosphere for a strip mall restaurant. must trys include the amazing sandwich and the tuna tataki ( a mildly spicy little pile of protein perfection )... both are so, so delicious. also like the hokkaido roll and the party bowl. tuna tartare is yummy and more spicy. have also tried the tokyo tower and special volcano and enjoyed them both. lunch specials ( bento boxes ) are a great deal also and come with a nice little salad and soup. you won't be disappointed. : ) acceptable low - or no - carb, graininess or gluten - free options here!!

full text doc: i came to lone wolf because i wanted chris oldhouser to tattoo me. i found his work online and i loved it so i made an appointment with him. i came on a sunday which was a little weird because they only had two artists working and it seemed like they weren't supposed to be open. i was the only client they had that day. anyway, since i had talked to chris many times before meeting him i felt comfortable in the shop. the other two employees were really friendly as well. they told a lot of funny stories and brought me in to the stories. i liked the vibe because it was laid back. chris started a snowflake half sleeve on me and i absolutely love it. he got a lot of work done in only 4. 5 hours. i get so compliments on my arm and i love showing it off. unfortunately, i know chris is no longer with the shop but i highly recommend him because he does such good work. i also recommend lone wolf because on a sunday they were friendly and laid back. i don't know how it is on any other day though when there are more artists.

full text doc: kinda cool, kinda strange. that's how i'd describe this venue. i just got back from the jimmy eat world show. the band rocked, but the venue itself is just weird. it is basically like someone's big backyard. i'd prefer to have the option between seats or the lawn, but for this particular concert only the lawn was utilized. as the lawn is about 1 / 50th the size of the lawn at the susquehanna bank center, which makes of a nice intimate feel. the parking situation sucks, and even though there were about 60 people working the parking, none of them knew where i send us, which resulted in us driving in a circle about 5 times. the traffic in or out wasn't a problem at all for us. i guess we got lucky! the mann's proximity to 676 makes it pretty accessible from most of the city.

full text doc: great location!! i was looking for a place 1 / 2 way between vegas and norcal. we wound up staying here for the beach location. the beach is right across the street, and it is also a hyatt hotel. we definitely took advantage of the beach while we were here. it is an older hotel, but who cares. as long as the beds are comfortable, and the staff is friendly, it's like home. they even let us check in early. the room we had had 2 queens and a flat screen. the room also has a coffee maker, microwave oven, and a mini - fridge. the pool and jacuzzi is also a nice perk. the only problem was that there was no showers or changing rooms. the hotel also has a fitness center, spa, and a business center. the hotel has a bistro which looks a little pricey, but state street ( which is the main drag ) is close by with tons of restaurants. i will be back next time for the perfect location across from the beach. btw - the parking is plenty, but there is a $ 10. 00 fee a night.

full text doc: i was looking to have my living room carpets cleaned and my couch and love seat ( which had suffered the wrath of my cats ) cleaned as well. danny was the first to contact me directly, and the price was perfect. i booked him to come out and clean my place. he was on time, represented himself well, and got right to work cleaning the areas i needed him to clean. i was extremely satisfied with the work he did, and how he kept setting very realistic expectations about what to expect as far as results. i appreciate someone who's up front about what will work and what won't. he clearly is in this for the customer and not just the money. i would hire him again when we need work done, and i would recommend him to anyone that asks.

full text doc: i've never been to new orleeeens, but dina brought me a little alligator paw on a twine necklace from this famous voodoo shop. immediately, my life went topsy turvy. car accidents, gigantic sweaty girls attacking me on the dance floor for no reason, random boys screwing up my life, parties in cleveland turning into massive riot scenes with cinder blocks and bricks flying through windows, ex boyfriends climbing out of the woodwork and having spats with one another, you name it. one day the claw disappeared. we thought it had fallen under the seat of my dad's old mercedes when it got hit by a drunken dude who ran a red light. we never found the claw and the car left my life shortly thereafter, and everything kind of settled down. so, be careful what you bring somebody from marie laveau's.

full text doc: there is only 1 word to describe this place : jumbo! i have eaten here many times as it is a close ( location wise ) favorite of a good friend of mine. i don't know why it took me so long to review this place or why it finally really hit me today that everything is jumbo, but there it is. tonight i ordered the honey bbq wings ( 10 of them! ) for a little over $ 6. i have been on a wings kick lately, and one of the other places i ordered 10 wings from was slightly more money. i thought to myself, they will probably be about the same size. nope. i did say jumbo, right? they were about 2. 5 times bigger than the wings at the other place. they also gave about 2. 5 times more bleu cheese dressing ( although fewer chunks of cheese, i will admit ). in addition, the other place forgot to give us celery, and they gave us a ton of celery, probably around 10 pieces. the wings were quite tasty with lots of sauce. because, as mentioned above, i thought the wings would be small, i also ordered a chicken salad hoagie. the price was a little over $ 5

full text doc: we are a big fan of the service and food. we called them on a saturday night with a large delivery to feed our family, and they were so fast about preparing and delivering the food. there is a $ 25 delivery fee, but i'd say the food was well worth it. we ordered the super family meal and was very impressed with both the quality and the amount of food. the chicken and ribs were amazing! just the right flavoring and char. the collard greens that we added on was also delicious and not too salty like they are up north. plantains were just right and a perfect dessert to end the meal. the only thing that could have been better is the potato salad, which was like cold mashed potatoes to me. i definitely recommend peck's!

full text doc: i've been a so - labeled " regular " here since the week they opened. this is my stop for brunch every sunday after yoga. at first all the tables were old doors that were sawed in half with a plate of glass to flatten out the topography of the door and turn it into a stable eating surface. i loved this idea! they have since switched to regular little tables but it's still charming. note : this is a very tiny place. if you have a party of more than two you might end up waiting for a table. i have been very lucky so far because there is always a table or two open when i show up, glowing from yoga and ready to chow down. i usually get the indian queen omelette which is roasted red peppers, sun - dried tomatoes, and goat cheese with home fries and a giant home - made biscuit. i have only been able to clean my plate once in the many times i've been here. the french toast is delightful and because of the apricot stuffing you don't even need syrup! delicious! this place will continue to be at the top of my brunch even after i move away from the neighborhood.

full text doc: dive bars the wide world wide, eat your freakin'hearts out ; this is the high dive. here's the best place in the big sleazy to stay a few hours and get obliterated. any hour of the the day, there is diverse ( and sometimes downright freaky ) clientelle. sometimes the tenders are grumpy / sometimes jolly, but they are always pouring generous helping of the spirits. say hi to frankie and kim for me. frankie's the evening bartender. kim's a regular ( well, so am i for that matter, so say hi to me ). boys and girls, here's the lowdown : it's as local as it gets, just a great neighborhood joint with swell company, a choice jukebox, and quite tasty bar food. uber - highly recommended!

full text doc: old school. you need to come here for steaks! on weekends, make sure you have a reservation or you will be waiting at the bar / lounge - which isn't a bad thing because there are plenty of places to sit and relax before dinner. don't eat anything else but the steaks.. the other food is like airplane food. i tried the sea kabobs once because for some reason i wasn't feeling like meat.. well.. i regretted my decision they served my plate. it was terrible. the shrimp was hard and over - seasoned, the scallops were so dry and overcooked that i could not eat them, and the " lobster tail chunks " tasted like grainy mush. i was super disappointed.. but that's what i get for choosing seafood at a place known for steaks. everyone else's food ( everyone ordered steaks ) was delicious and i kept picking at my boyfriends juicy manager's special cut steak. excellent. your steak will come with its own juice sauce and usually one onion ring so ask for extra onion rings and sauce. very flavorful.

full text doc: couldn't take another day at bread co., and i only had 10 minutes to grab a bite. food trucks have been swarming to pine and broadway, so a quick walk outside revealed the go! gyro! go! truck. i'm always down for a good gyro, so... yeah. it's way better than good. it was delish! i had the classic gyro, although they had several ( a meatball gyro, and a chicken souvlaki gyro, too ) to choose from. their greek salad looked tasty. the roasted potatoes, which came with the classic gyro for $ 7. 50, were ok - really just steak fries with some seasoning, nothing exotic. tasty enough. but the potatoes paled in comparison to the gyro. and i love that they asked if i wanted everything on it. no, i'm not a fan of parsley, and it's an option you can leave off. and they offer to do so. yay. definitely going back next time they're at our intersection. can't wait to try the rest!

full text doc: we went there mid dec on a saturday to celebrate our first marriage anniversary. it is a pricey ( $ 35 per person with 1 drink ) but a pretty nice restaurant. there is nothing about it that blows you away but it is overall it is quite good however there are small imperfections which in my mind make it pretty decent place. i could definitely go there again. most of their seating seems be outside in a covered patio ( just like a cafe would ). it was quite cold in the night however they had heaters which kept you warm enough. it was funny though seeing the girl who stands at the front door seating people... she had god knows how many layers of clothing, gloves, maybe a hat ( i might be imagining the hat ), muffler / scarf and was standing under a heater : ) i thought the food was great ; i ordered some kind of salmon which had onions, tomates and mangoes in it... really delicious and i don't even like sea food. my wife thought the food was so - so ; she had ordered some kind of chicken. service was not definitely at par with the food. the guy who served us could not answer simple questions about the wine and then was in a hurry

full text doc: while on vacation to nashville we had the opportunity to visit a variety of restaurants. clearly, monell's was our favorite, hands down. the southern food was amazingly delicious and the food just kept on coming. we were in and out of the restaurant in a quick amount of time. i never liked peas, but their pea salad was amazing. southern fried chicken was incredible. there was so much food to choose from and the price was right! course after course came to our table as we passed the bowls... to the left... and enjoyed home cooking and conversation.

full text doc: biggest waste of money ever. i got comcast cable and internet for 80 dollars a month. a lot of channels that i was supposed to get didnt work. about half the time on demand wouldn't work. if i watched tv for more than an hour the picture would do that distorted cube thing and freeze up. there was rarely a time when the cable worked without problems. the internet was very slow. after two months of service i canceled. i have had clear for about a month now and am much happier. its about the same price as comcasts cheapest internet ( $ 40 - $ 50per month ) but its much faster and you can use it anywhere in the city. instead of cable i just hook my computer up to my tv. comcast just sent me my final bill for $ 600 which i dont understand because i only had service for 2 months. i guess i'll have to call them and waste more of my time with their stupid company.

full text doc: the interior is ultra - modern and very cool. i like how the colors of the lights constantly change adding a new dimension to the experience. i went with 3 friends while we were in town for a conference and we decided to go all out. we ordered a couple of entrees. the seafood stew thing was awful and nothing special. then we went with a huge order of a sushi assortment plate. the nigiri was pretty delicious with very fresh fish. some of them i had never tried before. then we rolled with the dessert. the wasabi tiramisu was heavenly, the wasabi kicks in at the very end of each bite. nicely done. the chocolate mousse was delicious too. the desserts were probably the highlight of the evening. the sushi was great and fresh but not too inventive, i guess out in philly it might be a big deal since they don't have many sushi restaurants? they also charged far too much for supermarket quality sake.

full text doc: the name doesn't do the place justice ; it's so much more! inside is a wonderland of food and drink run seamlessly by an incredible staff. if nine credit card charges last month are any indication, it's clear i spend a lot of time here. what does dk + c have that no other downtown digs have? moxy! i usually wind up here for late night. i say hello to whatever manager is working ( that's what happens when you're there twice a week ) and grab a seat at the bar to hang out with my friend angela who also happens to make my drinks. over a south 6th or a glass of red, we talk about our days, about life, sometimes relationships, but it's never too serious and it's always uplifting. she's got a spunk about her that cracks. me. up. and the bar area itself has an appeal that's made it so friends and i start our night or wrap things up sitting in those stools at least once a weekend. we gather there because the place has a great vibe, it feels welcoming and there are always killer tunes which serve as the soundtrack to our evening. when we need a little nibble there '

full text doc: i know i've said before that i dislike restaurants that try to prepare food from enormous conglomerations of geographic areas and end up doing it all badly. so why am i giving 5 stars to a restaurant advertising " a pan latin experience "? because for once, someone seems to have nailed it. first of all, get the " carnivale " appetizer. you pay like $ 9 per person, and they bring out whatever the chef felt like making that day. for two of us, we got 5 different little appetizer things, all of which were fantastic, and were presented beautifully on a long plank covered in banana leaves. none of them seemed to correspond to specific ethnicities of food, but instead were well flavored with tropical fruits, and vibrant spices. i think that's why this place is so good, they use a mix of latin american flavors to accent creative modern dishes, instead of mangling traditional food. on to the entrees... my companion had the enchiladas, and they good, but the sides were blah. i had the cayo chicken. get this : grilled chicken, fresh pineapple, and fried onions. oh. my. god. * every * dish should come with

full text doc: block 1912 is another one of my favourite spots on whyte avenue. located in an historic building, this spacious cafe sells delicious coffee, treats, and light meals. i always try to get a comfy seat, but if none are available there are usually plenty of regular tables where one can sit, even when it gets busy on the weekend. normally, i get a small or medium coffee - - the large is so huge it looks like you could go swimming in it! i have also enjoyed an iced mocha from time to time. the specialty coffee drinks are a bit pricey - - good for a treat, but not often. same for the food - - the portions seem good, the fare contains numerous healthy choices, but it is a bit on the high side pricewise. a friend of mine had a salad here though and said it was very good. a lot of people head to block 1912 in the warmer weather for the ice cream - lots of flavours, and delicious!

full text doc: this is probably the best lowe's in indianapolis proper. although not the largest store, this store has the best and most intuitive layout. i've always been able to walk in and find what i want immediately and get to register without a unreasonable line ( because they have most registers open ). it's like this store was laid out to a handyman's instincts with logical progression from one department to the next. the help i've received here has been spot on, and there is always someone around in this store. it's as if they purposely overstaff, but as busy as this store is sometimes, maybe it is quite necessary. i've never seen a busier garden center in the summer, but they fly through flowers, push the bushes, and slang the seed. and you should also see what they can do with the legal stuff, ( jk! ) all in all, this lowe's will help you complete your project quicker.

full text doc: 4. 5 stars. as everyone before me has stated, this really is a lovely space. so i'll just get to the food : grilled baby octopus & radicchio appetizer - - very good, octopus was neat looking with a slight char. a bit chewy with a nice clean flavor. radicchio was a nice complement but some was too bitter. 4 stars. linguini w / scallop / shrimp / mussel / clam / squid - - awesome. delicious broth and pasta. tons of seafood, no skimping here! 5 stars. veal canneloni - - familar, comforting flavors. lots of gooey cheese. good but not spectacular. 3. 5 stars coconut lemon mascarpone torte - - sweet, creamy and delicious. toasted coconut gave a nice crunch. 4. 5 stars 1 appetizer + 2 meals + 1 dessert + tip came to around $ 80. i'll give it one more visit before awarding 5 stars.

full text doc: i'm not sure why people are complaining about the prices and service! this place is amazing! atmosphere : i've been to many hookah bars & yes some of the more downscale ones do charge per hookah, but omar's is : a ) on mainline, b ) more upscale, their upstairs is gorgeous with a pool table, small dance floor & deck!, & c ) the people who work here are awesome! price : ( as clearly listed on menu ) so it's $ 10 per person, $ 5 per hookah for premium flavors, & $ 5 per hookah per each extra coal, & i believe it's like $ 2 per water bottle. so for the reviewer that said she couldn't figure out the bill, here's a better break down. i did take off one star for this because the coal is genuinely over priced. i mean a pack of like 10 coals costs a few bucks, so they're certainly making too much off of that. service : it's a hookah bar. your waitress does not come up to your table every 15 minutes. people hookah to have conversations with their friends! i'd be annoyed if my waitress came by too often. however,

full text doc: small but worth the visit... i've lived in largo, florida over 25 yrs. my family visited this primate zoo a few times when i was in elem - middle school. i remember back then being so shocked at how the place was allowed to be open. the gages for the chimps were literally 5 x 5 and stacked 2 high in two rows. they had a huge brown bear in the smallest enclosure and a rather large gator in a cement enclosure so small the water was green & it could barely turn around. the resident silverback gorilla was kept in a small converted trailer and just seemed so miserable. it was heart wrenching. flash forward, i was in town visiting my sister in safety harbor and we decided to take my niece & nephew there. my sister informed me she had heard over the years that they were forced to close. after looking it up online, we were delighted to hear they had just reopened after a major remodel. upon arrival the outside had not changed very much. entrance fee was very minimal. but to my delight all the cages and enclosures were much much larger and way nicer! yes, it's not your typical " state zoo " but it's being ran by volunteers and

full text doc: this is my last'flashback from when i worked in hazelwood in 2010'post, i promise! one of my favorite places to frequent when i worked in good old noco was el coco loco. this mexican place had delicious food for a super cheap price. during my most recent visit, i was impressed with the food and the service. chips and salsa are always presented to you right away. el coco loco's chips are amazing. they're super thick, and a little warm. they almost had a slight nutty taste to them, which i adored. the salsa was pretty good, but for me, the chips were definitely the star. their lunch menu was pretty expansive, and prices were super reasonable. just about everything was less than $ 7. i ordered the huevos a la mexicana, which was comprised of two scrambled eggs mixed with bacon and pico de gallo. served with rice, beans and my choice of corn or flour tortillas, it was a hefty portion of food that could easily feed two. and i think it was right around 6 bucks, which made me happy! if el coco loco was closer to maplewood, i'd come more often. but it's just not worth the drive to north

full text doc: i can't believe i never left a review for ac4 until now. a little over 3 years ago i joined ac4 with the goal of losing 30 pounds. in 3 months of dedicating 6 - 7 days to this gym and just overall eating a little healthier or smaller portions of the unhealthier stuff, i was able to lose 35 pounds. everyone's gym goals are going to vary, wether it's losing weight, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, getting swoll, etc. but i think this gym can satisfy pretty much everyone's needs. their rates are far cheaper than any other gym in town, ( 40 - 45 $ depending on the rate you choose ) they are open 24hrs which for me was great because my schedule is always changing and i needed to be able to work out whenever i can find an hour or two in the day. it's kept very clean, even the showers and changing rooms are nice. they have tanning, hydro massage, wifi, 2 changing rooms, 2 shower rooms, 2 restrooms. the bottom floor is mostly weight machines and free weights for you swoll gym rats out there. upstairs is all cardio. bikes, treadmills, stair climber etc
