full text doc: excellent food and beer, better than your average welsh pub. on a good night, you may be able to cajole john into reciting one of his poems for you. no kidding, he's won some prestigious awards for his poetry. as for me, i jut love their fresh - fried thick - skin potato chips, guiness, harps, or double dragon on tap, and the load of characters i've met there. one old dude would lecture me every week on ezra pound's critique of the wasteland ( this is t. s. elliot's'hood you know ). i've also met a number of artists who call it their home. their shepherd's pie is pretty good, although not quite as substantial as llywellyn's, while their beef stew rivals any i've had anywhere. head to the pub above ( upstairs ) after you eat for a scotch and cigar. they carry cardhu ( my personal fave ).

full text doc: my favorite record store in or near philadelphia. this place is huge and they offer a great vinyl section ( in the back ). any place that offers vinyl records in an environment that doesn't wreak of 1972 is a - okay in my book. most new releases are in stock and they offer a good selection of used at great prices. i know, from experience, this place can get any special orders in within two days - which is great for a collector. they were able to order me a special edition vinyl from the uk and i had it in my hands within a few days. the owner of this place is a lifetime record store junkie ( who happens to hang out at honey's on the weekend ). although he's not the most approachable person you will ever meet, he knows a lot about great music - this place is always playing something worth listening to!

full text doc: well. where do i start. the company we went with was the highlight of the evening. that says a lot. the food was good. but that's all. for the price it was a disappointment. let me explain. they couldn't handle our friends'dietary restrictions, i. e. bringing a plate of mussels with bread on top that had been expressly requested not be there for the gluten allergic person and the sushi roll with cream cheese that wasn't on the menu description that went to the milk sensitive person. my wife's lobster was good, but for $ 52 ( $ 56 if you wanted it spicy ) it should have had some side dish. anything really. i had the grouper which was good, but overdone. sides of grits and greens were pedestrian. we drank a bottle of wine with dinner, but again, this was a short - coming. selections were few and overpriced and ours was merely ok, though probably the best on the limited menu. portions were quite small. i'm all for " smaller " portions to help me keep my girlish figger, but this was about 50 % less than what i consider small. overall, it was only ok.

full text doc: cruising through no for a couple days, i only had a few chances to get some good food, and boy am i glad i chose bennachin. i met up with two friends who came here the day before, and needed to come back again because it was so good. i honestly didn't know what to expect, being that i had never eaten traditional african food before. god.. this place is awesome. i was full, but i didn't feel heavy, and my taste buds were tickling. i got their ginger drink, which actually kind of burned as i drank it, but it was still good. if i'm ever back in no, i'm definitely making a stop at this place. i actually passed up eating at an expensive gourmet restaurant to eat here and i couldn't have been happier with my choice. not only that, but the waiter we had was super nice too! i should also add that i'm not vegetarian, but i did end up getting a veggie dish that, again, did not disappoint.

full text doc: another great patio place in st. louis! this patio is not as massive as others, but it's a nice quiet spot in downtown kirkwood. the inside of the restaurant / bar itself is dark with many tables. it even has a back room for those with little ones. i always try to separate myself and my kids from those without kids for everyone's enjoyment. the menu here is mostly burgers and sandwiches, but they have toasted ravioli as an appetizer as well as good chicken quesadillas. this is definitely a hangout for an older crowd. not a good spot if you're looking for some action!

full text doc: wow - i can't believe i've waited this long to yelp square on square. i have eaten here many times - mainly for lunch as they do a filling, mid - priced lunch special. the hot & sour soup here is some of the best ever. really. 5 stars for the h & s soup. we also had a large group party here in february 2008. they offered a set meal with soup, appetizer choice of 6 entrees and dessert. it was very well organized and our group of over 30 people left well - fed and happy. the manager, steven, is very nice and easy to work with. the only detractors here ( preventing the 5 star rating ) is the extremely long lines at lunch time. ( don't come at 12 : 30 on a tursday of friday ) also the decor is in need of refreshment. kinda grungy. don't miss the mango chicken and filet mignon - really tender and nice here.

full text doc: this review is based soley on customer service as i will not be staying at the hotel. still, if you are thinking of booking - read entire review. i had reservations for this weekend. very impressed that a few days ago rob, the concierge called and offered to arrange tours, restaurants, etc. the day before my planned trip urgent professional obligations popped up. i had to cancel. it was only after i cancelled my air reservations that i realized there was a 72 hour requirement on my reservation otherwise it is non - refundable. i called the front desk ; a lovely women answered and i asked if i could commit to another stay right then would they not penalize me ; she checked w / that hotel's accounting and they said that if hilton corp would allow it they are fine. by then end of this entire issue i learned that this hotel is not corporate owned. they receive their money only after the guest stay so the pre - pay goes to corporate. as a hilton diamond member, i called their desk. i understand rules are rules. they held firm. in the back of my mind i wondered why i did not note the 72 hour cancellation as i am quite organized. this morning i re - booked my trip with southwest for march then

full text doc: sherwood did an amazing job on the flowers for our wedding. tracy went above and beyond to make sure that everything fit my vision and my budget. we got our bouquets, boutonnieres, centerpiece flowers, and a beautiful set of double doors topped with rustic flowers and succulents which was just stunning in the background of our pictures and behind us during our ceremony. my bouquet was absolutely breathtaking, even more beautiful then i pictured it. i can't recommend them enough!!!

full text doc: i feel that i might be committing sacrilege by saying i wasn't all that incredibly impressed with tony luke's... but there, i said it. i'm not saying that i prefer pat's or geno's ( really, i'm not, because the added touristy kitsch doesn't make for a better sandwich. ) after waiting in a line that went past the end of the building, i got my chicken cheese steak, sat down at one of the covered outdoor tables ( which we had to fight for ) and... just... wasn't that crazy about the sandwich. the meat is sliced rather than chopped, so the cheese didn't have much to stick to and it all oozed out one end when i tried to pick the sandwich up and eat it. there were college kids in ivy - league t - shirts at the table next to us proudly taking pictures of them with their tony luke sandwiches, and i really just don't see what the hype is all about. the meat wasn't terribly tender, the cheese kept leaking out, and there was way more bread than there was meat to go with it. i've definitely had far worse cheese steaks

full text doc: this is a nice little intimate venue. great place to see a show up close and personal. it is * extremely * small. if there is a lot of people, expect to be stomped on. this is not a place to wear open toe shoes - - you will lose those toes. it's a little annoying that if you're under 21 they won't even allow you to walk * through * the bar area ( the whole building ) to get to the stage / dance floor, you have to trot up the stairs and around the building and come down at the stage. i expect it isn't really their fault though - - legal obligations and what not. there is precisely zero parking specifically for this club. you have a couple of options : there is city parking lots that have something like a $ 13 or so maximum, or you can find nearby street parking in the residential areas surrounding state street. in the middle of the day during a farmers market i was able to find street parking a quarter mile from state street without even trying - - i just danced around a couple of blocks and happened to notice an unrestricted street with some spots. overall, i enjoyed my time there.

full text doc: my favorite place to get smoothie bowl. you get your money's worth because the bowls are large and filled with ample amounts of fruit and other toppings compared to other places i've tried. my favorite bowl is their pitaya bowl! you should definitely also try their pitaya smoothie. my. favorite. smoothie. of. all. time. service is quick and nice! be sure to get a stamp card too - 10 stamps equals a free bowl! i would suggest that they have a stamp program for smoothies or other items in stores too.

full text doc: i attend eos lounge once every weekend and it is always the highlight of my weekend. the new and improved layout is extremely appealing to the eye upon entry of the lounge. the dj's are always on point creating the best atmosphere to have the most fun. i usually uber there already drunk but am always sure to hit the bar at the lounge due to the excellent service they provide ; there are tons of exciting drinks to choose from and they are never skimpy on the alcohol. over all i can proudly say eos is the number one club in santa barbara.

full text doc: i usually end up in this particular canadian tire store most often and this single review will represent my opinion of the entire chain. they pretty much have the same layout and product lines. however, i have seen some neat variations. for example, the larger store in whitehorse has a " zamboni " floor cleaner and i saw the manager travelling around the store on a sedgeway! canadian tire is a national chain that sells tires ( duh! ), garden supplies, housewares, tools, sporting goods and lots of stuff in between. i'm not sure whether there's a us equivalent. the other neat thing these guys do is give you canadian tire money if you purchase in cash. it's as good as money and the paper itself seems to be of higher quality that us or canadian currency. i enjoy just poking around the store and seeing what they have. often times, i'm come out with a tool or garden - related purchase that i'll haul back to california with me. chances are they carry it back home, but who cares when you're having such a great retail therapy experience!

full text doc: love everything about this place! the food, the environment, the drinks, the staff - its all top of the line! we have gone here twice now and are huge fans! everything we have tried is good ( and we tried a lot of stuff ) and the food portions are ridiculously huge! its also a little pricer - but you definitely get your monies worth. i recommend trying the greek beer " mythos " if you haven't tried any greek beers before - its very delicious! a dinner at santorini pretty much guarantees you will be leaving very full and very happy! totally recommend!

full text doc: union jacks is the best bar in manayunk, and one of my favorite bars in the city to just go and knock back a couple of beers. they have one of the best draught lists i've ever seen - it is continually changing but there is always something new and interesting on there. their bottle list is equally impressive. i've only ever had the burgers and wings at uj, because that's all i've ever wanted to order. they have about a dozen different sauces for the wings, and most of them are good. the honey carribean wings are out of this world. the burgers are juicy and also come in many different varieties. the service at uj is pretty good. usually it is just the 2 bartenders, so on a busy night it can be a little slow but i don't blame them for that. i've found the bartenders to be pretty knowledgeable about the beer they serve, so feel free to ask for suggestions if you're stuck. keep in mind that they don't accept credit cards, although they do have an atm on - site.

full text doc: kooma tries very hard to bring a hip, urban sushi house vibe to west chester, and in many respects it succeeds. the ambiance is stylish, and the place is noisy and crowded. you can also expect a lengthy wait for any sushi ordered on a weekend ( my wait was an hour ). the sushi is very fresh, but i honestly found it good but not great. fresh fish does not necessarily equal great tasting sushi. my wife ordered some of the non - sushi ( almond beef ), and it was very sub - par. the beef was shaved thin, overcooked and with poor flavor. it was easily the worst asian beef dish i have ever had.

full text doc: i happen to live near two different rouses. this location is definitely the better of the two. while both stores have the same sales ( pick 5 deal on the meat! ), the clearview rouses has a little bit of a better selection. the extra selection of ramen noodles ( including some " premium " ones ) appeals to the bachelor in me. the expanded salad bar and hot plate lunches speak to the lazy cook in me. while rouses may not have the specialized selection of whole foods or the old metairie charm of dorignac's, but the prices are certainly better on my budget.

full text doc: stopped by for sushi in the middle of a long drive. i guess it's supposed to be an upscale place, but it gives the feeling of a chain / franchise restaurant ( maybe it is, and i just don't know! ). in fact, that's why i stopped there. i wanted to find a non - fast food place for dinner, and i just wasn't in the mood for olive garden or red lobster, which were practically next door. why do i say " chain "? i guess it has to do with the appearance of the menu and how you're served. for example, someone other than your waiter / waitress usually brings you your food at olive garden, and the same is true at potstickers. the prices are way high for what you're getting. i ordered 3 sushi rolls ( 2 regular rolls, one special roll ). this came to $ 33 including hot tea and tip. at most japanese restaurants, hot tea and miso soup are complimentary when you order sushi. not so here. the rolls were good, but i wouldn't say they were outstanding. oh, and they charge extra for tobiko on the california rolls ( really??!! ). i

full text doc: i have been going through the homebuying process and on the first house i had my home inspector as well as 2 roofing companies come out to inspect the quality of the roof. the first company indicated the roof ( a flat built up type of roof ) would need almost full replacement $ 6000 + since there were multiple " soft " spots on it. roofsavers came out and gave me an estimate for approx $ 800 and only for repairs that i was expecting... not an unnecessary full roof replacement. however - before any roof inspections, my home inspector is very knowledgable indicated what did need to be addressed ( which roofsavers independantly recommended ) and also warned me about the " soft " spots which were in fact not damaged areas, but the properties of the roof material that was not designed to be load bearing ( of a 150lb + person ) in particular areas. based on a variety of inspection issues, i did not buy that house. the next house, when going through the inspection process, roofsavers gave just as honest and straight forward inspection report. i have not needed them for repairs yet, but the honesty in their estimates / inspections would lead me to trust them in their repairs as well.

full text doc: after reading about this place in the paper and then seeing it on food network i thought i would give it a shot. hole in the wall on girard ave. not much to the inside, a couple of stools up at a bar ( no beer, no booze ), majority of those in the shop on a saturday afternoon ordered take out. strange dynamic with the staff. they seemed to have one guy making cold sandwiches and dealing with the money, another guy cooking hot food, taking orders and hazing a guy in the back room. after wanting to order 1 of everything on the menu, i ordered the paesano. with the exception of the size, the sandwich was out of this world. the size was 1 / 3 of a loaf of sarcone's bread. it was about 2 to 3 inches smaller than the " primo " size hoagie. as i said the sandwich was fantastic, the only downside was i could have eaten five ( 5 ) of them.

full text doc: 12. 99 all you can eat lunch? insane. the quality of the sushi here is comparable to kampai, and the service is warm and attentive. the price is right on point. this would be a great place go for lunch if you're downtown, as you can take advantage of their lunch specials. i wouldn't suggest this place for anything particularly romantic, as the space is a bit overwhelming ( feels hollow, probably rarely filled to capacity ). so, the ambiance is slightly lacking. but the food is good - the sushi won't astound you with the creativity or anything, but it's definitely good. the 17. 99 dinner deal is a steal : 4 pieces of nigiri, 3 rolls, and an appetizer ( they even threw in a miso soup! ). ultimately, my prognosis is : go here if you want a feast on a budget!

full text doc: ok, maybe i am biased - because not only am i a patient, but i used to work for dr. snyder waaaaaaaay back when. she is always at the forefront of cosmetic and restorative dental procedures. she just does damned good denistry. the office environment is clean, state - of - the - art and at the same time, warm & welcoming. her staff is helpful and friendly. i have since moved away - bt anytime i am in doylestown and need a cleaning - i go see dr. snyder and her hygienist. it's a terrific practice that i endorse most highly.

text: taqueria ) tables tables center skylight ( seats panoply nicer trendy room salsas tad well seating evening the the the the variety s s s but spots window ' ' '
full text doc: this place is so cute! there seems to be relatively few spots open for when you're looking last minute to go out to eat a nicer dinner at 9 : 30pm on a wednesday evening. however, mission taqueria pulled through, with its delicious panoply of salsas and unique tacos! the decor is also a tasteful mix of trendy yet relaxed, and they have a wide variety of different seating arrangements ( booths, long tables, small tables, window seats, etc ). there's also a cute intimate upstairs courtyard / skylight room in the center of the restaurant if you wanna take a break to go outside and look up into the night sky. it's just a tad bit pricey for what you get, but hey, it's well worth a trip!

full text doc: after reading they had one of the best philly's in st. louis we decided to give them a try. we went on a saturday afternoon and after ordering we had to wait over half an hour to receive our food. that is way too long for a deli if you ask me. i will also say that the ordering experience was a little confusing as first timers. we didn't see the chips next to the counter and didn't realize we were supposed to grab them when we ordered our food, and nothing was mentioned about it. on to the food. if you like your philly's with cheese whiz, you will love this philly. i thought it was very good. however, my husband likes the other type of philly that uses " real " cheese. so, between the two of us it was a toss up on the food. i would go back, but i know my husband will not, mainly due to the wait.

full text doc: i've only ever been to monell's on sunday for brunch, but man - oh - man if that is a good representation of how they do up their meals there, count me in for every day. my goodness. i am still stuffed from last time i went, a few months ago before i moved to los angeles. it's $ 14 for ayce soul / southern fare, served family style at giant tables like back at grandma's place. the restaurant certainly _ feels _ like her place. there's a huge garden pavilion outside, and a comfortable den feeling inside. you could show up alone or with three other people, and end up sharing the meal with a few hungry strangers, and when everyone starts asking to " pass the _ _ _ _, please, " you instantly feel like a distant family sharing a reunion meal together. there's nothing quite like this place. everything is delicious and served at the most perfect time! they start you off with just drinks and biscuits and vegetables and side dishes, then serve up the main course ( usually a few different selections of meat ; pork chops, fried chicken, ribs, etc. ). it's so well - timed that your hunger pangs fade away at

full text doc: cafe desta is a charming eatery in a section of tucson that sorely lacks restaurant variety. my friends live in the neighborhood and see cafe desta as an oasis. i've been for lunch several times and dinner once and have always been extremely satisfied. the food is vibrant and tasty and makes for great photo opps - if you like photographing your food, and what yelper doesn't? the lamb is especially mouth watering but if you don't eat meat there are a number of vegan / vegeterain options. the restaurant has a very personal feel since the owners - a couple - are always there and are warm and eager to please. there's even a mini art gallery of brooke's paintings.

full text doc: located in the armpit of the interbelt, its location sucks but the store is pretty great. the store is one of the better that i've seen, it has a pretty wide selection and lots of well - made food for those of us too lazy to cook for themselves. but they also have that spectacular tasting table which puts this place on my " gettin'my poverty on " list. of course, consuming a full meal on these babies is rude and obnoxious, but a couple of stop - bys while you're shopping will not only curb your appetite for free... it's expected.

full text doc: i like mcallister's. like it, don't love it. i unfairly compare them to jason's deli, and they come up short. the offerings are pretty plentiful, sandwiches of all varieties, salads and sides. an added bonus is their stuffed spuds which are large baked potatoes with " fixings ". during my last visit i brought my dad along and he ordered one, unfortunately it wasn't as stuffed as one would expect by the description, but he said it tasted great. i have had the french dip and a few of the sides, all were delicious. their portions aren't as big as jason's but their prices reflect that for the most part. the environment is kitschy, which is my nice way of saying tacky. it reminds me of someone's grandmother's house in the early 80's, all of it very flowerly and dated. but i believe that is what they were going for..... service at this location is always prompt and very friendly. again, i like it and will definitely return for convenience, but it isn't a true deli experience in my mind in terms of freshness and portion size.

full text doc: i went discovered this place based on a recommendation from another bar tender, otherwise i never would have found it. more than anything, i was pissed off that i haven't known about this place since it opened. the space is unbelievable and watching the mixologists in action was quite a performance. one of the bartenders made my friend a drink ( we promised not to tell the name of it ) that it took 5 bartenders 15 minutes to make. they had to change the music to get themselves pumped up about the kind of shaking that was about to go down. the result - the most unbelievable cocktail i've ever experienced.

full text doc: i am a big fan of olive garden but this location is just alright.. the parking is really hard to come by and they don't take reservations so your best bet is to do call ahead seating right before you leave your home to get there. we ordered the spinach and artichoke dip ( excellent! ), the choose your own appetizer ( 2 items for 8. 50 deal ) with fried ravioli ( not good whatsoever ) and calamari with peppercorn sauce and marinara ( wow wow wow i love it! ). for dinner we had the chicken scampi which was angel hair pasta with a really watery bland garlic sauce.. i did not enjoy this at all! the one thing that never fails me at og is their peach bellini iced tea.. i could drink that by the gallons it's so tastyyy [ : for dessert we got the black tie cake and it was so chocolately and yummy! it's too bad i don't like this location though..

full text doc: joe's cafe is a must when in downtown santa barbara! it offers a fun atmosphere and great food! their menu has plenty of options and is great for lunch or dinner. first time i went i had the french dip sandwich. since then i have also had the fish & chips and bbq pork sandwich. all have been outstanding in freshness and taste! the one flaw in the times i have been there has been the service. it sometimes took a while for our drinks to be refilled or for the server to check up on us. i have been there when it is crowded and also when it is not and the level of service seems to be the same. but regardless, joe's cafe is definitely worthy of stopping in!

full text doc: since i quit the gym, i spend more time with kelly drive than i do with most of my friends. in the winter, it is a quiet, solitary stretch that is always well - lit and ( if you have a dog, or a friend with you ) feels pretty safe. the rest of the year is is great for people watching and enjoying the river. where else in the city ( or in many cities for that matter ) can you run more than 8 miles and never have to worry about cars? i had taken one star off because i hate the springtime regattas, but upon reading everyone else's reviews i remembered the whole rest of the park and had to put the star back on. hikes in the wissahickon? yes, please. smith playground... who knew? lemon hill, the ball fields near strawberry mansion, spraygrounds, the horticulture center... i love you, fairmount park....

full text doc: this was probably one of the best craft beer and food festivals i've been to in indy. ( thanks to yelp for sending me there with a buddy to enjoy! ) although event parking was $ 10 in the lot or at white river state park, we managed to park at the circle center garage and snake our way through the indiana convention center ( never know when it randomly decides to rain here... ). $ 2 for a 3 hour event. not to mention a good way to burn off the beer / bacon belly afterwards. victory field was an awesome venue to host this event. ample walking space, picnic tables, cup holders, standing bar type counters, and limitless stadium seating to enjoy my booze and bites. numerous brewery reps were located along the entrance all the way around to the exit, making it a nice circle to make sure you didn't miss anything yummy. i have to give a shout - out to upland in the concessions stand for the best seasonal release and most enthusiastic server ever. a 3 oz. pour of barrel chested barleywine aged in bourbon barrels at a whopping 9. 5 % abv. i should've gone back to get seconds! totally a quick way to get a buzz. another unique

full text doc: try the buri - bop, it's mind blowing. this place is dee - lish ( what else could you expect from the iron chef? ) and the decor is funky fresh yo ( think brave new worldesque dining ). my fave is the centerpiece at each table which not - so - vaguely look like glowing vibrators... a great conversation piece during any meal. pricey place so be sure to go with a thick wallet.

full text doc: this is a comfortable mid - city bar with a basic dive feel. the bartenders rock, and won ; t shy away from conversation. plenty of live music ( most nights ) fills the bar, so if there's a band you won't be able to converse. a bit dirty and not well - lit, banks street doesn't try that hard and doesn't expect you to. really friendly place.

full text doc: i really love this end of the city, where people still live like my parents did in the fifties and corner bakeries like this still get by. little ol'holmesburg bakery is sooooo tiny and insignificant - seeming compared to those great - big super bakeries that they have in all the super freshes now, but you need only try one of their butter cakes to understand how this place stays in business, for they are deliciously imperfect, buttery and terrible for you. they have a pretty nice collection of cookies and cake offerings, some fancy, some with that baked - at - home look. i'd suggest going with the latter. i definitely don't bake myself, so holmesburg is the closest i get to that old feeling of taking a baking sheet out of the oven and grabbing something delightful.

full text doc: i don't love b & bs. but hubby does and sometimes i have to do what he wants. : ) the simpson house is pretty. victorian decor and beautiful gardens. the staff has always been pleasant. we came here once over the holidays and the house was decorated so pretty. the rooms in the main house can be small as in most b & bs. we have stayed in the " carriage houses " in the back. they are disconnected from the main house. they are gorgeous and i prefer them any day ( of course, since they are the most $ $ $ $ ). do you like free food? well, here they lay out some pretty tasty hors appetizers each evening. cookies before bed. breakfast was plentiful yet pretty heavy for me. hubby loved it all. romantic, if you don't mind seeing other people being romantic pretty much all around you. great location, walking distance to downtown.

full text doc: i travel back and forth from philly to dc and i found this place when i got a flat. a little lackluster, but read on and fine out why that doesn't matter! greg, was such a help. he explained to me everything i needed to know about buying tires. tread, sizes, names, etc. after he was done pointing out the tires he told me to try pricing elsewhere without showing the number he gave me. he had them all substantially beat. one shop said show me your lowest offer and i will match it. i showed him and i was called a liar. then i went to greg who fixed me up and then he told me that they were running a special where i get free flat fixes if brought in to them for the life of the tire. haven't had to use it yet but with the money i saved, i don't mind paying the $ 10 bucks for the flat! way to go airport discount tire & auto. i wish you had shirts i would buy one. i am always there looking for them while i am getting some cheap ass gas for cash!

full text doc: this was the 2nd time we went, lat time the place was packed and while the food was good it wasn't " amazing. " this time around there was hardly anybody there so we got a lot of attention from our server. we had a " meal for two " so the overall price was very good. the st louis ribs were excellent, brisket flavorful, corn bread was sweet and slightly crispy on the edges... so just right! in fact the whole meal was great. more than enough for even me ( a voracious appetite ) so we had leftovers. the atmosphere is awesome too, very much like a hunter's cottage. better than dickies for sure. overall an excellent value and the food is better now than when they first opened.

full text doc: my fabulous byo girls took me to salt & pepper for an early birthday dinner over the weekend. they didn't realize that s & p's move to passyunk also came with a liquor license, so they brought wine along and agreed to pay the $ 10 / bottle corkage fee. we started with the three apps that were a special that night. one was a spicy tuna tartar with a strong wasabi flavor and some crackery crisps for scooping. the next was a goat cheese and pesto flatbread pizza and the third was a plate of fried plantains with sardines. that one was definitely very different but the plantains were spicy and savory. we were loving on all three of the starters and were excited for the mains. we waited. and waited. and waited some more. two bottles of wine were killed before our entrees made their appearance. i'm all for pacing and i enjoy a leisurely dinner, but at one point, i think we were all wondering if the chef had to run to the grocery for something. there were only about three tables occupied in the restaurant. finally, the entrees arrived. my friends who ordered lamb chops were thrilled, and my other friend

full text doc: my daughter was referred here by our pediatrician. the office staff was very helpful and worked hard to get us in quickly. our first assessment visit was informative and surgery was scheduled. she had a lump surgically removed. dr. mahoney was very thorough and kept my daughter calm and relaxed throughout the entire procedure. he explained to me everything he was doing as he worked. his nurse was also very competent and engaging. both are witty, friendly, and professional. a follow up call was made the day after to check in on her. i'm going to switch our entire family to this practice!

full text doc: one of the nicest hotels in metro indy, the renaissance indianapolis north opened for business in the summer of 2008. this is a boutique hotel with bold colors, modern designs and great amenities. like all renaissance hotels, the carmel location is decorated around a local theme, in this case carmel's arts and design district. in addition to 263 beautifully appointed guest rooms, this hotel boasts an inviting " street feel " restaurant and bar area that serves up some delicious and innovative cuisine as well as 15, 000 square feet of meeting space, a 24 - hr fitness center, indoor pool and upgraded club level rooms and club lounge with concierge. one caveat : the renaissance is a bit of a drive from the indy airport and the downtown area, so plan accordingly. this is good bet if your business is along the northern corridor of the city.

full text doc: used the park and fly for 8 days and stayed one night. our car was broken into and we we robbed while we were away. someone used a screwdriver and pushed it in below the driver door and poked a hole in the driver door to pop the lock. very expensive to repair the door. the things that were stolen can be replaced but the damage to the car is really bad. i am lucky it was still there. hotel is in an office park and very isolated. conveniently located but not safe!!! the hotel staff did nothing and wanted nothing to do with the problem and advised us to call police. they didnt even want to stay until the police came. it was 2am and raining when we arrived after long delays at the airport. the shuttle service was slow. the hotel front desk people were friendly. the room was as expected for the cost reasonably clean and comfortable. we will never stay here again!!!

full text doc: i love this place! it's very clean, friendly, and professional, and i would recommend it to anyone seeking a vet in the main line area. i was referred here by a friend who grew up in the area after i had horrible experiences with bryn mawr veterinary ( see review for details ). no such problems here. even if you call with a question, the staffers will hunt down a vet to find out the answer for you. if the vet said she'd call you back, you get a call from the vet herself ( who is patient and completely willing to answer all your questions until you're satisfied ). if you need to pick up food or medication and are running late, they'll try their best to accommodate you, even staying late ( obviously, don't push this one ). they even mailed refills of medications without an extra shipping charge. dr. maria peters is the vet that my dog and i saw - - she clearly loves animals and did a great job of being caring toward both pet and owner. she completely solved my dog's diarrhea problem in a cost - conscious way, fully explaining the different options ( treating the symptoms vs. conducting testing to pinpoint the cause ) and the

full text doc: rustic vibes just a few miles east of main street, possible'cause e'ville is still a small city. as you approach, keep an eye out for the white andria's sign beside a wooded driveway on the north side of il - 143. the drive leads back about 100 yards to a converted ranch home. the pub entrance nearest the south lot takes you into the lounge ( fine place for a first - class steak burger and drink ) ; the front door leads directly into one of the dining rooms. the appearance of the building won't impress you, and you may wonder whether you've made the right choice. carnivores, take courage and walk inside, because behind those unpretentious walls you are going to find really good meat. i've ordered or shared beef, lamb, and pork. all were excellent! drinks are reasonably priced : well drinks in the $ 4 range, wines by the glass $ 4 - $ 6, house wine carafes less than $ 20, and bottles moving up in price from there. they can do gluten - free, but you may have to ask a few questions about ingredients. p. s. : often male diners wear a sportcoat, and female diners

full text doc: st. louis has some seriously good places to eat, but i'm going to go out on a limb and say that sportsman's park ( formerly known as jackie's place, for those of you who are truly old school ) is the best. i think i like it so much because it remains unchanged, and i should know because i've been going to sportsman's since i was in diapers ( when the st. louis cardinals memorabilia was both baseball and football... boo - yah ). the service is consistent, friendly, and fast. enough said. but the food, oh how i crave the food. yes, its just bar food, but boy is it tasty! love the toasted ravs. love the ty cobb salad. love the bison or turkey burger with a side of the seasoned curly fries or housemade vinegar slaw. club sandwich and wraps are good, too. but seriously, have you ever had a more tasty buffalo chicken? ( i leave that kind of open - ended because you can get wings, tenders, etc. ) omg, i'm salivating thinking about it now. can't wait until my next trip down to st. louis... sportsman '

full text doc: great casual place to meet friends for a few drinks and some good food. the atmosphere is beachy - fun ( similar to islands in california ) and the noise level is tolerable. we started off with the blackbeard shrimp ( blackened shrimp served on bread with a very tasty dipping sauce ) and it was excellent. i had the cheeseburger in paradise and my dining partner had a burger with jalapenos and cheese. both were cooked excellent and tasted awesome. i had the french fries with a side of ranch and she had the sweet potato chips. we were there during happy hour and mojitos were half price so we tried the regular, the blackberry, the pomegranite and the pinapple. all were tasty but the pomegranite and pinapple were our favorites. to round out the evening she had the jamaica apple crisp and i had key lime pie. both were excellent.

full text doc: this is a very nice, neighborhood place for homestyle food and good service by very personable people. you can't help but feel comfortable here, thanks to the atmosphere and the welcome you receive upon arrival. although the service is fast, you don't feel rushed at all. candice b was our server, and she was a pleasure from start to finish. my wife ordered the country & eggs, which was a large tender portion of country fried steak topped with sausage gravy along with two eggs. i had the stuffed breakfast, that consisted of two slices of french toast with apricot preserves and cream cheese, two eggs and i chose ham amongst the sides included. we loved it all! everything was fresh, tasty, prepared with care and the portions are big! very nicely done from all angles!

full text doc: central grocery has exactly one item on its menu - a muffaletta. signs throughout this small italian grocery store declare that this the place where it was born, a claim shared about a half dozen other establishments in the french quarter, but i'm willing to state the one served here is the best. a huge sandwich consisting of salami, ham, cheese, and olive salad on a round roll, closer to the size of a small loaf of bread, it's so big that four people can easily share a whole one. what sets this above the others in town is the terrific olive salad, perfectly seasoned and dripping with oil, so grab a very large fistful of paper napkins before you take your first bite.

full text doc: if my cat was still alive i'd be afraid to add another 5 star review here, for fear that it would get too busy at companion care to get an appointment. sadly, my little guy was already near death with advanced diabetes ( which he somehow managed to hide for a very long time, as cats will do ) when i first got him in here ( acting on the advice of another well - reputed vet who couldn't see him that day ). dr. majeska and her staff were fantastic, from explaining what was wrong with my cat, to options for treatment. he ended up in a critical care facility that stabilized him, and on to a regimen of treatment. dr. majeska and genevieve were very patient with my questions and thorough in setting me up to handle my end of the ongoing treatment. they were quick to respond to my emails and to set up appointments as needed during critical moments. my little guy's passing was due to my own ignorance, for not recognizing his illness early on, and assuming it was just " old age. " although the treatment couldn't save him in the end, it bought me a precious month of his company, and ended on a sweet note when he finally passed, very comfortably, in

full text doc: smak parlour is a really cute little women's clothing boutique at 2nd and market in olde city. the store is clean, brightly lit, and has interesting displays. the clothes are also super cute, and some of the outfits reminded me of something a hip pan am flight attendant would have worn back in the early 1960's. they've got colorful dresses, shirts, tunics, accessories, etc. some of the accessories are particularly cool, like the barbie shoe earrings and the shoes. i also think that the clothes are made by local designers - they've got fabric bolsters, etc. in the back that led me to believe that the clothes are made there. the prices are also pretty reasonable. check it out.

full text doc: * 3. 5 stars * i ordered take out from this place because they offer it and it was literally so packed there was not a single seat available. anyway, this place is only 2. 5 miles away ( i. e. 5 - 7 minutes or less ) so i decided taking the sushi home would not be too bad. it took a bit longer than i expected and i was sort of awkwardly standing there waiting for my sushi for what seemed like awhile. now, i previously gave this place 5 stars, but i am deducting 1. 5 because the service was not that great for me this time and i was not all that excited about the sushi. it was not bad it was just not quite on point. i ordered the tuna and tuna roll and the metairie roll. both were much messier looking than i expected, like they were made in in a hurry and tossed in the box. consistency is important for me and there is some inconstancy going on here. that being said, there are a lot of other rolls i have not had yet. also the sashimi is cut thick which is nice and the seafood always tastes fresh. i will definitely give them another shot, maybe this was just a weird occurrence,

full text doc: best mom - and - pop place in the area. the zeps are incredible - just don't get fooled into a large - they are enormous, stacked high with fresh cut onions and tomatoes, along with hot peppers on the tables. the breakfast is out of the this world - especially the sandwiches - just ask them to put them on long rolls for a better fit. lou's is an institution, it is old school, everyone knows each other, and the word diet does not coincide with the place - but don't be scared away if you've never been - they will treat you like family. enjoy!

full text doc: took my gf here for her birthday with high expectations and they delivered. the food and service is fantastic, the ambiance is nice and romantic. we pretty much stuck to anything seafood and our server insisted that the crossing tries to distinguish itself from other establishments based on the quality of their seafood and i'd have to say i agree. everything we ordered was great ; maryland lumb crab cake, tuna crudo, scallop entree, tuna steak entree and then shared the raspberry sorbet which was honestly insane. they were extremely accommodating to a lactose intolerant diner and went out of their way to make sure the night went very well. you won't be dissapointed by the crossing.

full text doc: alright : this is the best studio in town, but don't take my word for it. this year, they were voted as such by the good people of reno in the r & r, for the 6th year in a row. they're good. there are so many things that will keep me coming back. the teachers are amazing ( angie fraley's class is inspiring and life changing in ways i don't know how to encapsulate in a yelp review ). she almost always incorporates a mental practice or theme in addition to the physical rigor : working with the mind and body. a couple of tips for her classes : arrive early ( spots fill up quickly ), and drink a ton of water during the 24 hours or so before. the space is relaxing and welcoming. the vinyasa ( and non - bikram ) style hot yoga classes are challenging and approachable and will make you sweat in puddles and sleep like a baby that night. every teacher i've taken a class from at the studio is experienced, kind, and promotes a philosophy of self - love and nonjudgment. they all seem to agree : if it hurts don't do it! be nice to yourself. find your

full text doc: went to high street while in philly for brunch because it was on eater 38 and it was solid. they have a few outdoor seats and we snagged a table to enjoy the weather. service was good at first but then got a bit slow at the end because i think our server started to get overwhelmed. they have a few options for breakfast ; two toast options, some salads and some sandwiches. it is definitely a healthy eating hipster kind of place. in true hipster fashion i got an avocado toast and a salad. my husband got the pork sandwich. the avocado toast was really good and was topped with a roasted garlic oil with large chunks of garlic. the bread soaked up the oil and while that may not be the healthiest, it was delicious! i was deciding between the roasted broccoli salad and the greens salad. i chose the greens because it came with shaved cauliflower and rye chips. when i got it i saw that it also came with chickpeas and petal couscous. it was good but needed more dressing but a squeeze of lemon does the trick. my husband enjoyed the pork sandwich and the bread was soft and came with sesame seeds. for drinks we ordered the porch fizz

full text doc: morelia started off with no name, but they finally got a name so you call them something other then " that mexican place ". the restaurant is convenient and easy to get to, especially if you work in the area. the food was very good, i went with a pork burrito for lunch. the tortilla was fairly standard fair, but the pork filling was tender and juicy. while good the pork did not have a rich complex smokey flavor that would have pushed it up to 4 stars. rice was well cooked without hard areas or mushy portions. beans were average, not bad but nothing out of the ordinary ( they are beans after all ). the chips were crisp and salty with a great fresh salsa. the tomatoes were firm and juicy with fresh onions with just enough bite to them but not to overpower the salsa. there were also hints of citrus that brightened up the flavor a bit. the service was excellent. wait staff was quick, polite, and efficient. food was made, plated, and served very fast during lunch. overall i am very happy with morelia for a lunch during the work day that can get you back to the office in a reasonable amount of time with good food. as a plus you don't leave smelling

full text doc: their beers are awesome. i had the chance to sample a few of them the other day and i was not the least bit disappointed. the raspberry mead ale and the grim reaper stout were the highlights! you can even buy jugs of their current selection with $ 5 deposit on a refillable jug. the place dates back to to 1700s and has some history in the revolutionary war. it's decorated with portraits of native americans ( injuns ) from colonial period and has a very nice dinning room and bar. the food is decent but it would be worth going just to sample their beers.

full text doc: i had two huge trees snap last night in the wind blocking a main walkway at our home. i called joe mills at action yard and tree. he sent a crew out the first thing in the morning which was a sunday morning... sunday! in 90 minutes, it was cleared, cleaned, and i have lots of firewood as a result neatly stacked by his employees. his crew was very polite and professional. i'm a stickler for good customer service. action yard and tree lived up to my expectations. thank you!!!

full text doc: i stumbled into this place late one weeknight, not knowing much about it and not expecting much. the interior's got this sort of roadhouse / nautical thing going on, which is what you'd see at a fake seafood place in an airport, but it also sat right on the water. i had a very laid - back waiter who sat down at the chair across from me and asked me what i was thinking about for dinner, and i basically said " do your best - whatever you think. " that was the ticket - he came back in a bit with the special not on the menu : two huge mahi - mahi, sushi - grade steaks of tuna, blackened on the outside to give them a good crust, but rare inside. i talked to the waiter about it a bit more, and he said they catch those tuna off the gulf shore. this guy came right off the boat, gently seared, and to my plate. it also came with a great spicy wasabi sauce, and some corn on the cob and fries, which were all great, but that tuna... oh man, it was the best piece of seafood i've ever had in my life. it easily flaked, but was thick

full text doc: this is my second time at far east nashville. the first i was in town for business and my friend wanted to try it out since she wanted some vietnamese food. i went along because i'm always down for a one - pot noodle dish. the decor is modern, dimly lit, and the overall space is rather small. it was pleasant. the wait staff were younger, eccentric, funky. onto the food. i ordered the beef pho the first time. it wasn't the best i've had, but it wasn't the worst. there was no shortage of noodles or beef. the broth did lack some substance and i would say that's where they fell short. there wasn't a lot of sprouts or greens to accompany the dish either. my second time there, i ordered the green onion tilapia. yum. the seasoning was just right. the fish wasn't drowning in it - which i prefer it not. the accompanying fish sauce was a good blend, too. you'd be surprised at how many restaurants mess that sauce up. the hubby had the stir - fried vegetables, which was really water spinach and other leafy greens in a thick soy sauce, and saute

full text doc: i remember as a child visiting the ( old ) dali museum and being fascinated by his art. for years i always spoke of going back and bringing my family especially when the new building was done. i finally did it at least with my youngest son. we spent about 3 hours there. we tried to do the guided tour but there were too many people and we couldn't hear or see anything. they have a self guided tour with head phones so we went back down stairs and and got the headphones. much better decision and it went so much better. i noticed most visitors decided to do the same thing. i asked my son if he enjoyed the museum and he did. they have a lot of ongoing activities each day so check out the website to see what's happening on their schedule even for the little ones. thursday is half price after 5 p. m.

full text doc: i am beyond impressed with jefferson animal hospital! i took my dog there for the first time today for a routine check up and to get his nails cut. everyone there was amazing : from the woman at the front desk, to the vet tech, and especially dr. schneider. i feel like i've only ever had bad experiences with vets but she was absolutely wonderful! the last time i took my dog somewhere to get his nails cut, they told me i would have to get him sedated to get it done... it took a little bit of work, but dr. schneider and the vet tech got it done without me having to pay the extra cost of having him sedated ( which was no easy feat seeing as though he's 80 pounds and very strong ). they were both so kind and thoughtful and actually took the time to answer any questions i had. i will definitely be back again!

full text doc: wow, i guess i'll be the first person to write a review of this place. first of all, my memories of this tiny, cramped, mom - n'- pops grocery store in chinatown go wayyy back to grade school, when we used to come by after school and push and shove our way to the chips or candy or popsicle sticks. we used to save our dimes and quarters so we could get treats from here. my mother would also come here to buy newspapers and noodles and other various things for the kitchen. the store is owned by a small family and has been serving the c - town community for years and years... i remember when they used to use an abacus to ring our stuff up... they might still do. i guess this review is more nostalgia - fueled than anything, but i'll be sure to come here if i'm ever in c - town and want a light refreshment and a blast from the past.

full text doc: we went here on recommendation of my grandmother and weren't sure what to expect. not only was the food delicious but the cultural experience was fantastic! we ordered the ethiopian spiced hot tea to drink which had an exquisite spicy chai flavor. it was thoroughly enjoyable and complemented the food well. for our meal we got the restaurant's namesake combo for two which was plenty for leftovers and a whole second meal! instead of silverwear you get a large piece of thin pancake lime ethiopian bread and you tear of bits to pick up the food and eat it with your hands. this was my first experience with ethiopian food and culture and i would definitely go again! i loved this place and agree with my grandmother that it is a must go! if you are into unique foods and experiences you need to stop here!

full text doc: the people watching here is spectacular. west tampa sandwich shop appears to be the neighborhood sandwich stop. i could be wrong ; they could be clairvoyant and know everyone's name that walks through the door. well, except for mine. i may have immunity? rubbish! they're locals and like i said the people watching is outstanding because of this. as sally l. pointed out, you don't know what to do if you walk in a foreigner to this place. sit, dance, run? yes, sit. someone will come to you and the service will be awesome. in the meantime, marvel at all of the photographs on the wall of patrons inside the establishment along with autographed photos of celebrities and politicians. i had a frita ( cuban hamburger ) here. it was juicy, flavorful and satisfying. coupled with a batido de mamey and i was ready for a long nap. i sampled some of there sopa de gallego and highly recommend it. i'd never had it before, but it is certainly different and worth a sample. this place is a solid 3. 5. i suspect there are untapped restaurants in the area - - begging to be yelped.

full text doc: we all know it, every critic in town knows it : le bec - fin is the finest french restaurant in philadelphia. le bec - fin is one of the restaurants that my boyfriend and i must go when we visit philadelphia during breaks. we went during winter break for my 20th birthday and i must say, it was a sweet way to celebrate! i adore their dessert cart as the server bring the cart to my table, i distinctly remember my mouth getting watery. by far, it's the sweetest sight! they don't accept walk - ins, so you must make a reservation. and guys, please do dress - up. while i was dining here, i saw a couple who were under dressed by any standard. they were wearing jeans - in my opinion, an ultimate no - no. also, do keep your etiquette constantly. otherwise, you will stick out like a sore - thumb! this is another restaurant that i find myself keep dining in. my boyfriend and i already planned to celebrate his 20th birthday, which is coming in 3 weeks, at le bec - fin, because they truly are the best.

full text doc: i have now been to matyson three times, and it's pretty darn good. the service was friendly, the decor sleek and simple. the food? i thought my onion and garlic soup was just a little too... salty. my flank steak was very good, once i wiped off the extra sauce on the wilted vegetables... but that left the vegetables a little too salty to be eaten. the truffle fries were amazing... and you know how you get that little head rush with too much truffle? yeah, that was me. on the downside? just a bit too pricey, i think. my friend got the tasting menu ( pork this week ) which she really liked. overall, i'd go back again.

full text doc: i always wanted to go into a restaurant or bakery and say, " this reminds me of the good old days. " but since i'm still fairly young, can't exactly say that with much credibility. i can say that i think a place reminds me of the simpler days. the sweeter days when things weren't so frenetic and chain - based and people took their time. people savored and had old - fashioned values. okay, so maybe no one except the characters on " little house and the prairie " actually possessed such values, but a girl can dream. applegate's is the sort of place where simplicity and originality reign supreme. it feels old, in a good way. it's not like bread company, though you can get the same kinds of things here. i never see crowds or people checking their watches to make it back to the office on time. here, the pace is slower. they've got tons of great soups from which to choose and even barrels of penny candy. i'm just glad this place has survived as long as it has. proof positive that deep down, we're all looking for a bit of simplicity, the way it was back in the good old days.

full text doc: we tried to get reservations during restaurant week but they were all booked. however the lady who answered the phone said we could have the same deal this week. so we went on monday. our reservations were at 5 : 30. we met at the bar and tried their drink special of the day which was refreshing and strong. we were seated promptly at 5 : 30. the place was pretty much empty at the time. our waiter was extremely nice and our service was attentive. the meat kept coming. the reason we selected chima over fogo was one of the people i was with does not eat meat, and chima offers swordfish and salmon. i've been to fogo 3 times, and i really couldn't tell any difference between the two places. we all enjoyed our meal here. i don't think i would go back and pay regular price at any time. none of us eats enough to get our money's worth, but it was a nice, fun place to go with restaurant week prices.

full text doc: i've been going to tony's since i was a little bambina on my father's shoulders. my father's family is from yonkers, new york, and when he moved here as a teenage, he missed home. tony's deli was mecca to him while i was growing up. a lot of my college and work friends were squeamish about this place. i had to explain to them, it's a legit deli. it's cramped, it's a little greasy feeling, and it's dim. it feels like home to me. red & white checkered table clothes ( a little obvious italian, but it's ok ). beautiful cuts of meat behind the counter, freezer full of cheese & pre - prepared ready to go meals ( and cannoli pie! ) tony's is also one of the few " west coast " deli's that does not pre - fill their cannolis, which keep them crispy and delicious! the sandwiches are crazy delicious. the rocky is my favorite by far ; mortadella, prosciutto, provolone, tasty garlic toast bread. the pre - prepared dishes are great too, totally brings me

full text doc: simply put, the best pizza. in my 2 + years as a student in new orleans, i'm proud to say that i've been an excited witness to the growth of naked pizza ( formerly, the unfortunately - named " world's healthiest pizza " ). i've probably averaged one naked pizza pie for every two weeks. by my rough calculation, that's about 43 pizzas. all 43 have left me in awe. these folks have stumbled on something fantastic. they've taken arguably the greatest and most popular dish in american cuisine and made it good for us. that's not the fantastic part, though. the fantastic part is that it is, consistently, the best tasting pizza i've ever had. it's natural, organic, and so satisfying. as for the menu, you can't go wrong with any of the specialties. personally, i prefer a more minimalist approach - - my favorite topping combination is tomato and fresh basil ( which, yes, they grow in - store ). tuesday is 2 for 1, and they have a perpetual large - two - topping special. give naked a shot. after a couple pizzas, you'll be hooked. your body ( and your taste buds )

full text doc: i recommend all to go to pharmacy of america compared to cvs, rite aide, or walgreens. let me tell you why. i recently was hospitalized and was prescribed medications that my insurance only covered for half. they were so caring, patient and attentive. they made calls, and worked with my insurance to get me the prescriptions i needed. i first went to cvs, and rite aide to fill my prescriptions but they literally just don't have the time or compassion to check and see what other " routes " to take to give you the best options. thank you again making it happened for me. it was my first time at a pharmacy of america last night and i will now go nowhere else.

full text doc: recently renovated, this small, quiet, and charming inn - a perfect example of spanish - colonial architecture, a style typical of historic santa barbara - is ideally located in a residential neighborhood only two blocks from west beach, and is within walking distance of stearns pier. a very short drive away is the center of town, a wide, tree - lined avenue with shops and restaurants conforming to the same architectural style, resulting in an interesting uniform look. the 27 - room inn is a welcome change from contemporary high - rise or motel - style chain properties. each room is unique, light, and spacious, with beautiful period furnishings. all of them have a coffee maker, refrigerator, microwave oven, cable tv with free movie channels, direct dial phone with voice mail, in - room safe, iron & ironing board, high - speed internet access, am / fm clock radio, and a hair dryer. several have a fireplace, whirlpool tub, and / or a balcony. both times we stayed here, the accommodations we had included a separate, fully equipped kitchen, where we prepared bacon and eggs to supplement the expanded continental breakfast that's included in the rates. ample free on - site parking is available. the only thing missing, unfortunately, is

full text doc: this residence inn by marriott is located just about 3 miles from the beach. 5 star hotel for the spacious and very clean rooms. stayed over night after attending clearwater food and wine fest, knowing we'd be partaking in lots of adult beverages and not wanting to be a statistic. the king studio suite was spacious and modern with full kitchen with everything you'd need. free wifi was a plus! they even have free breakfast, dinner reception etc. would highly recommend this clean hotel for your stay. it's a short 10 min ride to the beach. taxi will cost about $ 8 each way. there is a small mexican market within walking distance for any last minute needs.

full text doc: my boyfriend's family lives in tampa, so we are in the area often. one thing we have noticed over the years.... a serious lack of places for quality breakfast that doesn't require table service. enter, the vine baking co. the decor is adorable, sort of shabby chic meets farmhouse. they have a handful of small tables for 2 or 3, as well as a bar that seated about 6 or so. definitely small and quaint, but we loved that! we got our food to go though because we were in a hurry. i got an iced americano with hazelnut swirl.... so glad that they had almond milk! not all places do. i also got a bacon egg and cheese. the bread was similar to a cuban sandwich bread i believe. it was really tasty! i like that the cheese and egg were mixed together vs a slab of cheese just being melted on top. ps notice the cute mother's day pastry display! we didn't indulge though, i don't have much of a sweet tooth. i still appreciated the craftsmanship though!

full text doc: betsy is spot - on with her excitement about this place. the inside just blows you away with its gilded doors, plates, and teacup tops. the space is small and intimate, the perfect place to play catchup with my mom over a leisurely, priviledged lunch. i got the crab, sweet indiana corn and tomato salad. the crab was delicate and succulent, the corn, fresh and just the perfect temperature. red pepper added a little more excitement, though i could have used maybe a bit of spice to take this into southwestern cuisine territory. but the flavors were extremely fresh and clean. they worked. ( a tomato was a little insipid, but hopefully it was a bad bunch. ) the pumpkin pie chiffon was the perfect climax to the meal. homemade, this spicy loaf is more like a pie than bread, and fall - apart soft. the creamy icing wasn't too sugary.

full text doc: you've gotta give the blockley pourhouse credit for having concerts and giving a damn in a neighborhood that sorely needs such establishments. the food's okay, they have a handful of good beers, and for a decently loud rock concert, the sound can be good. on the other hand, the room is oddly set up, with far more room to either side of the stage than in front of the stage ( especially when the bar is busy ). not only is this problematic at crowded concerts, but quiet, more sparsely attended concerts have to compete with bar noise very directly. moreover, the scene can be extremely fratty / bro - y, and on a night when there isn't a concert, the blockley comes off as an odd mix of a nightclub and a sports bar, especially with their giant tvs. actually, i should note that this is probably a pretty decent place to watch a sporting event. finally, as another review has mentioned, they have a pretty limited tap selection for a place that calls itself a " pourhouse ", and the bottle list isn't exactly inspiring, either. there are a couple of good local brews, yes, but, well, they should simply have a greater number of quality beers from

full text doc: terrible. our group was excited about dining on the canal, but extremely disappointed with our experience here. after ordering, we waited for about 45 minutes without hearing anything from our server. we noticed that no one seated outside had any food, including a few tables who had arrived before us, and started to worry. so we finally got our server's attention and asked how long it would be until our food came. her response? at least another 45 minutes because there were tables in front of us. we asked to speak to a manager, who said that the wait was not her fault, but it was because the kitchen " ran out of food. " ( the restaurant was not even close to being full ). well, why couldn't someone have told us that before we sat down and waited for nearly an hour? as soon as the people at the tables around us heard what was going on, several people got up and left, including one table who said they had been there for over an hour and a half. we paid for our drinks ( the rude manager did not offer to give us the drinks for free ) and left.

full text doc: i'm sad to write this review because i love trying out new sushi places. my friends brought me here a few nights ago because it is their favorite place for sushi, but i just wasn't feeling it. the space is somewhat run down and very outdated, and the sushi just was not the style i enjoy. particularly the energy roll with salmon : i was expecting fresh, bright, flavors of raw salmon and the salmon in the roll was cooked and the roll tasted really heavy to me. my friends also insisted we have another roll which ( i believe ) was the dragon roll and it was fried sushi, in foil which it was completely stuck too, stuffed with cream cheese. it was not spicy ( disappointing ) and it was way too rich for me. the hamachi kama ( broiled fish collar ) was extremely dry as well. also the price seemed quite high for the few rolls i had in comparison with other places around town that taste fresher to me.

full text doc: on the surface, l'etage has everything i would seem to want in a bar. loungey seats, a great beer and wine selection, a pretty bar and a gloomy ambiance. however, there is something that bugs me about the place. it isn't, as setephan mentioned, the spurious frenchie thing. that i can deal with, as pretentious as it might be, particularly in south philly. rather, it's the obnoxiously loud music that seems to be cranking every time i walk in. why? why not eurotrashy downtempo dance or hell, even jazz. why junky dance and hiphop? if i'm spending $ 7 for a beer and sitting in a cozy lounge, i would like to be able to hear the conversation i am trying to have.

full text doc: met andrew d. and a couple of friends here after getting off work last night. they were waiting outside when i arrived and said the wait would be about 5 minutes. the wait turned into 15 and just as we were getting antsy, we were seated. the atmosphere left a little to be desired as the pleather table cloth was rather sticky and tables were basically on top of each other, but at least it was authentic! we received chips fairly quickly and i loved all 3 of the salsas that accompanied them. being that it was a holiday weekend, a pitcher of margaritas was in order and a sol for the non - margarita drinker of the group ; as well as an order of guacamole. i thought the guac was delish, but there were giant chunks of tomato, thus making it hard to scoop up with the thin chips. i ordered the enchiladas for dinner, one mexican, one swissa and they were to die for! the cheese was phenomenal, the plate piping hot and the accompanying rice and beans hit the spot. the rice was especially surprising with a delicious smoky flavor. it seemed like everyone thoroughly enjoyed their dinner as i was the only one with a take - away box. i would say it

full text doc: i popped into tony's on the way home today to pick up some take - out. i heard the food was good and i like the look of the place from the outside. it's been around for years and seems to keep steady business. i stopped on this particular day because it was minus 14 and they had christmas decorations up inside. it looked so warm and inviting, and the thought of taking out a thin crust and salad and not having to cook was tempting. i walked in, and fell in love with this place. it's dimly lit, warm and ambiant. candles cover the tables and christmas music was playing softly. the servers and manager all made eye contact and i was welcomed and given a menu to look over. i sat and took my time browsing, and enjoyed the space. i could tell that the people who work here all like each other and are proud to work in such a place. it has the vibe of a good, honest, hard - working family restaurant, with class and homemade goodness as part of their time - tested recipe. i settled on the lasagna al forno with homemade noodles, beef and fresh mozzarella, topped with their pomodoro sauce, and the chef salad with roma

full text doc: franklin tea is a specialty loose leaf tea store. they also have a nice supply of tea service items like tea pots, one - cup tea brewers, tea strainers, and fancy decorative tea pots. the loose leaf tea collection is really the draw for this little spot. the selection includes black teas, flavored teas, and specialty blends created by the franklin tea store. they had a brewed sweet tea for sampling when i visited on saturday. it was delicious. i love tea, so i had fun looking at all the little trinkets for brewing tea here. they had a cool collection of one - cup brew mugs which were really great. the prices here are also really reasonable, especially considering they are located in downtown franklin.

full text doc: solid 4 stars. i came here on a weekday during a business trip and the place was booming with business. i went to the back and sat at the bar, which was a separate room with a nice ambience. bartender was friendly enough, ( for city people, i guess ), informative and nice about getting me samples for the beer. i chose a sour / stout that he recommended and loved it. next, i ordered the dekoninck mussels, which were in a clear broth with apples, gruyere, and caramelized leeks. the mussels were fresh - - so fresh that they still had some rocks and sand in them. overall, i thought the flavor was good. the pomme frites were delicious. fresh cut fries that had a nice crunch on the outside and a soft buttery center. the sauce was to die for! extremely rich, flavorful, velvety and savory. would definitely come back for the fries! for the beer and mussels - - sure.... maybe.

full text doc: it's really a great gym. you can't beat the price, there is ample equipment so there isn't usually a wait for a machine. i was skeptical about the whole non - judgmental marketing but it's true! it's an inspiring place to work out. they have stations for 12 minute abs, 30 minute workouts and machines and free weights for any length workout. the clientele changes somewhat based on the time of day but everyone regardless of age, size, ability seems to be really positive, pleasant and supportive of other people working out whenever i've gone. they can also provide a print out of all dates you've exercised for health insurance reimbursement ( that way you don't have to track it yourself ). worth checking out.

full text doc: for the best steaks in nashville, you have to head over to the stock - yard. it is out in the boonies, but it's worth the drive. i had the pleasure of dining at this legendary establishment, voted one of the top 10 steakhouses in the us, for a co - workers bachelor party. a private room was set up for us in the humongous building where the stock - yard is located. as usual, i went with a filet mignon - cooked medium - which was quite good, along with a side of creamed spinach. the food was good but by no means the best i've ever had ( yes - i was somewhat disappointed ). the beauty of the stockyard is the history and the atmosphere. it also boasts having the oldest bottle of wine in the united states ( circa 1776 ). when you first walk in there is a huge lobster tank, where you can pick out a massive lobster if you choose to go that route. we were served by a lovely waitress who attended to our every need with a smile and considerable grace, given that she was in the middle of a raucous bachelor party of 15 + guys. definitely worth a visit if you're in nashville. oh, and

text: provolone ketchup tasty onions fixin sauce pickles bite quick spicy whole peppers double fried fries hot hot
full text doc: i used to eat here every week because my office was right around the corner. anytime i am in the area i stop by for a quick bite. i like it when the cook the steak in whole pieces. i get a double meat with fried onions and provolone cheese. they have a nice fixin's bar with hot peppers, pickles, ketchup and hot sauce. their spicy fries are pretty tasty as well.

full text doc: sonoran hot dogs. holy moly. beware... after you've tried one of these, you'll start craving them on a regular basis. a bacon - wrapped hot dog, grilled, placed in an soft bun, topped with just the right amount of " a bunch of stuff. " the grilled jalapenos are either mild or super hot ( it changes every time i go ), so be careful. the burros and caramelos here are amazing also, but if you're visiting and only plan to go to el guero canelo once, don't pass up on the sonoran hot dog.

text: groovin change crab thru marrow divine duck fried drinks salad music back bone nye chicken loud
full text doc: on nye my husband and i enjoyed dinner here. classy atmosphere, great drinks - the crab salad, bone marrow and chicken fried duck were divine! only thing i would change was the music when we first arrived, which was really loud and harsh. good thing it changed midway thru our meal, even the bartenders were groovin'at that point. we will def be back for more!

full text doc: the show is absolutely amazing, but, the restrooms smell absolutely awful! they are the worst smelling public restrooms i have ever seen since i went to china. they smell awful even though they don't look filthy. hint : get some clorox or pine sol and wash the restrooms! there is no excuse for that as much as they charge for tickets. i did appreciate the full bar inside the theatre, they sell mixed drink doubles and they pour them strong so you only need to buy one!

full text doc: i called ahead to place a take out order and it was ready pretty fast. seaweed salad was delicious. vegetable spring rolls were pretty average a little oily for my liking. the sushi was fantastic i ordered this florida roll which i believe had salmon and tuna in it and it was sooooo good! i had a hard time deciding which roll to choose since they all looked so interesting and delicious. i also got the chicken katsu which was perfect. i have definitely found my new sushi spot in south tampa!

full text doc: one of the best and hopping karaoke bars in santa barbara. located on upper state street, this place has a very loyal and local following... the whole bar is always jamming...
