full text doc: my husband and i stayed here for our anniversary. it's a few blocks from state street but on the end away from the beach. we walked everywhere, and it was great though exhausting. the b & b is very cute. we stayed in susan's loft, which was nice except the bathtub / shower was a little iffy. think bathtub with a handheld shower head put into the side of the sloped roof. other than that, it was great. the staff was helpful and very low key. lots of goodies available to eat all day, including a nice breakfast with granloa, fresh fruit and something warm ( french toast, spanish omelet etc ). later in the afternoon there was cheese and wine and lots of homemade cakes and biscuits that were available to eat all night long. in fact, we were kind of fooded out. i thought the value was good for what we got, and i appreciated being on the top floor so we barely noticed the other guests other than at breakfast.

text: condiments hoagies when like pound any a a per fast out . . .
full text doc: a good choice for salad, and the vegetables are fresh. located right in the center city, and a good alternative to pizza, hoagies or other typical fast food. the only thing to watch out for is the $ 6. 69 per pound price which can add up, especially when dressings and condiments are priced just like any other item.

text: ) ) service always staff nice atmosphere of every regular ( ( area the the the the the the the the the the the chain crawdad fried place place folks ' ' ' ' ' ' '
full text doc: i think the fried seafood is always a little bland. don't waste the money for potatoes - they are pretty bland, too. now that that's out of the way - this place is great for boiled seafood. great crawfish ( don't say crawdad's or they will smile at you ), pretty good blue crab, excellent shrimp, and the sausage is okay, too. you order by weight ( or count for the crabs ). it's no fancy place but it is a local eatery with regular returning customers. i try to eat here with a friend every time i'm in the area. the wait staff is great and this is not a chain. the perino's seafood shop down the highway is owned by the same family but not the same folks. clean, genuine, great service, great boiled seafood, real nice family atmosphere - what more could you ask for?

full text doc: i went to will with some friends the night before thanksgiving, i cannot, i repeat cannot rave enough about it! we ordered most of the menu minus a few things so we could all share and try everything. we were not disappointed by one plate. i love going out and have tried a lot of places in philly, this is one of the best. to top it off its byob so when the check came we were pleasantly surprised at how low it was. as someone who is not a mushroom fan i could not get enough of the hen of the woods mushroom, it was perfectly crispy at parts soft at others and the sauce was beyond delicious. the scallops were seared just right nice and light and fresh. i am still thinking about how good the pork was, tender and fatty and crispy yum! we also had the special which was like sushi i can't remember exactly what it was though, except that it was amazing. if you go ( and you should, now ) please don't miss the sweet potato pottage, i can honestly say it was one of the best things i've ever eaten, i contemplated licking the bowl.... the standout in the entrees was the sirloin

full text doc: among one of treasure island's pearls, sloppy joe's has something for everyone... locals and tourists alike. primary is the great location right on the best part of the beach. with a wide expanse of sand to the sea, sloppy joe's is a favorite of mine especially approaching and during sunset. with live music in the background, plenty of folks having fun, good food and great beverages, sloppy joe's is the place... and an essential link in the rather good treasure island pub crawl. park across the street in the lot adjacent to the walgreen. be very, very careful crossing the street to sloppy joe's. yes.. the is a very noticeable crosswalk, signs and lights... but that hasn't prevented a few from being mowed over!

full text doc: eh, it's not like i'll be avoiding this place since i won't be able to divert my itinerary if i have to. the airport is small, but i'm not put off by that. the terminal for my connecting flight was somehow not attached to the rest of the airport and there was a shuttle area taking people to and fro. the shuttles run fairly quickly but with just a few minutes between flights it felt like forever, especially since the'line'is really a huge crowd that stretches further than the space available - and if there's someone who's in a wheelchair it's hard for them. you always could walk out and in but that would require you to go through security again - again, if you're pressed for time is also not a viable option. the concourse i was on, hardly had any food options - no place for even the signature philly cheesesteak which would have really made my opinion of this place higher but, it did not. i may just pick another place to fly out of if i can, if not i'll just suck it up and join the crowd.

full text doc: delaney's first trip to the dentist was a success! she was very nervous but the play room with the touchscreen games and play kitchen kept her busy until it was time to go to the room. everything from the waiting room play room to the wall paintings were very kid friendly. dr. sekhon was awesome. delaney's favorite part was getting her goodie bag with a new toothbrush and toothpaste and picking her surprise out of the treasure chest! we will be back in 6 months!

full text doc: it's difficult to find a great color and cut in philly. i've found it here. i only go here when i am in town visiting my parents, so i can't vouch for specific stylists. however, i've had services done by a handful of stylists at g & p and the results were always decent to good. their staff of skilled stylists ensure you will never get a bad haircut. caveat : i wouldn't recommend this place if you want to get services done on a saturday. they are normally overbooked and the atmosphere feels rushed. the stylist will cut your hair, but an assistant will both color it and blow it dry. if you go during the week, you will get the individual attention you are already paying for.

full text doc: from the outside this diner is very unsuspecting. it looks like your usual nj diner establishment. the parking lot is a disaster as apparently no one knows what " one way " means. once you actually find a parking spot and get past all the mundane, you are treated with a real good diner experience. my girlfriend and i came on father's day by ourselves and saw a huge wait. we thought we were going to be sitting there forever, but as we found out all were large parties and we were promptly sat in a 2 person booth. score! our stomachs were most appreciative. it was still breakfast time so i decided to get the creamed chipped beef on biscuit and the gf got a fried egg sandwich with bacon, cheddar and tomato on white. both came with home fries ( mine came with a juice as well ). it was quite busy here and i could realize our waitress was a bit overwhelmed as it looked like she was servicing the entire counter as well as a few tables. she took our orders and was very pleasant. the food came out quickly, which was surprising given the volume. i now have to say this, the creamed chipped beef blew me away. it was on par with

full text doc: i love this place and i always come here to get vegetable fried rice and vegetable egg fu yung - 3 patties and definitely enough gravy! my guy gets the pepper steak and the kids get orange chicken and sesame chicken combo plates. we split a large order of crab rangoon. the older lady that usually greets me when i come to pick up the order is super nice, always gives me free chopsticks and you can get as much soy sauce, red pepper, etc. as you like because it sits out separately for the taking. most places you have to ask several times for more or pay for it! i have had the older man hand me my order but never take it by phone but he's always nice as well... no free chopsticks but a great smile!

full text doc: a friend and i had dinner there two nights ago. excellent service. haley was attentive and extremely helpful. the food was good and well prepared and reasonably priced. it is a terrific place to go for a quiet evening of good food. the place is kind of old fashioned looking but in this case old fashioned is nice. we will certainly go back again soon.

full text doc: tequila's is our ( husband and i ) favorite mexican in town. i really like the cheese enchiladas ( the sauce is amazing ) and they have good spinach burritos too. if you want to splurge try the papas con queso ( french fries with queso sauce ). not healthy but oh so good! the staff is friendly. the manager / owner always makes us feel very welcome. it's also a good place to eat while there is a game on. husband can keep an eye on the game ( they have a couple of tv's ) while you eat. oh and don't forget the mango margaritas!

full text doc: great service and great food! reminescing my experience at roy's pebble beach, i ended up here for dinner. the atmosphere is warm and the chefs worked in an open kitchen. i ordered from the fix prixe menu and had the fusion sampler, mac nut mahi mahi, and the chocolate souffle for dessert... a deal. everything was delicious! i felt so stuffed! content and in a food coma, i slumped in my seat after the meal. i couldn't finish my dessert and but i keep picking at it... i couldn't bear to have such good food go to waste. one of the servers even noticed and joked that i looked stuffed. he chuckled at my feeble attempt to finish off the last of the chocolate souffle.

full text doc: this place is a wine afficionado's dream. they basically sell everything except for the actual wine, from expensive crystal stemware to wine cellars to cigars to those fancy, expensive corkscrews. the prices are pretty reasonable, although the crystal and such is expensive, which is to be expected. pinot has also partnered with tangerine to offer wine tasting classes on wed. nights in the summer, and they also have first friday specials, like live jazz and wine tasting. this place couldn't be any cooler. and, as kimberly p. has observed, the guy behind the counter is really easy on the eyes.

full text doc: i'm a frequent patron of the kung fu tea in virginia. got the ordering down like a pro, and i know exactly what most of the drinks taste like and which ones i prefer. i usually order kf milk green tea, passion fruit green tea, passion fruit slush, matcha red bean slush, yogurt grapefruit, yogurt green tea, winter melon milk green tea, oreo milk tea, taro slush, or matcha milk strike. if i can, i'll adjust sweetness levels to at least 50 % and lower. on a road trip up to new york, we stopped in philly for lunch and afterwards decided to grab some kung fu tea for the road. i ordered my usual matcha milk strike without anything else and didn't make any adjustments. unfortunately, the matcha milk strike was not as good as the one i had in virginia. they put too much powder and it was extremely bitter, even after i mixed and mixed. i could barely drink it. in the end, i had to dump most of it away. my experience at tea do last time i was in philly was much better. i still remain loyal to the kung fu tea name, but i would be

full text doc: so it's sandal season again and my feet needed some major tune - up. i really thought that this place would be just another nail salon like every other one in strip mall, america. this place is different. plasma tvs, stone walls, fountains, mood lighting, a bottle of water.... very relaxing. holly gave me the best lower leg / foot massage ever. it lasted at least 15 minutes and was so gentle. all for $ 30... i'm now a loyal customer.

text: metairie broccoli gravy dilly since satisfied always always always entree childhood once leaves month piccadilly experience fresh with with under would would g soft often thanks to to to to to to dennis of of of down those home are they bucks usually location fried coming is
full text doc: thanks to dennis g, who reviewed the metairie location for reminding me that i owe this place a review. wow. i can't believe i have never reviewed this place! i seriously eat here probably once a month. now, piccadilly isn't one of those places that you go to for a fancy dining experience, but the food is like home cooking to me, probably because i have been coming here since i was a kid. i always get the dilly plate, which is an entree ', two sides and a piece of bread for under 8 bucks. you really can't beat that. i usually get the fried catfish, mashed potatoes and gravy and broccoli with a soft roll. it's always good and fresh and it always leaves me satisfied. also, i don't often get dessert, but when i do i get the chocolate pudding. this place is pretty awesome. i know there are people who have never been and would never want to try it, but this place reminds me of my childhood when i would go with my grandmother to lunch. they also have take out, if you don't want to sit down and eat!

full text doc: this outback is a frequent standby for me when deciding on friday / saturday dinner options. there are many things here that have been good, however i gave a below average rating based on how this particular outback compares to others i've been to. i'm sometimes willing to give a resturaunt the benifit of a doubt if i have noticed a one time offence. however in the case of this location, on three seperate occassions i have had unsatisfactory meals. in fact so unsatisfactory that if i find myself there i no longer consider a certain particular dish an option. it was not always like this at this location. this 4th street outback is where i first had the particular item that i no longer indulge in. all in all i see this erosion of quality as an over all reflection of the restaurant.

full text doc: yes, it used to be that gay bar. now it's one of my favorite places to go. the neighborhood is located next to the blue collar bistro ( and owned by the same ) and the brew house. very cool, open atmosphere. they have a digital jukebox for your listening pleasure ( or displeasure when some cowboy puts in $ 20 and plays every song on the album ). there are a lot of booths and several flat - screen tvs for you sports fans. the drinks are reasonably priced and you can order food from the blue collar bistro. what i like best are the games! they have two ping - pong tables setup in the middle of the bar ( in addition to the small pool table ). on top of that they have a bunch of random board games for you to play ( i. e. rummicube, truth / dare jenga, clue, etc. ). usually we'll just cruise down there and get a pitcher or two and play dominoes. but it is a great destination if you aren't trying to go downtown to the state st. scene. it can get really packed here too on random nights, but i've found that it will usually begin to slow down after 12

full text doc: i guess i should have known better. this is not a traditional new orleans restaurant - it's part of the royal sonesta hotel. it's an inviting space and i loved the decor and the name. it's open air and faces right onto bourbon st. we chose it for a sunday afternoon lunch so it wasn't too crazy inside or out. i guess it could have been if the saints weren't getting their butts handed to them. i think we simply ordered wrong. we had od'd on oysters the previous 2 days but we probably should have had them here. instead, we got peel and eat shrimp. they were mushy and kind of flavorless - not plump and juicy as expected. the cocktail sauce was good though - and it had a serious kick! we also got 2 iceberg & blue cheese wedge salads. i never order that. ever. but, i had no choice. it was practically the only green ( well, more like water - colored light green ) item on the menu. i also had a bowl of shrimp, oyster and sausage gumbo and it was blando. shrimp were small and obviously had been frozen, oysters were mushy, the roux was thin

full text doc: this might be my new favorite brunch restaurant! we had a great experience with excellence service, food, and cocktails. i will be returning to try one of their diverse menu options. for 11 on a saturday, we only had to wait a few minutes for a table. one was available, but it just had to be finished bussing. my only negative experience was from the host. after a few minutes, she came up to me and told me she thought my whole party was there. i had started drinking a mimosa while waiting for my friends. i told her they would be here any minute, and it would be a group of 3. i was also the only person who entered the restaurant at the time i came in, and i was clearly the only one who sat. i don't know who the invisible 2 people were. i think they should wait to seat you if there is a policy that your entire party must be there before seating. there was no one waiting, and i saw another open table, so i don't know what the issue was. i believe it would be the restaurant's responsibility to enforce that policy, given that i had already ordered and was seated. luckily, the service from our waiter was excellent

full text doc: this was our first trip to nashville and found this restaurant while searching online - initially, what intrigued us was the menu. we were graciously seated in a room with 3 other tables ( discovered later there are only 8 tables in the place! ). we started with the fried green tomatoes with crabmeat - delish! our entrees were great too - my husband had the standard filet and i had the sea bass. for dessert, we really enjoyed the white chocolate wild berry half baked cookie - finished the whole thing, which we never do! so yummy! best customer service / wait staff, which isn't unusual for what we found in nashville! as we were finishing our meal, the waiter asked if we would be interested in a tour? we jumped at the chance, since we had been loving all the history so far. the tour was just as great as the meal! the owner's mom took us through the 18, 000 square feet of this phenomenal home built in 1843 - we were astounded at all the nooks and crannies, secret rooms and even a natural spring located right inside! a must visit and don't forget to ask for the tour!

full text doc: i've been to mantra twice in the last two days, and i think it's fantastic! i went last night for happy hour for center city sips, and i was lucky enough to get there early and grab a table for me and my friends. the hostess was a really cute asian girl who was super friendly. the $ 1 special appetizers were yummy - a salmon nori roll and chicken dumplings. the cocktail specials were also both really good ( i had to try both, of course ). one was a mojito muddled with plums, and the other was an " asian red head " ( sake, white peach puree, and grenadine ). the decor was also really cool - somewhat dimly lit and cozy, with cool wooden tables, a gold wavy wall behind the bar with a mirror mosaic, and really classy modern asian - style cutlery and plates. my only complaint was that the bartenders weren't all that fast, the the place was crowded for happy hour. the guy downstairs made really good drinks, but the chick behind the bar kept getting confused and messing up orders, not to mention she took forever to make one drink, so people were getting kind of antsy waiting for their alcohol

text: ; pharmacists demand my my my ill me me not not not ' ' times another needs no no medicines customer customer think busy the the the the the the service rude getting apology of came came hire now worst pharmacy at at more more understanding
full text doc: i dropped off two prescriptions and was told it would be 45 minutes. i left and came back an hour later and told it would be another 15. when i came back in 20 minutes, my prescriptions still were not filled. i told them i was staying in the front of the line until i had my medicines. these were not refills or medications i could wait a day or two before getting. i was ill and needed the medicine. i was not rude, but i felt i had been patient enough and now they needed to show some understanding. when i received my prescriptions about 10 minutes later, there was no apology for the long wait. i understand that this is a busy cvs, and i imagine mondays are the worst for demand ; yet, customer service is important. this cvs needs to hire more pharmacists and be able to estimate wait times more accurately. i have used this location for several years but no one knows me or treats me as as valued customer. perhaps that's just the way it will be at any location or at any pharmacy, but i think it's time i venture forth and find out for sure.

full text doc: i have 14 piercings and 7 tattoos. 4 piercings and 2 ( soon to be three ) tattoos have been from this shop. i honestly don't know why i went anywhere else for any of my work. the piercers here are professional, clean, educated, and they make you feel comfortable. they have piercing deals on the last saturday of every month, and friday the 13th tattoo specials that bring in a ton of clients ( many of which come back for more work. ) i have had one bad experience with a tattoo artist but thankfully he no longer works there. i feel like a friend walking into renotattoo co. but when it matters, the artists become professional ( but not stuffy ) and welcoming. there are two piercers here, one female and one male. in some shops, there's only one piercer and if you want a genital piercing you're kind of screwed if your uncomfortable with the opposite sex doing it. all in all, i love renotattoo co. i wont be going anywhere else.

full text doc: we recently stayed at the green house inn for 5 lovely nights and would go back in a second! i knew i had found the right place online when i read about the tropical saltwater pool ( so refreshing on a muggy afternoon ), the laidback atmosphere, and the most hospitable host who is also a lifelong resident so full of helpful suggestions and friendly conversation. jesse welcomed us upon arrival and it immediately felt like we were staying at a friend's house. a friend who happens to have a home nearly 200 years old with so much charm and character. i loved that the pool was clothing optional, never closed, and my partner loved bud light in the vending machine for $ 1. my only complaint was that it was such a great place to stay, it was hard to get motivated to get out and explore new orleans. we felt comfortable walking to either garden district or french quarter, even at night, although taxis were quick and easy. if you have an open laid back attitude and want a beautiful and comfortable place to stay, green house inn is for you.

full text doc: i was in reno for a night and was in the mood for some thai food. being from san francisco, where we have many good thai restaurants, i has a bit apprehensive about the quality of " ethnic foods " in reno. i found green papaya in the yellow pages and decided to give it a try. the restaurant itself was empty but as we dined there was a steady stream of customers picking up take out orders. we ordered appetizers of chicken satay, crispy tofu, and tom - kha soup. you can order the soup in degrees of spiciness rated from 1 - 5. we ordered it as 3 and i thought it could have been a tad more spicy ( i like it hot ). my entree was a large plate of yummy tofu pad thai. our dishes were brought out quicky and the service was excelent! i highly recomend green papaya!

full text doc: i'm a big fan of sportsman's for the bar food. their sliders are magnificent - - they are on the starters part of the menu, but i eat them for a meal! they are basically gourmet krystal burgers. lovely! also, their fried pickle slices are divine. i am a huge fan of fried pickles, have had all kinds, and these definitely rank in the top 3! dip them in ranch and they are extra special. as for drinks, hey it's a sports bar - - i usually just get beer. they do have a full bar though. and both upstairs and down, their bars are huge and well - staffed. i've never had a problem with service there. i generally enjoy the upstairs, because that is where the pool tables and extra big screen tvs are, and my friends are typically up there. but be warned, it's pretty smoky. overall great place to hang out, watch sports, and chow on some much better than average bar food!

text: pistachio kedgeree poured dance queenshead gastro ) papered brunch buttie fit risotto britishly fish bay comprehensively beet duck spot beers wrong sounds electro prepared gravel hearts analogs down doesn can club smallish dirty mary progressive chips do toast beans oddly sunday lounge take british joint chris
full text doc: four posted lounge beds over a gravel patio, indie - electro dance parties, bathrooms papered with british tabloids, and a progressive european - influenced gastro pub menu. sounds out of place in the bay area, doesn't it? the queenshead is an anomaly, but is also the most welcoming scene i've experienced down here. joint owners darren and paul have poured hearts into this smallish restaurant / pub / club, and the result would fit into any of the more eclectic scenes of miami, ny, or san fran. chef chris greer can do no wrong - the menu is seasonal, balanced, and comprehensively delicious. try the pistachio stuffed duck breast, the fish and chips, or the beet and mushroom risotto. for dessert, take a few people and order one of each item. explore sake - bloody mary's, or any of the familiar ( or unfamiliar ) beers. sunday brunch, long an underexploited opportunity downtown, is spot - on here. sausage and beans on toast is britishly delicious, as are the chip buttie, the kedgeree, and the other oddly named and exquisitely prepared pub breakfasts they've translated into modern culinary analogs. dj craig dirty spins

full text doc: i just finished my first and probably only movie at this establishment. i purchased my ticket without incident, but when i took it to the ticket person, she announced that i would be in theater 4, adding, " did they tell you about the theater? " i said no, they had not, and was there a problem? she said that the heat was out in theater 4, " and it's pretty cold in there, so go in and see what you think. if it's too cold, we can exchange your ticket. " as i walked down the corridor, i heard her yell up to the snack bar guy, " dave, will you tell tom to tell people about theater 4?!? " theater 4 was indeed chilly, but i wanted to see the movie i had come to see any not any other, so i toughed it out in my jacket, scarf and gloves. this was not really that bad, except there was nothing i could do about my feet, which quickly turned into icicles. i suppose i should have changed and seen " bobby " or, god forbid, " happy feet, " but dammit, i wanted to see " stranger than fiction, " so that's what i did. now i'm back

full text doc: stopped in for lunch today and were seated on the patio. the outside area was nice, but the tables are a bit rickety and there was no music, tv or anything. i saw speakers, but they weren't being used. once we got our margaritas, we noticed they were really light on tequila, and i mean nearly virgin. we heard a couple at the next table complain about the same thing. we ordered an extra shot of tequila to fix what otherwise was a good drink. we ordered the carnitas and carne asada plates. the carnitas were delicious. just the right amount of delicious spicy pork. the carne asada wasn't as great. basically bland, very thin skirt steak paired with grilled scallions. would have been better with roasted peppers and thicker steak. both plates were served with rice and beans, and sweet corn bread, which was surprising and delicious. overall, we liked our meal, but there are a few things they can improve on.

full text doc: it was a sad, sad day in indianapolis history when the pendleton pike ritter's closed down. i still miss that place. fortunately for us, there are still ritter's scattered around the city. if you're looking for a seriously rich, creamy, guilty pleasure of an ice cream, ritter's is your place. to attest to its thickness, they will serve it to you upside down, or used to. i can't get enough of the chocolate custard with oreo topping, but they also have all kinds of decadent sundaes, milkshakes, and floats. mmmmm.

full text doc: i walked in at # eureka in santa barbara ca after 10 and boy it was pretty late for me but i was famished soon as i was seated jessica the server patiently answered all my questions about the # bison # burger i was eyeing. this # sexy monster comes with bacon - infused jalapeno jam! you heard that right, jam on a burger! did i say " uh, weird? full text doc: i went to blackstone looking for some good local brews and a relaxed meal, and it fulfilled both of those demands. the two brews i tried ( $ 3 / 10 oz, $ 4. 50 / 16 oz ) were both really flavorful, with a great aftertaste. i ordered corn chowder ( about $ 5 ) under the impression that it was vegetarian, and it was tasty and filling, but not truly vegetarian ( those pesky little bacon bits get you every time ). the vegetarian options were limited to pizza, nachos, and onion rings, when all i really wanted was a basic veggie burger. our waitress had a good sense of humor and timing, and was very patient with the indecisive members of my party. the decor felt a little too contrived, but with its dark interior, stained glass hanging in the windows, comfort food, and of course the innards - warming beer, blackstone would be pretty perfect for a cold winter's evening.

full text doc: i'm a rather boring frozen yogurt person, as i only eat the plain yogurt with fruit, however they do have multiple options with plenty of healthy and not - so - healthy toppings. in terms of price, it is in line with other frozen yogurt places in the area, the city, and the philly burbs - usually about $ 5 - 6 for a relatively greedy serving size, $ 3 - 4 for an actual, not - a - fatty, serving size. for people who complain about price and compare the recent - ish - wave of frozen yogurt joints with the soft - serve " dairy product " you can get at mcdonalds or mister softee, you apparently don't quite get the point of frozen yogurt - the taste, the natural ( and unnatural ) flavor choices, the health benefits, and, of course, the hipsters behind them who charge the prices they do because thousands of people will pay to participate in this delicious fad. the staff is very friendly, and the location is perfect.

full text doc: there are few things nicer in tucson than taking a morning to go to the botanic gardens. i love to bring a good book and sit at the cafe and read by the fountain. it's a super relaxing and beautiful place! the food is also delicious, and everyone i've met who works here is friendly and helpful. in the summer, we buy our two dogs " dog days of summer " passes, and they enjoy the gardens as much as we do ( and we also appreciate the water bowls that are out for them! ) the butterflies are not to be missed. the gift shop is also really cool and a great place to find gifts - i recently purchased the nighttime flowers kit, which is growing in my kitchen. my only advice is to buy a family membership instead of a one - time admission. if you go 3 times in a year, it pays for itself!

full text doc: scott roofing has put on 2 new roofs for us, one in tahoe, one in reno. both times ( 2002 and 2015 ) everything from the estimate to the completed job was handled with the utmost care and professionalism. i have not had workers this informed, polite, hard working, punctual and non - invasive ( other than all that pounding, i hardly knew they were here ). they arrived, worked a solid 10 hour day and came back the next day ready to go again. ken was always available to answer his phone and my questions. both jobs were planned, begun and completed on time and to my great satisfaction. they even walked around my home at the end of each work day, picked up any trash and blew off the walkways and driveway. my home never looked so good! great company, the best.

full text doc: here's where i agree with ellen and disagree with mark. i think naked tchopstix offers the best sushi in the indianapolis area ( and i have eaten at several - 7 or more - places around here ). the sushi is fresh and the rolls are creative and so tasty. the maui roll - tempura shrimp with avacado, mango and almonds - is amazing. i'm also a huge fan of the corona roll - white tuna with tempura " crunchies, " a citrus sauce and a tiny slice of lime. and the ginger cinammon cooler... heaven! i don't know that the restaurant offers all that much in the way of ambiance - it's a bit cramped, but i hear they're expanding. my husband and i like to go on a saturday or sunday afternoon when it's not half as crazy as it is on friday and saturday nights.

full text doc: i really want to like juan's. i really do. but everything about this place is inconsistent. when you walk in the door, you roll the dice that some combination of the following things will happen : the hostess will seat you quickly, the hostess will inform you that there is a wait and you will grab a delicious or terrible margarita from the bar, the hostess will hardly speak to you and you will mill about in the door way for half and hour. when you are seated, your server will either be sweet and great at her job or alternate between being no where to be found and hipster - snotty. your food will either be fantastic! mexico meets california - - delicious magic awesomeness hitting all the right spots! or you will furrow your brows, try to figure out what the mystery taste is and have diarrhea the next day. ( seriously ) i really want to like you, juan's! get your act together so i can like you!

( but i did mentally note the little jello shots coming from the bar ). my boyfriend and i were bar hopping and walked into this tabu place we've never heard of. downstairs was a small bar with a few people... we glanced at the weekly specials posted on a board and said, " hey this would be good on a weeknight... ". yet nothing special so far. then we turned up the tall narrow staircase that is so common to many bars in philly to a different world. it was dark and neon - y and it was boppin! it was a different sort of dance floor that we laid eyes upon : no obvious grinding, not a lot of women, and jurassic park was playing on both sides of the wall. but that isn't to say that it wasn't fun! the saturday night dj was alternating between techno beats and some non - mainstream yet dance - able rhythms. and bless that air conditioning that other dance - floors lack. generally, this was an eclectic bar with people dressed urban outfitters style, really a style where no one's judging you when you dance like no one

full text doc: go here and try the bottleworks field green salad! it has this amazing vanilla dressing on it that makes me so happy. entrees are all good, nothing outstanding, but all are good. the real reason you want to come is for the sticky toffee pudding. if you want to sample heaven then try out this dessert! if there are no more than three of you, you'll only need one. this dessert is huge! the first time i visited schlafly was the first time i met my fiance's parents. we took the brewery tour and then had a late lunch. the tour was awesome! they have a little gift shop area and you can pack your own six packs. the really interesting thing about this place is its connection with the art community. schlafly is always having an art exhibit or a film night. this is just a well cultured, yet very fun place to be.

full text doc: started with ceviche which was fresh and excellent ( a special ). for my main course i tried their paella ( also a special ), very tasty, but it had the texture of a jambalaya. desert was the " like water for chocolate " surprise which was excellent. overall a solid meal served in average ambiance for a reasonable price. not a bad option if you happen to be walking down the touristy state st in santa barbara.

text: points staff receptionists receptionists point sometimes or the the the the the the the the the back friendly ' ' most thinner waxed 4 both as great overall of
full text doc: i would give this place 5 stars, except the receptionists are extremely rude and arrogant. i somehow always feel like an idiot by the time i leave and sometimes i question why i come back. besides them, the rest of the staff have been great for the most part. i'd highly recommend amy jo or alyssa, as they are both friendly and thorough. at one point, i was talked into purchasing the serum with my points, and i must say it actually works. i now get waxed every 6 weeks, rather than 4, and the hair is much thinner. overall, this place is clean and the technicians are good. i'd recommend this place if you can get past the absolutely god awful receptionists.

full text doc: i came here on a saturday afternoon with a few friends. we were walking along state street and stopped in for some food and drinks. too bad. we had an assortment of burritos, chips, guac, etc. and some margaritas and beer. everything was fine. nothing special. the problem was mostly the service. the servers were rather taciturn, and not particularly attentive. there was a crowd, but nowhere near capacity. that and the fact that the patio is overcrowded. there are way too many tables considering how much space is available. maybe that's why the waiters seemed kinda pissed off, having to weave around everyone.

full text doc: came here in april of 2011. everyone you talk to says this is the place to go and it is for a good reason. i had a wonderful goat cheese tomato soup. my boyfriend, the gumbo. both were amazing and great depth of flavors. the bbq shrimp is messy, but worth it. also, the shrimp and grits was delicious. so creamy and well seasoned. the chocolate cup cake is a must! the portions are generous, but not too big. i was very impressed with the service. high end, but cozy.

full text doc: lost my cfl virginity here back on august 13, and the overwhelming lesson of the evening was : stamps suck shit. yes, it became clear that this was the important conclusion to draw as the esks beat the stampeders in a dramatic last second thriller. i would have thought that it was a hard fought match between two excellent teams, but the fans informed me otherwise with repeated chants in the stadium and surroundings : " calgary sucks. " more specifically, " stamps suck shit. " oh, and that you want the eskimos to score so that a sponsor will donate money to high school football. yes, that is shouted. don't ask. just for sh * ts and giggles, i'd like to see the nfl adopt cfl rules for a week. why? because it leads to awesome football! there are only three downs, the play clock is only 20 seconds, the defense has to line up a yard back from the line of scrimmage, and the field is about 10 % wider and longer - all of which leads to a whole lot more offensive action and risk taking. and less boredom. there are also some random things like twelve players per side and points for missed field goals ( wtf? ). but i'll take the package

full text doc: set in an old acadian mansion, the country club is one of the most amusing gay bars i've ever had the privilege of visiting. featuring a pool - side cocktail bar and acres of decking and deck chairs on which to sun au natural, it was all i could don't to take up permanent residence. seriously the only place i've ever been where one can float about naked with a magarita in hand. oh yes, and the boys are very handsome too. www. countryclubneworleans. com

full text doc: holy mackerel. so many great veggie options so little time! in the past, i have felt that in order to eat breakfast in reno, you had to ingest sausage, bacon, ham, or - god forbid - chicken fried steak ( bleh, what an atrocious, but oh - so popular option for breakfast ) and to order a breakfast meal without one of those belly bombs was a breakie faux pas. not the case here! it seems like i may have found my holy grail of suitable breakfast places. great ambiance. extremely pleasant staff. and all the veggies i could want in my omelet. sigh. contented sigh. i had the jeremiah - mushrooms, onions, avocado, and cheese. i chose not to " ham it up " since i don't eat pig ( or cow for that matter ). i had it with the tomato pesto sauce. the veggies in my omelet were nice and chunky, and nothing was soggy or overly greasy. i am a fan of the endless toast option even though i didn't take advantage... options are good. my jeremiah was delicious overall. the potatoes were definitely not as mary - worthy

full text doc: my wife and i love cheddars! though some call it over rated, it is a great dine in restaurant with great food and reasonable prices. known for their burgers, you can walk out spending under $ 10 for a burger and fries. their chicken fingers are good, and the philly cheese steak sandwich is great! we usually take the edge off with their signature drink, the painkiller. it's a cocoanut rum, schnapps, orange juice and maybe tequila. they limit you to 2, but often bend the rules. ; ^ ) the ambiance is cool. not overly lit, but not depressing dark. very soothing. i like looking at the oversized horizontal ceiling fans and relaxing. there is a waterfall outside, but the weather has prevented us from sitting out there and enjoying it. we'll be up there frequently though

full text doc: great little place to go for the best and largest piece of french texas toast. one slice is more than enough for me and comes coated in powdered sugar and cinnamon. mmm... other great menu items ( that i crave just thinking about it ) would be the home made yogurt in a clay pot - just add honey and / or granola. the crazy juice drink that they make is really good too - albeit i'm still not sure about the price for the drink.

text: tables gras pass of of of of parades beware streets used door beer but pool bartenders rest few catch front mostly mardi ' ' ' ' ' ' cool
full text doc: i'm pretty fond of this place. i haven't been here recently, but i used to come here all the time. mostly for the pool tables. i am good friends with one of the bartenders and have made friends with the rest of them. cool place to chill and catch a few basketball and football games. i'm pretty sure they have a happy hour. just beware during mardi gras season. i couldn't even get in the door during mg this year. the streets were obviously really dirty since the parades pass by right in front, so there were shards of broken beer bottle glass everywhere. there was a cover, which is understandable. i'm a fan. i'd come here anytime.

full text doc: i hosted a pizza making party for my clients a few weeks ago and i gotta say, it was one of the coolest things i've done in a while. the staff was beyond amazing with educating my group on the ins & outs of making perfect pizza dough, along tutoring us on the science of toppings and pairing our entire experience with wonderful flights of wine ( almost bottomless glasses! ), it impressed everyone that attended. i can't wait to come back and have the pizza again, it was amazing. every side dish and appetizer we were served was better than the last. the employees took pictures of our party while we were crafting our masterpieces and i got to spend more time with my clients. overall, a + + + evening. can't wait to come in the spring / summer and sit on the back patio. bonus? they have a side patio for our four legged friends!

full text doc: most of the reviews here are spot on : sucre is a pastisserie / gelaterie / confectionary trying to be very fancy, at which it basically succeeds. the space is absolutely gorgeous, if a little loud due to the abundance of reflective surfaces. the gelato itself is on the icy end of the spectrum, which is a legitimate preference among some. i myself sort of like the iciness, but i can appreciate that some would not. the flavors, however, are delightful : the coconut - basil had fresh green pieces of basil, and the gelato itself had a lovely tart undertone, possibly a citrus? - - it was as perfect a flavor combination as one can achieve. everything else is beautiful. i suspect it is just a seasonal thing, but they had the most beguiling, magical, sigh - inducing chocolate eggs for sale, in dozens of color combinations, and polished to a mirror finish. they were like something that willy wonka would offer you at the factory. my only gripe would be the service on my visit. the girl serving the gelato was hurried and terse, despite there being only two or three people in line. in fact, i don't think she ever said a word to

text: paesano gustaio philly arista lamb seed suckling sesame pig sandwich portion may roast beef recommend roll known free drink excellent enjoyed real )
full text doc: one of the best sandwiches in a city known for sandwiches. i have had the paesano ( roast beef ) and the arista ( suckling pig ) as well as enjoyed a portion of my girlfriends gustaio ( lamb ). they were all excellent. i would recommend this place to anyone looking for a real philly style sandwich ( gotta have the sesame seed roll! ). plus it won't break your budget ( $ 4 - $ 8 ) and you get a free drink. you may have to stand while you eat. the staff is great and friendly as well!

full text doc: location, location, location. expect to pay top dollar for this hotel designed for business people, rich tourists, and conventioneers. it's a nice place to stay and for $ 10 extra, you might be able to swing high - speed internet and breakfast in their restaurant, thirteen, which includes anything on the menu or from the buffet. onsite parking isn't cheap either and the atm in the lobby charges a mighty $ 3. 25 fee. you're in a prime spot downtown in a city in the northeast, just blocks away from major attractions and right near the subway. so if you're looking for convenience, this is the place to be.

full text doc: i like country music in the way that i like what's on the radio as " cross - over " but not really old school country. my friend and i met in nashville and this is just one of those thugs that you have to do. i am a huge fan of prairie home companion and this felt like a close cousin of that. the staff here is amazing... we wanted to take silly pictures around the venue and their photographers took them. when some came out blurry, they walked us around the whole place taking pictures of us and then gave us a deal on the prints so that we could buy more than we normally would have. i spent too much money in the gift shop ( who could resist a purple cowboy hat, i ask... not me! ) and they held my things until the show was over and everything. you might scoff, but my purple cowboy hat was a huge hit at tootsie's later that night. : ) this is a fun family friendly activity that everyone can enjoy. young kids might get bored, but if you are lucky enough to get tickets when there's a celebrity there i'm sure it's amazing. if you are in the area this is something that you must do!

full text doc: never have i so easily given a restaurant a one star review after my experience with the dugout bar. their bland food and horrid service left a lot to be desired upon our visit a month ago. when consulted, management did nothing to solve the problem, not even offering an apology. if you're looking for a family atmosphere and palatable food, the dugout bar is not the place to go.

full text doc: you're eating dinner in an old house, yet it kind of feels like eating in a nursing home in the 1950s. not that that's necessarily a bad thing... it's just a different dining experience than i am used to. hollyhock hill is the poster child for family style dining in indianapolis and generally i don't think it disappoints. it is generally more expensive than a typical restaurant, but i definitely think you get your money's worth. a general overview of the experience : salad / appetizer course : salad with their signature dressing ( it's light and refreshing, beets ( oh.... the beets... love them ), tomato juice, soup, etc. they always bring out a vegetable tray that feels more like a meal for your pet rabbit - i never eat that. main course : your meat choice ( love the fried shrimp, the fried chicken is actually just okay in my opinion ), mashed potatoes, i don't know what they do to their gravy but it is the best i've had and sooo good. i generally put a ton on my plate and dip the rolls into this instead of the apple butter. can't

full text doc: i've only been here twice, both times on the weekend for dueling piano nights. i don't like this place as much to watch the show because there are barely any tables available and they let in way too many people. i find myself either standing near the bar and just listening to the songs, or sitting in the back patio area, which is less crowded. the drinks are ok, but it's a nightmare trying to get drinks at the bar. again, too many people. this is a good place to retreat to when you realize that there's a $ 15 cover at bubinga for men. my guy friends didn't want to pay that much, no matter how many skeezy sluts there were pouring into the place. i'd give rum bullions another try.

full text doc: i'm the first person to review the foodery? you have got to be kidding me. no self - respecting beer snob has been able to live in philly without dropping serious money at this beer - specializing corner store. they have an extensive selection of domestic microbrews, craft beers and imports. their belgian selection is excellent and they also have killer scotch ales ( traquair jacobite... $ 9 a bottle but sooo worth it ). don't think you're going to get off lightly in the cash department. while they do offer a 10 % discount on their mix - a - six, these beers can add up. i'm not saying it's a rip off ( read my review on philadeli ) but it ain't going to be cheap either. also, they've recently hired some staff beer - geeks to walk the novice through the daunting prospect of choosing six beers.

full text doc: for beautiful lashes and brows, look no further! natalie's soft approach and gentle touch is the icing on the cake! i've had horrible lash experiences in the past with another aesthetician that made me want to stop getting them all together. natalie was so patient with me and explained to me the does and dont's and what a good application should feel and look like. never have my lashes hurt or pulled with her. she is so meticulous and truly cares about a thorough application and meeting your desired looked. not only is she amazing at what she does, she's sweet as a peach!

full text doc: juice box yoga reno is the best place in the region to get your sweat on! this is not a corporate business but one where the passion, heart, and vision of the owner ( tanya rose, who is also a teacher ) is evident throughout. from the friendly greeting at the front desk to the spacious dressing rooms divided by gender, you will feel comfortable the moment you walk in the door. if you are new to bikram style yoga ( 26 postures done in a specific sequence, no props, and in a heated room ), or are meeting a new instructor for the first time, you will be able to talk to your instructor beforehand to inform him / her of any injuries or " tweaks " you might have that could impact you during class. grab a glittery rock on your way in if you'd like an ice pack during savasana in addition to the heavenly cold lavender washcloth - your reward for completing class. bring a water container ( you can refill from coolers in the dressing area ) and read up on the website prior to your first class for guidelines / tips. i love the mobile app from which you can peruse the class offerings and sign up. super convenient. the studio is a large mirrored space with rubber

full text doc: simply put, this is one of the best comic book stores you'll find around. a great selection of statues, action figures, comic books ( both old and new ), and graphic novels. the staff is very friendly, the store is is well - organized and there are th occassional events there as well. if you're in the area and interested in the field definitely check the place out.

full text doc: my wife and i stopped here after a 4 hour drive from delray beach for a late lunch. we both ordered the fish tacos. they took quite a while to come out, we asked about them twice, and when they did, they had tiny bits of dry over cooked fish on them. we started eating, but they really were too ridiculous today. we called over our server and asked if this was how they were supposed to look. he said no and said he was embarrassed. he then said he would get more fish and a manager. again it took awhile for the manager to show up, she apologized and said she would resolve and left. then the extra fish the server ordered arrived. from tiny to small and still over cooked. we asked for manager again, and again it took awhile, while waiting the fish we assume, the manager ordered arrived and it was appropriate, but the tacos were now cold and soggy. we ate some of the fish, and we were not charged, but what a mess. we had not been to a cheesecake in about two years, since a salad i was eating had staples in it, and i don't think we will be returning. cheesecake used to be one of our " go to " restaurants

full text doc: this bakery is unlike any of the bakeries in chinatown. from the variety of pastries to the $ 3. 50 rice platters, it is nice to finally see some diversity in the kinds of buns. the dim sum that they have is incredible, and much cheaper then if you were to purchase it at a resturant. although their english is not superb, most of them speak enough to understand your order and make what you want. the smoothies are not made from powder, unlike most places, they use fresh fruit. i definately enjoyed the food i got there and will be going there very often.

full text doc: upon entering establishment i was warmly greeted by both bartenders. despite the fact that it was a full bar i was introduced a open bar seat and quickly handed a happy hour menu. i didn't have to wait past the point of decision and was suggested more options tailored better to my taste. i asked for a glass of white and oysters... my needs were met and the bartender claire suggested i explore other wines outside of my usual sav blanc and i'm so glad i did! great atmosphere, awesome happy hour and wonderful service.

full text doc: stopped by pied piper creamery on a hot sunday in july. it was recommended from a " best of nashville " website and got decent reviews on yelp. the hole - in - the - wall ambience was quaint, but upon entering, there was a distinct mildew odor. the service was pleasant and the person working was generous with samples. perhaps it was an off day, but the selection seemed limited to standard flavors. i tried the trailer trash, which was basically a mix of vanilla and several different candy bars. so many people recommended this flavor, but i found it to be only average in taste... like a pre - mixed do - it - yourself version of something i could order at a cold stone creamery. it's good ice cream, to be sure, but it's nothing to die for. i gave three stars because i like the idea of this place and might come back to try a new unique flavor. my recommendation : no need to go out of your way to try this, but if you're passing by, why not?

full text doc: i really enjoy the bosphorus. it's a place we frequent for lunch. i just ate there the other day with a large group and i think everyone was very impressed. bottom line : hummus is amazing. it's perfectly spiced and oiled and they serve it with grilled pita that's nice and warm. mmmmmmm. the rest of the food is pretty good. the lunch special is a great deal. you get to pick an appetizer and an entree for $ 8. 50. it's very meat oriented, so if you consider yourself a carnivore, then you will probably enjoy it! i love the decor of the restaurant. they have those " turkish eyeballs " staring at you from every direction. it's in an old house and i just think its super intimate. also, i've never had an issue with parking. there is always street parking either in front, in the neighborhood behind ( fletcher place ) or they have a quaint lot in back.

full text doc: okay, club is clean and all, but the staff lacks. here's my story and it is long, but then again, never piss off a novelist. i play racquetball and one night i left my number " 22 street " a's jersey in the place. it was one of those pro jersey's that button up, very high quality and gift from someone special to me. i travel, so when i realize that i cannot get back for days, i call. i know the guy that answered, big guy, in his 20's. he finds my button up, but they have a policy that they can't hold it, so he puts it back and says it will be safe. so of course i get back and it's gone. so messed up!!! and the most b. s. policy that i have ever heard of!!! so i talked to the manager and tell her that she needs to change that policy. she tells me that if it were a piece of jewelry or something valuable, that they would have kept it. my dad gave me that jersey before he passed, so i am glad that they had possession of my property, and then deemed it not valuable and threw it back.

full text doc: i have been going to the marrakesh since 1979 or 80 while growing up in center city. my last trip was last week on july 12th this year. it is great to see some of the philadelphia 1970s restaurant rennaisance establishments still going strong ( others include fri, sat, sun ; warsaw cafe ; astral plane ). marrakesh is currently celebrating it 30th year. kim p's 9 / 21 / 2006 review was great ( and the pictures of her are gorgeous! ) ; and i am glad she and her group had a great time. one question she raised was the lack of wine selection. i am wondering if they charged her for the wine since they are currently giving it away in celebration of the 30th year. free wine is just one of the ways the marrakesh shows you they care about their customers. they don't have a liquor license. they are happy to give you free wine and they are happy to let you byo. while much of the philly's center city dining scene seems to be a reflection of places in new york with weeks long waiting lists and rediculous prices, marrakesh is a happy reminder for me of now defunct places like freddy's pizza ( which became jjs grotto

full text doc: i ordered a burger for dinner from this place and it came out with the center completely raw. besides being nasty, it can also make you seriously ill or dead in a worse case scenario ( and if i died then who would take care of my baby mama? ). maybe the grill chef smoked some bad herb that night. maybe his baby mama was givin'him plenty of drama. whatever the case, my boy was distracted that night because it's hard to f # *! k up a burger. i showed the waitress and she was cool like the fonz about it and removed it from our bill. during my second ( and last ) visit, i ordered a fish sandwich. it smelled fishy, was overcooked, and tasted as bad as it looked / smelled. it reminded me of one of my old girlfriends but that's another story. every time i walk past this joint i still cringe at the images of raw ground beef and mickey rourke's face flashing in my fragile mind. i'm suprised this place received so many positive reviews so far - perhaps my luck was bad. twice. three times would make me the fool wouldn't it?

full text doc: chef bruce is the man who made sushikazu in blue bell a local legend. having ceded sk to family and taking a couple year hiatus he is back in a beautiful restaurant at broad and spruce. first choice, and only choice when we are on ; y 2, is the sushi bar. watching his restrained balletic moves there while producing the city's best sashimi is one of the reasons to go. the beautiful communal / family table adjacent to the bar always the choice when we take the family. order uni here and chef disappears into the back kitchen for a few moments, dispatches the live sea urchin and returns with the roe. the difference between this and packaged uni, which so many restaurants use is much like the difference between realemon and a just picked meyer, the disparity is that great. the asparamaki is a must, the spicy tuna sushi and if you favor eel, the classic roll or to make it simple, sit at the bar and after you order the sushi sashimi combo, let him choose. didn't say a word our first couple vists, then opened up. a very cultured an erudite man, and a supremely talented chef.

full text doc: it's kind of weird to walk through a gallery full of ( less - than - good ) art to get to a restaurant. it felt like it was trying to be a museum cafe, but minus the museum part. i don't know if that makes sense, but that's what i felt. food / drink were excellent - steak salad with steak done exactly the way i wanted it, big ol'glass of wine because i was on vacation and you're allowed to drink all you want during the day when you're on vacation. service was delightful and not too intrusive, although i do wish someone had been more clear about whether i was supposed to seat myself or wait to be seated. it's always awkward to hover in the doorway of a place while you try to get the lay of the land. summary : food = good, ambiance = kind of weird. i'd probably go here again because i like salads and generous pours, but i would be kind of mad about it.

full text doc: you'd think that the braintrust at mcallister ( oh wait, that road ain't there no more... is it? ) and freret would understand the importance of a school of engineering, especially in the wake of hurricane katrina. after the damage to so much infrastructure i'm sure the city could have put structural, mechanical, and civil engineers to good use. but noooooo, herr cowen, in his infinite wisdom, decided to close the school of engineering. pure brilliance. the gripes with my alma mater don't end there ( though the end of engineering is my main one ). there've been so many near - sighted decisions : dissolving newcomb, withdrawing from the sec and tearing down tulane stadium, covering up mcallister drive, a seeming indifference towards local applicants, and on and on. it's a damn shame. the school could rank ahead of rice, emory, or any other " harvard of the south, " if only they could get out of their own way.

full text doc: i find that most of my friends don't seem to know about this place when they come into fountain square! and i have no idea why! this is the place to come to when you are looking for your authentic " mom & pop mexican restaurant. " it's a kid - friendly and family run establishment and it's rarely ever swamped. you're almost always guaranteed to be sat right away and some of the booths have a great view of the street for people watching while you eat. i've been here several times, but i jumped on the chance to go this week after i bought a groupon they had out a while back - $ 10 for $ 20 worth of dinner! i've really only ever had their enchiladas ( verde is the best ), but my friend ordered chimichangas and he was pleased. the meals are large, often enough to take some home for later. don't miss out on the guacamole or margaritas either - both are delish! only reason i'm giving it four stars this go around is service. like i mentioned above, the place is rarely ever super busy, so it shouldn't be difficult to find a server for refills, etc

full text doc: full disclosure here. i designed the acme oyster house website. in fact, i've been with acme since 1999 and still am even though i relocated to los angeles post - katrina. enough said there. still, i love acme and not just because they're a great client ( and they really are ), but because they really provide great service and the food really is good overall. i'm not a po - boy person, so i won't go there but it is at the lakefront location ( now since relocated to metry ) where acme taught me about the power of the oyster loaf. the jambalaya is really one of the best in the area and the oysters? well, c'mon! gumbo poopa is their answer to chowder in a sourdough bread bowl ala san francisco and it's great. anything bad? well, i'm not huge into fried food and in the quarter it dominates. also, i wouldn't come here to get red beans. so many better places to do that in town. desserts are great especially the bananas foster pie.

text: ) explains that but thing food food food and and and and and greasy how . . . . . . . . . . . . your your or or up up ( people behind pull cylinder it honest really start example me move chopped are
full text doc: i'm a sucker for tradition, but to be honest, i've never really understood the way that tradition plays out in the world of philly cheese steaks. and frankie's is a perfect example of why i am confused. let me explain. in philadelphia, a cheese steak is the greasy, cheesy cylinder of junk food waiting for you at the end of a long line at the corner of 9th st. and passyunk, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. it's a simple formula : chopped up steak, a simple roll, cheese wiz, and grilled onions. ( or provolone or american if you're some sort of commie. ) you pull up to the window, state your order as quickly as possible in the official cheese steak lingo, and you move along before the people behind you start grumbling. all of this is beautiful and well worth treasuring - - one of the great food traditions in a nation full of great food traditions. one thing cannot be disputed : frankie's treasures the tradition. the cheese steaks are served on authentic amoroso rolls flown in from philadelphia. a poster on the wall explains how to place your order in the correct lingo.

full text doc: ate there for lunch today. pretty good copy of in - n - out ( ino ). i actually like the fires here better than at ino. i had a double - double ( express double... whatever... ), wife had a cheeseburger. both were nearly identical to ino, except the onions seemed to have a stronger flavor. still excellent. fries were good, a little salty, but that's how i like them. price was about $ 11. i wasn't thrilled with the decor, but it's a burger joint... who really cares. it was clean, good enough for me. if i was in the area and wanted a burger, i'd go back.

full text doc: i am more than a little surprised to see all of the negative comments, especially about carla. the shop overall is a great place, clean and professional with really good artists. they are certainly woman who don't take shit from anyone, as one has to be when they work on south st. every time i have been in there, and i have been there many times and for many hours on end, the artists have been barraged by people who shop for tattoos the way they would shop for a new pair of shoes. anyone with a decent idea and a head on their shoulders is going to be treated fine. i constantly get compliments from people ( both the non - tattooed and the heavily tattooed ) for my tattoos and i never fail to give all of the credit to carla. i even had to start carrying her business cards because i got tired of writing down the shop info for people. the simple fact is that i went to carla for all of my tattoos, and they are all damn good. i highly suggest her for japanese style tattoos ( her specialty ) or art nouveau inspired designs. don't let the negative reviews keep you from getting a really good tattoo.

full text doc: great bbq joint in st. louis - if you are a bbq fan from anywhere i'd recommend you go. parking is a little difficult, and you'll likely have to wait in line, but the food is very good. also, beware that they will run out of certain items if you go later in the day. not the best bbq i've ever had ( from kansas city, so we tend to be bbq snobs ) but a must do if you are a foodie. that's the only reason it's a 4 stars instead of 5.

full text doc: the way out is everything a good bar / club should be : - nice bartenders - generous drinks - a pinball machine - large stage and decent acoustics - rock - em sock - em robots - great decor speaking of decor, lots of bars think they have great decor. whatever. this place has them beat. they have a display case full of nkotb memorabilia, which is horrifying, yet funny. there's a display case behind the bar full of odd mugs and glasses. there are carved masks in the front window that are just creepy as hell once you've had a few drinks. there's string art wall hangings and all sorts of strange things. every time i'm there i see new stuff on the wall i never noticed. the whole place is also hung with old lighted beer signs, almost all featuring african - americans. i've seen plenty of beer signs, but these are worth taking a look at, just to see what beer advertisers were trying to convey. ( lots of suave guys in 70's suits, and pam greer - ish women ) the room where the stage is seems to be decorated entirely in thrift store paintings, plus a large jolly green giant. it '

full text doc: this review is from our visit in april 2006 : 4. 5 stars! we had a fabulous dinner and excellent cocktails at this place. the ambiance was very warm and inviting, and the bartenders knew what they were doing ; ) we got cocktails after wine tasting, since we were a bit " wined - out. " i could see this place as being a nice place to go out, but still casual sb style. loved it, recommend it, and would go back again!

full text doc: this lounge is incredible. now mind you, i was pretty drunk by the time our designated driver hit this joint so i sucked down on ice water given graciously by a friendly bartender. my impressions were red and pink - i don't know if the lights were actually red or if the vinyl booths and seating and neon signs gave off such red heat it created the impression i was in a comfy teenage girls room... that happened to be on the las vegas strip, circa 1975. i remember the bathroom being rather nice... and the music absoultely alternative but really good. the clientiele was definitely a little older, some bike courier, scotch drinkin, flame shirt wearin with some gelled hair and their tanned friends bunching around the booths. it seemed like a decent pick up place... meaning if i went there by myself and struck up a conversation with someone, i would say the probability of me enjoying their company would damn sky high. a little sleazy, but mega comfortable, i rate this as my other favourite bar in tucson. only draw backs were limited seating, confusing exit when completely wasted and it was smokier than any other club i had been to thus far. i mean, i

full text doc: hadn't been there in 5 or 6 years. i really liked the food so i stopped in tonight around 8 : 45 for dinner. when i walked in i noticed how rundown it looked ; very few people there, less than 1 / 4 full, but, there were quite a few employees milling around. i was told i could sit anywhere ; sat down and waited. watched a few people chatting at the check out area. i was thirsty so after waiting 8 minutes i walked up to the check out area and asked for a glass so i could get some water ; i also asked if i could get a waiter. i got the water and went back to my table. eventually someone brought me chips and salsa. someone stopped by asking for my order. i pointed out i hadn't received a menu. after a few moments i was handed one that had thin wet red spots inside on the seams. i ordered and handed back the silver ware i was given, asking for clean silverware. a while later i was handed a sealed package of a napkin and plastic fork, knife and spoon!! when i objected to plastic i was told there wasn't any clean silverware, something about a machine, and getting ready to close. i gave up,

full text doc: i knew as soon as i wandered into this place that i was going to love it. it's tucked away in queen village near south street, and doesn't look like much from the outside. but don't walk by without stopping in! there are books stacked from nearly floor to ceiling in this store that looks deceptively small. it's actually huge!!! it extends for rooms and rooms, seeming to never end! books are organized by category and ( sometimes ) by author, ranging from history to classics to fiction to science and much, much more. if you're willing to dig in a little, this is certainly a place you could get lost in for a while! prices vary significantly depending on the book. most are extremely reasonable, but some rare / higher value books may run you a bit more. definitely don't miss this cute find while in philadelphia. just give yourself some time, you may be there for a while!!

full text doc: the painting of the woman's right breast that stephan c. mentioned comes in handy sometimes. i've found myself meeting and interviewing people here for the very first time a lot. so i needed a recognizable landmark in the room for them to notice and what could be better? aside from that north 3rd is one of my favorite spots to bring a group. the food is really good, the staff is friendly, and the alcohol selection is top notch. and it can be quite roomy, even when it gets crowded which happens a lot. north 3rd also hosts a fun short film night every tuesday that is worth checking out. it's selection can range from funny, to cool, to really weird.

full text doc: anyone who gave this place less than a 4 is nuts for 2 reasons : ( 1 ) their beers, while sometimes not the tastiest or nicest the next morning, are very high in alcohol percentage and definitely do the trick for cheap. ( 2 ) the bar in the summer is amazingly huge, tiki bar, dance floor, several outside bars, patio deck, inside area. it's pretty much the best thing ever. the only downsides? that it gets a bit chilly in philly ( yes, i rhymed ) and the outside closes down. oh, and the food leaves a lot to be desired... but hey, it's a brew pub, they are chefs of alcohol.

full text doc: arrived late at night and there was still a long line. this told us that it had to be good. went with the tenders ( medium seasoning ), pimento mac and cheese, and fries. the fries were seasoned perfectly and chicken was awesome. service was great as well. you order at the counter and then they bring your order to you.

full text doc: my boyfriend and i dined here before seeing a show at the academy of music. our waiter was very nice and very attentive. he offered a suggestion of a drink to my boyfriend and said it was a little spicy, it was disgusting but we give this guy an a for effort and we did not complain about it. we were told of the specials and decided to order from the specials. he got a pork dish and i had a shrimp dish with lobster and squash sauce. i did not care for mine but his pork dish was amazing! the portion sizes are not very big for what you pay. we ended up trading dishes and i was very happy with his, the pork was melt off your mouth delicious. for an appetizer we order traditional guacamole, there was an older spanish lady making guacamole in the open which was pretty neat. the guacamole was a fairly large portion. when we first arrived it was nice and quiet but by the time we left we were squished with the people next to us. if you are claustrophobic like myself i would not recommend this place. the service makes me want to come back but the decor and how close this place has tables does not make me come back.
